794

795 <h1>

796Prostate Cancer Treatment (PDQ)Health Professional Version</h1>

797

798 <div id="cgvBody">

799

800 <div class="summary-sections">

801

802 <nav class="on-this-page" role="navigation">

803

804 <h6>

805On This Page</h6>

806

807 <ul>

808

809 <li>

812</li>

813

814 <li>

867

868

869 <div class="accordion">

870

871

872

873 <section id="_1">

874

875 <h2>

876General Information About Prostate Cancer</h2>

877

878 <div id="_section_1" class="pdq-sections">

879<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

880<h6>

881In This Section</h6>

882<ul>

883<li>

884<a href="#_1679_toc">

885Incidence and Mortality</a>

886</li>

887<li>

888<a href="#_1682_toc">

889Anatomy </a>

890</li>

891<li>

892<a href="#_2090_toc">

893Screening</a>

894</li>

895<li>

896<a href="#_1686_toc">

897Pathology <ul>

898<li>

899<a href="#_2097_toc">

900Gleason score</a>

901</li>

902<li>

903<a href="#_2100_toc">

904Molecular markers</a>

905</li>

906</ul>

907</a>

908</li>

909<li>

910<a href="#_4_toc">

911Clinical Presentation</a>

912</li>

913<li>

914<a href="#_27_toc">

915Diagnostic Evaluation</a>

916</li>

917<li>

918<a href="#_35_toc">

919Prognostic Factors<ul>

920<li>

921<a href="#_38_toc">

922Extent of tumor </a>

923</li>

924<li>

925<a href="#_41_toc">

926Histological grade of tumor </a>

927</li>

928<li>

929<a href="#_45_toc">

930Patient's age and health </a>

931</li>

932<li>

933<a href="#_47_toc">

934Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level </a>

935</li>

936<li>

937<a href="#_2105_toc">

938Serum acid phosphatase levels</a>

939</li>

940<li>

941<a href="#_2107_toc">

942Use of nomograms as a prognostic tool</a>

943</li>

944</ul>

945</a>

946</li>

947<li>

948<a href="#_53_toc">

949Follow-up After Treatment <ul>

950<li>

951<a href="#_2113_toc">

952Follow-up after radical prostatectomy</a>

953</li>

954<li>

955<a href="#_2116_toc">

956Follow-up after radiation therapy</a>

957</li>

958<li>

959<a href="#_2118_toc">

960Follow-up after hormonal therapy</a>

961</li>

962</ul>

963</a>

964</li>

965</ul>

966</nav>

967<div class="pdq-hp-patient-toggle">

968<a href="/types/prostate/patient/prostate-treatment-pdq">

969Go to Patient Version</a>

970</div>

971<p id="_1676" tabindex="-1">

972The median age at diagnosis of prostate cancer is 67 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.1">

9731</a>

974] Prostate cancer may be cured when localized, and it frequently responds to treatment when widespread. The rate of tumor growth varies from very slow to moderately rapid, and some patients may have prolonged survival even after the cancer has metastasized to distant sites, such as bone. The 5-year relative survival rate for men diagnosed in the United States from 2012 to 2018 with local or regional disease was greater than 99%, and the rate for distant disease was 32%; a 97% survival rate was observed for all stages combined.[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

9752</a>

976] The approach to treatment is influenced by age and coexisting medical problems. Side effects of various forms of treatment should be considered in selecting appropriate management.</p>

977<p id="_2566" tabindex="-1">

978Many patients&#8212;especially those with localized tumors&#8212;may die of other illnesses without ever having suffered disability from prostate cancer, even if managed conservatively without an attempt at curative therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.3">

9793</a>

980,<a href="#cit/section_1.4">

9814</a>

982] In part, these favorable outcomes are likely the result of widespread screening with the prostate-specific antigen (PSA) test, which can identify patients with asymptomatic tumors that have little or no lethal potential.[<a href="#cit/section_1.5">

9835</a>

984] There is a large number of these clinically indolent tumors, estimated to range from 30% to 70% of men older than 60 years, based on autopsy series of men dying of causes unrelated to prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.6">

9856</a>

986,<a href="#cit/section_1.7">

9877</a>

988]</p>

989<p id="_2086" tabindex="-1">

990 Because diagnostic methods have changed over time, any analysis of survival after treatment of prostate cancer and comparison of the various treatment strategies is complicated by evidence of increasing diagnosis of nonlethal tumors. Nonrandomized comparisons of treatments may be confounded not only by patient selection factors but also by time trends.</p>

991<p id="_2087" tabindex="-1">

992For example, a population-based study in Sweden showed that, from 1960 to the late 1980s, before the use of PSA for screening purposes, long-term relative survival rates after the diagnosis of prostate cancer improved substantially as more sensitive methods of diagnosis were introduced. This occurred despite the use of watchful waiting or active surveillance or palliative hormonal treatment as the most common treatment strategies for localized prostate cancer during the entire era (&lt;150 radical prostatectomies per year were performed in Sweden during the late 1980s). The investigators estimated that, if all prostate cancers diagnosed between 1960 and 1964 were of the lethal variety, then at least 33% of cancers diagnosed between 1980 and 1984 were of the nonlethal variety.[<a href="#cit/section_1.8">

9938</a>

994][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

995Level of evidence C1</a>

996] With the advent of PSA screening as the most common method of detection in the United States, the ability to diagnose nonlethal prostate cancers has further increased.</p>

997<p id="_2088" tabindex="-1">

998Another issue complicating comparisons of outcomes among nonconcurrent series of patients is the possibility of changes in criteria for the histological diagnosis of prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.9">

9999</a>

1000] This phenomenon creates a statistical artifact that can produce a false sense of therapeutic accomplishment and may also lead to more aggressive therapy. </p>

1001<p id="_2089" tabindex="-1">

1002Controversy exists about the value of screening, the most appropriate staging evaluation, and the optimal treatment of each stage of the disease.[<a href="#cit/section_1.10">

100310</a>

1004-<a href="#cit/section_1.14">

100514</a>

1006]</p>

1007<section id="_1679">

1008<h3 id="_1679_toc">

1009Incidence and Mortality</h3>

1010<p id="_1680" tabindex="-1">

1011Estimated new cases and deaths from prostate cancer in the United States in 2023:[<a href="#cit/section_1.2">

10122</a>

1013][<a href="https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/prost.html" title="https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/prost.html">

1014Cancer Stat Facts: Prostate Cancer</a>

1015]</p>

1016<div class="pdq-content-list">

1017<ul id="_1681">

1018<li>

1019New cases: 288,300.</li>

1020<li>

1021Deaths: 34,700.</li>

1022</ul>

1023</div>

1024</section>

1025<section id="_1682">

1026<h3 id="_1682_toc">

1027Anatomy </h3>

1028<p id="_1684" tabindex="-1">

1029<figure id="figure_1685" class="image-center-medium">

1030<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/450023.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

1031Enlarge</a>

1032<img id="_1685" alt="Drawing of the male reproductive system and urinary system anatomy showing the front and side views of the ureters, bladder, prostate gland, vas deferens, urethra, penis, and testicles. A side view of the seminal vesicle and ejaculatory duct is also shown. The drawing also shows front and side views of the rectum and lymph nodes in the pelvis." title="Drawing of the male reproductive system and urinary system anatomy showing the front and side views of the ureters, bladder, prostate gland, vas deferens, urethra, penis, and testicles. A side view of the seminal vesicle and ejaculatory duct is also shown. The drawing also shows front and side views of the rectum and lymph nodes in the pelvis." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/450023-750.jpg">

1033<figcaption class="caption-container">

1034Figure 1. Anatomy of the male reproductive and urinary systems.</figcaption>

1035</figure>

1036</p>

1037</section>

1038<section id="_2090">

1039<h3 id="_2090_toc">

1040Screening</h3>

1041<p id="_2091" tabindex="-1">

1042Screening for prostate cancer is controversial. In the United States, most prostate cancers are diagnosed because of screening, either with a PSA blood test or, less frequently, with a digital rectal examination. Randomized trials have yielded conflicting results.[<a href="#cit/section_1.15">

104315</a>

1044-<a href="#cit/section_1.17">

104517</a>

1046] Systematic literature reviews and meta-analyses have reported no clear evidence that screening for prostate cancer decreases the risk of death from prostate cancer, or that the benefits outweigh the harms of screening.[<a href="#cit/section_1.18">

104718</a>

1048,<a href="#cit/section_1.19">

104919</a>

1050]</p>

1051<p id="_2092" tabindex="-1">

1052For a detailed summary of evidence regarding the benefits and harms of screening for prostate cancer, see <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-screening-pdq">

1053Prostate Cancer Screening</a>

1054.</p>

1055</section>

1056<section id="_1686">

1057<h3 id="_1686_toc">

1058Pathology </h3>

1059<p id="_2567" tabindex="-1">

1060More than 95% of primary prostate cancers are adenocarcinomas. Prostate adenocarcinomas are frequently multifocal and heterogeneous in patterns of differentiation. Prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) (noninvasive atypical epithelial cells within benign-appearing acini) is often present in association with prostatic adenocarcinoma. PIN is subdivided into low grade and high grade. The high-grade form may be a precursor of adenocarcinoma.[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

106120</a>

1062]</p>

1063<p id="_1687" tabindex="-1">

1064Several rare tumors account for the rest of the cases. These include the following:</p>

1065<div class="pdq-content-list">

1066<ul id="_2095">

1067<li>

1068Small-cell tumors.</li>

1069<li>

1070Intralobular acinar carcinomas. </li>

1071<li>

1072Ductal carcinomas.</li>

1073<li>

1074 Clear cell carcinomas.</li>

1075<li>

1076Mucinous carcinomas.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

107721</a>

1078] </li>

1079</ul>

1080</div>

1081<section id="_2097">

1082<h4 id="_2097_toc">

1083Gleason score</h4>

1084<p id="_2568" tabindex="-1">

1085The histological grade of prostate adenocarcinomas is usually reported according to one of the variations of the Gleason scoring system, which provides a useful, albeit crude, adjunct to tumor staging in determining prognosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

108621</a>

1087] The Gleason score is calculated based on the dominant histological grades, from grade 1 (well differentiated) to grade 5 (very poorly differentiated). The classical score is derived by adding the two most prevalent pattern grades, yielding a score ranging from 2 to 10. Because there is some evidence that the least-differentiated component of the specimen may provide independent prognostic information, the score is often provided by its separate components (e.g., Gleason score 3 + 4 = 7; or 4 + 3 = 7).[<a href="#cit/section_1.22">

108822</a>

1089]</p>

1090<p id="_2098" tabindex="-1">

1091 There is evidence that, over time, pathologists have tended to award higher Gleason scores to the same histological patterns, a phenomenon sometimes termed <em>

1092grade inflation</em>

1093.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

109423</a>

1095,<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

109624</a>

1097] This phenomenon complicates comparisons of outcomes in current versus historical patient series. For example, prostate biopsies from a population-based cohort of 1,858 men diagnosed with prostate cancer from 1990 through 1992 were re-read in 2002 to 2004.[<a href="#cit/section_1.23">

109823</a>

1099,<a href="#cit/section_1.24">

110024</a>

1101] The contemporary Gleason score readings were an average of 0.85 points higher (95% confidence interval, 0.79&#8211;0.91; <em>

1102P</em>

1103 &lt; .001) than the same slides read a decade earlier. As a result, Gleason-score standardized prostate cancer mortality rates for these men were artifactually improved from 2.08 to 1.50 deaths per 100-person years&#8212;a 28% decrease even though overall outcomes were unchanged. </p>

1104</section>

1105<section id="_2100">

1106<h4 id="_2100_toc">

1107Molecular markers</h4>

1108<p id="_2569" tabindex="-1">

1109A number of tumor markers are associated with the outcome of patients with prostate cancer, including the following:[<a href="#cit/section_1.20">

111020</a>

1111,<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

111221</a>

1113]</p>

1114<div class="pdq-content-list">

1115<ul id="_2570">

1116<li>

1117Markers of apoptosis including Bcl-2, Bax.</li>

1118<li>

1119Markers of proliferation rate, such as Ki67.</li>

1120<li>

1121<em class="gene-name">

1122TP53</em>

1123 mutation or expression.</li>

1124<li>

1125p27.</li>

1126<li>

1127E-cadherin.</li>

1128<li>

1129Microvessel density.</li>

1130<li>

1131DNA ploidy.</li>

1132<li>

1133p16.</li>

1134<li>

1135<em class="gene-name">

1136PTEN</em>

1137 gene hypermethylation and allelic losses.</li>

1138</ul>

1139</div>

1140<p id="_2617" tabindex="-1">

1141However, none of these has been prospectively validated, and they are not a part of the routine management of patients.</p>

1142</section>

1143</section>

1144<section id="_4">

1145<h3 id="_4_toc">

1146Clinical Presentation</h3>

1147<p id="_909" tabindex="-1">

1148In the United States, most prostate cancers are diagnosed as a result of screening; therefore, symptoms of cancer are infrequent at the time of diagnosis.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

114921</a>

1150] Nevertheless, local growth of the tumor may produce symptoms of urinary obstruction such as:</p>

1151<div class="pdq-content-list">

1152<ul id="_2093">

1153<li>

1154Decreased urinary stream.</li>

1155<li>

1156Urgency.</li>

1157<li>

1158Hesitancy.</li>

1159<li>

1160Nocturia.</li>

1161<li>

1162Incomplete bladder emptying.</li>

1163</ul>

1164</div>

1165<p id="_2571" tabindex="-1">

1166These symptoms are nonspecific and more indicative of benign prostatic hyperplasia than cancer. </p>

1167<p id="_2094" tabindex="-1">

1168Although rare in the current era of widespread screening, prostate cancer may also present with symptoms of metastases, including bone pain, pathological fractures, or symptoms caused by bone marrow involvement.</p>

1169</section>

1170<section id="_27">

1171<h3 id="_27_toc">

1172Diagnostic Evaluation</h3>

1173<p id="_2102" tabindex="-1">

1174Needle biopsy is the most common method used to diagnose prostate cancer. Most urologists now perform a transrectal biopsy using a bioptic gun with ultrasound guidance. Less frequently, a transperineal ultrasound-guided approach can be used in patients who may be at increased risk of complications from a transrectal approach.[<a href="#cit/section_1.25">

117525</a>

1176] Over the years, there has been a trend toward taking eight to ten or more biopsy samples from several areas of the prostate with a consequent increased yield of cancer detection after an elevated PSA blood test.[<a href="#cit/section_1.21">

117721</a>

1178] </p>

1179<p id="_3175" tabindex="-1">

1180The use of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)&#8722;directed biopsy in the initial diagnostic evaluation of prostate cancer is also being studied, either as a replacement for, or in addition to, standard systematic prostate needle biopsies. The data have been reported primarily by experienced MRI radiologists and urologists in referral centers, and generalizability of results is uncertain. A multicenter randomized trial of 500 patients has shown that, in experienced hands, a multiparametric MRI-directed biopsy is more accurate than a transrectal-guided biopsy to detect clinically significant cancers. MRI led to the detection of more Gleason score (&#8805;7) lesions and fewer Gleason score (&lt;7) lesions, with fewer biopsies overall.[<a href="#cit/section_1.26">

118126</a>

1182] The data suggested that MRI-directed biopsy can replace standard transrectal-guided biopsies. However, a large, single-arm, single-center study of 2,103 men with MRI-visible lesions who underwent both MRI-directed biopsies and standard systematic prostate needle biopsies under ultrasound visualization suggested otherwise.[<a href="#cit/section_1.27">

118327</a>

1184] In that study, MRI-directed biopsies alone led to misclassification of 8.8% of cancers defined as clinically significant (Gleason score 4 + 3 or higher) compared with the combination of both biopsy techniques. Both studies reported only on histology end points at the time of diagnosis, rather than health outcomes on follow-up.</p>

1185<p id="_2103" tabindex="-1">

1186Prophylactic antibiotics, especially fluoroquinolones, are often used before transrectal needle biopsies. There are reports of increasing rates of sepsis, particularly with fluoroquinolone-resistant <em>

1187E. coli</em>

1188, and hospitalization after the procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_1.28">

118928</a>

1190,<a href="#cit/section_1.29">

119129</a>

1192] Therefore, men undergoing transrectal biopsy should be told to seek medical attention immediately if they experience fever after biopsy.</p>

1193</section>

1194<section id="_35">

1195<h3 id="_35_toc">

1196Prognostic Factors</h3>

1197<p id="_36" tabindex="-1">

1198The following factors influence the survival of patients with prostate cancer:[<a href="#cit/section_1.30">

119930</a>

1200-<a href="#cit/section_1.34">

120134</a>

1202]</p>

1203<div class="pdq-content-list">

1204<ul id="_37">

1205<li>

1206<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_38">

1207Extent of tumor</a>

1208.</li>

1209<li>

1210<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_41">

1211Histological grade of tumor</a>

1212.</li>

1213<li>

1214<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_45">

1215Patient's age and health</a>

1216.</li>

1217<li>

1218<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_47">

1219Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level</a>

1220.</li>

1221</ul>

1222</div>

1223<p id="_2562" tabindex="-1">

1224For more information on survival rates, see <a href="https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/prost.html" title="https://seer.cancer.gov/statfacts/html/prost.html">

1225Cancer Stat Facts: Prostate Cancer</a>

1226.</p>

1227<section id="_38">

1228<h4 id="_38_toc">

1229Extent of tumor </h4>

1230<p id="_39" tabindex="-1">

1231When the cancer is confined to the prostate gland, long-term prognosis is excellent. Patients with locally advanced cancer

1232are not usually curable, but 5-year survival is still very good. If prostate

1233cancer has spread to distant organs, current therapy will not cure it. Median

1234survival is usually 1 to 3 years, and most of these patients will die of

1235prostate cancer. Even in this group of patients, indolent clinical

1236courses lasting for many years may be observed.</p>

1237</section>

1238<section id="_41">

1239<h4 id="_41_toc">

1240Histological grade of tumor </h4>

1241<p id="_42" tabindex="-1">

1242Poorly differentiated tumors are more likely to have metastasized before diagnosis and are associated with a poorer prognosis. The most commonly used method to report tumor differentiation is the Gleason score. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1686">

1243Pathology</a>

1244 section.</p>

1245</section>

1246<section id="_45">

1247<h4 id="_45_toc">

1248Patient's age and health </h4>

1249<p id="_46" tabindex="-1">

1250Any benefits of definitive local therapy with curative intent may take years to emerge. Therefore, therapy with curative intent is usually reserved for men with a sufficiently long life expectancy. For example, radical prostatectomy is often reserved for men with an estimated life expectancy of at least 10 years. </p>

1251</section>

1252<section id="_47">

1253<h4 id="_47_toc">

1254Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level </h4>

1255<p id="_48" tabindex="-1">

1256 PSA, an organ-specific marker, is often used as a tumor

1257marker.[<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

125832</a>

1259,<a href="#cit/section_1.33">

126033</a>

1261,<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

126235</a>

1263-<a href="#cit/section_1.40">

126440</a>

1265] The higher the level of PSA at baseline, the higher the risk of metastatic disease or subsequent disease progression. However, it is an imprecise marker of risk.</p>

1266<p id="_2104" tabindex="-1">

1267For example, baseline PSA and rate of PSA change were associated with subsequent metastasis or prostate cancer death in a cohort of 267 men with clinically localized prostate cancer who were managed by watchful waiting or active surveillance in the control arm of a randomized trial comparing radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting or active surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_1.41">

126841</a>

1269,<a href="#cit/section_1.42">

127042</a>

1271] Nevertheless, the accuracy of classifying men into groups whose cancer remained indolent versus those whose cancer progressed was poor at all examined cut points of PSA or PSA rate of change.</p>

1272</section>

1273<section id="_2105">

1274<h4 id="_2105_toc">

1275Serum acid phosphatase levels</h4>

1276<p id="_2106" tabindex="-1">

1277Elevations of serum acid phosphatase are associated with poor prognosis in both localized and disseminated disease. However, serum acid phosphatase levels are not incorporated into the American Joint Committee on Cancer's (AJCC) staging system for prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.35">

127835</a>

1279] </p>

1280</section>

1281<section id="_2107">

1282<h4 id="_2107_toc">

1283Use of nomograms as a prognostic tool</h4>

1284<p id="_2108" tabindex="-1">

1285Several nomograms have been developed to predict outcomes either before radical prostatectomy [<a href="#cit/section_1.43">

128643</a>

1287-<a href="#cit/section_1.46">

128846</a>

1289] or after radical prostatectomy [<a href="#cit/section_1.47">

129047</a>

1291,<a href="#cit/section_1.48">

129248</a>

1293] with intent to cure. Preoperative nomograms are based on clinical stage, PSA level, Gleason score, and the number of positive and negative prostate biopsy cores. One independently validated nomogram demonstrated increased accuracy in predicting biochemical recurrence-free survival by including preoperative plasma levels of transforming growth factor B1 and interleukin-6 soluble receptor.[<a href="#cit/section_1.49">

129449</a>

1295,<a href="#cit/section_1.50">

129650</a>

1297]</p>

1298<p id="_1251" tabindex="-1">

1299Postoperative nomograms add pathological findings, such as capsular invasion, surgical margins, seminal vesicle invasion, and lymph node involvement. The nomograms, however, were developed at academic centers and may not be as accurate when generalized to nonacademic hospitals, where most patients are treated.[<a href="#cit/section_1.51">

130051</a>

1301,<a href="#cit/section_1.52">

130252</a>

1303] In addition, the nomograms use nonhealth (intermediate) outcomes, such as PSA rise or pathological surgical findings, and subjective end points, such as the physician's perceived need for additional therapy. In addition, the nomograms may be affected by changing methods of diagnosis or neoadjuvant therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.44">

130444</a>

1305]</p>

1306</section>

1307</section>

1308<section id="_53">

1309<h3 id="_53_toc">

1310Follow-up After Treatment </h3>

1311<p id="_916" tabindex="-1">

1312The optimal follow-up strategy for men treated for prostate cancer is uncertain. Men should be interviewed and examined for symptoms or signs of recurrent or progressing disease, as well as side effects of therapy that can be managed by changes in therapy. However, using surrogate end points for clinical decision-making is controversial, and the evidence that changing therapy based on such end points translates into clinical benefit is weak. Often, rates of PSA change are thought to be markers of tumor progression. However, even though a tumor marker or characteristic may be consistently associated with a high risk of prostate cancer progression or death, it may be a very poor predictor and of very limited utility in making therapeutic decisions. </p>

1313<p id="_2109" tabindex="-1">

1314Although the PSA test is nearly universally used to follow patients, the diversity of recommendations on the provision of follow-up care reflects the current lack of research evidence on which to base firm conclusions. A systematic review of international guidelines highlights the need for robust primary research to inform future evidence-based models of follow-up care for men with prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_1.53">

131553</a>

1316] </p>

1317<p id="_2110" tabindex="-1">

1318Preliminary data from a retrospective cohort of 8,669 patients with clinically localized prostate cancer treated with either radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy suggested that short posttreatment PSA doubling time (&lt;3 months in this study) fulfills some criteria as a surrogate end point for all-cause mortality and prostate cancer-specific mortality after surgery or radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.54">

131954</a>

1320]</p>

1321<p id="_2111" tabindex="-1">

1322Likewise, a retrospective analysis (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00004001">

1323SWOG-S9916</a>

1324 [NCT00004001]) showed PSA declines of 20% to 40% (but not 50%) at 3 months and 30% or more at 2 months after initiation of chemotherapy for hormone-independent prostate cancer, and fulfilled several criteria of surrogacy for overall survival (OS).[<a href="#cit/section_1.55">

132555</a>

1326]</p>

1327<p id="_2112" tabindex="-1">

1328These observations should be independently confirmed in prospective study designs and may not apply to patients treated with hormonal therapy. In addition, there are no standardized criteria of surrogacy or standardized cut points for adequacy of surrogate end points, even in prospective trials.[<a href="#cit/section_1.56">

132956</a>

1330]</p>

1331<section id="_2113">

1332<h4 id="_2113_toc">

1333Follow-up after radical prostatectomy</h4>

1334<p id="_2114" tabindex="-1">

1335After radical prostatectomy, a detectable PSA level identifies patients at elevated risk of local treatment failure or metastatic disease;[<a href="#cit/section_1.37">

133637</a>

1337] however, a substantial proportion of patients with an elevated or rising PSA level after surgery remain clinically free of symptoms for extended periods.[<a href="#cit/section_1.57">

133857</a>

1339] Biochemical evidence of failure on the basis of elevated or slowly rising PSA alone, therefore, may not be sufficient to initiate additional treatment. </p>

1340<p id="_2115" tabindex="-1">

1341For example, in a retrospective analysis of nearly 2,000 men who had undergone radical prostatectomy with curative intent and were followed for a mean of 5.3 years, 315 men (15%) demonstrated an abnormal PSA of 0.2 ng/mL or higher, which is considered evidence of biochemical recurrence. Among these 315 men, 103 (34%) developed clinical evidence of recurrence. The median time to the development of clinical metastasis after biochemical recurrence was 8 years. After the men developed metastatic disease, the median time to death was an additional 5 years.[<a href="#cit/section_1.58">

134258</a>

1343]</p>

1344</section>

1345<section id="_2116">

1346<h4 id="_2116_toc">

1347Follow-up after radiation therapy</h4>

1348<p id="_2117" tabindex="-1">

1349For patients treated with radiation therapy, the combination of clinical tumor stage, Gleason score, and pretreatment PSA level is often used to estimate the risk of relapse.[<a href="#cit/section_1.59">

135059</a>

1351][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

1352Level of evidence C2</a>

1353] As is the case after prostatectomy, PSA is often followed for signs of tumor recurrence after radiation therapy. After radiation therapy with curative intent, persistently elevated or rising PSA may be a prognostic factor for clinical disease recurrence; however, reported case series have used a variety of definitions of PSA failure. Criteria have been developed by the American Society for Therapeutic Radiology and Oncology Consensus Panel.[<a href="#cit/section_1.60">

135460</a>

1355,<a href="#cit/section_1.61">

135661</a>

1357] It is difficult to base decisions about initiating additional therapy on biochemical failure alone. The implication of the various definitions of PSA failure for OS is not known, and, as in the surgical series, many biochemical relapses (rising PSA only) may not be clinically manifested in patients treated with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_1.62">

135862</a>

1359,<a href="#cit/section_1.63">

136063</a>

1361] </p>

1362</section>

1363<section id="_2118">

1364<h4 id="_2118_toc">

1365Follow-up after hormonal therapy</h4>

1366<p id="_2119" tabindex="-1">

1367After hormonal therapy, reduction of PSA to undetectable levels provides information regarding the duration of progression-free status; however, decreases in PSA of less than 80% may not be very predictive.[<a href="#cit/section_1.32">

136832</a>

1369] Because PSA expression itself is under hormonal control, androgen deprivation therapy can decrease the serum level of PSA independent of tumor response. Clinicians, therefore, cannot rely solely on the serum PSA level to monitor a patient&#8217;s response to hormonal therapy; they must also follow clinical criteria.[<a href="#cit/section_1.64">

137064</a>

1371]</p>

1372</section>

1373</section>

1374<h6 do-not-show="toc">

1415[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1416</li>

1417<li id="section_1.11">

1418Croswell JM, Kramer BS, Crawford ED: Screening for prostate cancer with PSA testing: current status and future directions. Oncology (Williston Park) 25 (6): 452-60, 463, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21717898&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21717898&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1419[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1420</li>

1423[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1424</li>

1425<li id="section_1.13">

1426Wilt TJ, Brawer MK, Jones KM, et al.: Radical prostatectomy versus observation for localized prostate cancer. N Engl J Med 367 (3): 203-13, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22808955&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22808955&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1427[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1428</li>

1429<li id="section_1.14">

1430Hegarty J, Beirne PV, Walsh E, et al.: Radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting for prostate cancer. Cochrane Database Syst Rev (11): CD006590, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21069689&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=21069689&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1431[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

J Natl Cancer Inst 98 (8): 502-3, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16622112&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16622112&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1597[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1598</li>

1599<li id="section_1.57">

1600Frazier HA, Robertson JE, Humphrey PA, et al.: Is prostate specific antigen of clinical importance in evaluating outcome after radical prostatectomy. J Urol 149 (3): 516-8, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7679755&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7679755&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1601[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1602</li>

1603<li id="section_1.58">

1604Pound CR, Partin AW, Eisenberger MA, et al.: Natural history of progression after PSA elevation following radical prostatectomy. JAMA 281 (17): 1591-7, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10235151&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10235151&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1605[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1606</li>

1607<li id="section_1.59">

1608Pisansky TM, Kahn MJ, Rasp GM, et al.: A multiple prognostic index predictive of disease outcome after irradiation for clinically localized prostate carcinoma. Cancer 79 (2): 337-44, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9010107&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9010107&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1609[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1610</li>

1611<li id="section_1.60">

1612Consensus statement: guidelines for PSA following radiation therapy. American Society for Therapeutic Radiology and Oncology Consensus Panel. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 37 (5): 1035-41, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9169810&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9169810&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1613[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1614</li>

1615<li id="section_1.61">

1616Roach M, Hanks G, Thames H, et al.: Defining biochemical failure following radiotherapy with or without hormonal therapy in men with clinically localized prostate cancer: recommendations of the RTOG-ASTRO Phoenix Consensus Conference. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 65 (4): 965-74, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16798415&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16798415&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1617[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1618</li>

1619<li id="section_1.62">

1620Kuban DA, el-Mahdi AM, Schellhammer PF: Prostate-specific antigen for pretreatment prediction and posttreatment evaluation of outcome after definitive irradiation for prostate cancer. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 32 (2): 307-16, 1995.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7538499&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7538499&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1621[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1622</li>

1623<li id="section_1.63">

1624Sandler HM, Dunn RL, McLaughlin PW, et al.: Overall survival after prostate-specific-antigen-detected recurrence following conformal radiation therapy. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 48 (3): 629-33, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11020557&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11020557&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1625[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1626</li>

1627<li id="section_1.64">

1628Ruckle HC, Klee GG, Oesterling JE: Prostate-specific antigen: concepts for staging prostate cancer and monitoring response to therapy. Mayo Clin Proc 69 (1): 69-79, 1994.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7505870&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7505870&amp;dopt=Abstract">

1629[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

1630</li>

1631</ol>

1632</div>

1633

1634 </section>

1635

1636

1637

1638 <section id="_58">

1639

1640 <h2>

1641Stage Information for Prostate Cancer</h2>

1642

1643 <div id="_section_58" class="pdq-sections">

1644<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

1645<h6>

1646In This Section</h6>

1647<ul>

1648<li>

1649<a href="#_93_toc">

1650Staging Tests <ul>

1651<li>

1652<a href="#_2646_toc">

1653Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level</a>

1654</li>

1655<li>

1656<a href="#_1912_toc">

1657Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)</a>

1658</li>

1659<li>

1660<a href="#_3214_toc">

1661Positron emission tomography (PET)</a>

1662</li>

1663<li>

1664<a href="#_1916_toc">

1665Pelvic lymph node dissection (PLND)</a>

1666</li>

1667<li>

1668<a href="#_1918_toc">

1669Transrectal or transperineal biopsy</a>

1670</li>

1671<li>

1672<a href="#_1920_toc">

1673Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)</a>

1674</li>

1675<li>

1676<a href="#_1922_toc">

1677Computed tomography (CT) scans</a>

1678</li>

1679<li>

1680<a href="#_3226_toc">

1681Technetium Tc 99m (99mTc)-methylene diphosphonate (MDP) bone scan</a>

1682</li>

1683</ul>

1684</a>

1685</li>

1686<li>

1687<a href="#_103_toc">

1688Staging Systems </a>

1689</li>

1690<li>

1691<a href="#_60_toc">

1692AJCC Stage Groupings and TNM Definitions </a>

1693</li>

1694</ul>

1695</nav>

1696<section id="_93">

1697<h3 id="_93_toc">

1698Staging Tests </h3>

1699<p id="_2120" tabindex="-1">

1700Most men are diagnosed with prostate cancer at an early clinical stage and do not have detectable metastases. Therefore, they generally do not have to undergo staging tests, such as a bone scan, computed tomography (CT), or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). However, staging studies are done if there is clinical suspicion of metastasis, such as bone pain; local tumor spread beyond the prostate capsule; or a substantial risk of metastasis (prostate-specific antigen [PSA] &gt;20 ng/mL and Gleason score &gt;7).[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

17011</a>

1702]</p>

1703<p id="_1452" tabindex="-1">

1704Tests used to determine stage include the following:</p>

1705<div class="pdq-content-list">

1706<ol id="_1259">

1707<li>

1708<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2646">

1709Serum PSA level</a>

1710.</li>

1711<li>

1712<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1912">

1713MRI</a>

1714.</li>

1715<li>

1716<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3214">

1717Positron emission tomography (PET)</a>

1718.<div class="pdq-content-list">

1719<ul id="_3228">

1720<li>

1721<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3216">

1722Gallium Ga 68 (68Ga)-gozetotide and fluorine F 18 (18F)-piflufolastat PET-CT</a>

1723.</li>

1724<li>

1725<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3222">

1726Fluorine F 18 (18F)-fluciclovine PET-CT</a>

1727.</li>

1728</ul>

1729</div>

1730</li>

1731<li>

1732<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1916">

1733Pelvic lymph node dissection (PLND)</a>

1734.</li>

1735<li>

1736<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1918">

1737Transrectal or transperineal biopsy</a>

1738.</li>

1739<li>

1740<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1920">

1741Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)</a>

1742.</li>

1743<li>

1744<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1922">

1745CT scans</a>

1746.</li>

1747<li>

1748<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3226">

1749Technetium Tc 99m (99mTc)-methylene diphosphonate (MDP) bone scan</a>

1750.</li>

1751</ol>

1752</div>

1753<section id="_2646">

1754<h4 id="_2646_toc">

1755Serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level</h4>

1756<p id="_2647" tabindex="-1">

1757Serum PSA can predict the results of radionuclide bone scans in newly

1758diagnosed patients.</p>

1759<div class="pdq-content-list">

1760<ul id="_2648">

1761<li>

1762In one series, only 2 of 852 patients (0.23%) with a PSA of less than 20 ng/mL had a positive bone scan in the absence of

1763bone pain.[<a href="#cit/section_2.2">

17642</a>

1765]</li>

1766<li>

1767In another series of 265 patients with prostate cancer, 0 of 23 patients with a

1768PSA of less than 4 ng/mL had a positive bone scan, and 2 of 114 patients with a PSA of less than 10 ng/mL had

1769a positive bone scan.[<a href="#cit/section_2.3">

17703</a>

1771]</li>

1772</ul>

1773</div>

1774</section>

1775<section id="_1912">

1776<h4 id="_1912_toc">

1777Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)</h4>

1778<p id="_1913" tabindex="-1">

1779Although MRI has been used to detect extracapsular extension of prostate cancer, a

1780positive-predictive value of about 70% and considerable interobserver variation

1781are problems that make its routine use in staging uncertain.[<a href="#cit/section_2.4">

17824</a>

1783] Ultrasound and MRI, however, can reduce clinical understaging and thereby improve patient selection for local therapy. MRI with an endorectal coil appears to be more accurate for identification of organ-confined and extracapsular disease, especially when combined with spectroscopy.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

17841</a>

1785] MRI is a

1786poor tool for evaluating nodal disease.

1787</p>

1788<p id="_2121" tabindex="-1">

1789MRI is more sensitive than radionuclide bone scans in the detection of bone metastases, but it is impractical for evaluating the entire skeletal system.</p>

1790</section>

1791<section id="_3214">

1792<h4 id="_3214_toc">

1793Positron emission tomography (PET)</h4>

1794<p id="_3215" tabindex="-1">

1795It is becoming more common to use PET-CT with specific radionuclide tracers to stage prostate cancer. Several tracers have been tested and shown the ability to detect either lymph node or distant metastases in certain patients with prostate cancer. </p>

1796<section id="_3216">

1797<h5 id="_3216_toc">

179868Ga-gozetotide and 18F-piflufolastat PET-CT</h5>

1799<p id="_3217" tabindex="-1">

1800Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a transmembrane receptor expressed in high levels in prostate cancer. PSMA can be targeted for imaging with 68Ga-gozetotide and 18F-piflufolastat. These radionuclide tracers have been tested for the imaging of nodes and metastases in the initial staging of intermediate- and high-risk prostate cancer, as well as imaging of suspected posttreatment recurrent disease in patients with an elevated PSA.</p>

1801<p id="_3218" tabindex="-1">

1802A phase III trial included 764 patients with intermediate- or high-risk prostate cancer who underwent 68Ga-gozetotide PET-CT staging. The trial reported a sensitivity of 40% and a specificity of 95% in the detection of nodal disease as compared with PLND.[<a href="#cit/section_2.5">

18035</a>

1804] </p>

1805<p id="_3219" tabindex="-1">

180668Ga-gozetotide PET-CT was studied alongside CT and bone scan for the detection of metastatic disease in men with high-risk prostate cancer. Compared with conventional imaging, 68Ga-gozetotide PET-CT provided increased sensitivity (85% vs. 38%) and specificity (98% vs. 91%).[<a href="#cit/section_2.6">

18076</a>

1808] 68Ga-gozetotide PET-CT was also evaluated to assess recurrent disease and showed a high positive predictive value (PPV) and detection rate.[<a href="#cit/section_2.7">

18097</a>

1810] 68Ga-gozetotide also had better results than 18F-fluciclovine in that context.[<a href="#cit/section_2.8">

18118</a>

1812]</p>

1813<p id="_3220" tabindex="-1">

181418F-piflufolastat PET-CT had a sensitivity of 40% and a specificity of 98% in staging intermediate- or high-risk prostate cancer compared with PLND.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

18159</a>

1816] For the detection of recurrent or metastatic prostate cancer in the context of increasing PSA, 18F-piflufolastat PET-CT had a sensitivity of 95.8% and a PPV of 81.9%.[<a href="#cit/section_2.9">

18179</a>

1818]</p>

1819<p id="_3221" tabindex="-1">

1820Based on these data, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved 68Ga-gozetotide and 18F-piflufolastat PET-CT for the initial staging of patients with prostate cancer and suspicion of metastatic disease, and for the evaluation of potential recurrence based on an elevated posttreatment PSA.[<a href="#cit/section_2.10">

182110</a>

1822,<a href="#cit/section_2.11">

182311</a>

1824]</p>

1825</section>

1826<section id="_3222">

1827<h5 id="_3222_toc">

182818F-fluciclovine PET-CT</h5>

1829<p id="_3223" tabindex="-1">

183018F-fluciclovine PET-CT showed low sensitivity but high specificity in the initial lymph nodal staging of intermediate- and high-risk prostate cancer, compared with PLND.[<a href="#cit/section_2.12">

183112</a>

1832-<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

183314</a>

1834] Compared with conventional imaging, its specificity was similar, but sensitivity was higher for detection of extraprostatic disease.[<a href="#cit/section_2.14">

183514</a>

1836]</p>

1837<p id="_3224" tabindex="-1">

183818F-fluciclovine also detected more bone metastases and was more sensitive and specific than 99mTc-MDP bone scan.[<a href="#cit/section_2.15">

183915</a>

1840]</p>

1841<p id="_3225" tabindex="-1">

1842The FDA approved 18F-fluciclovine PET-CT for the assessment of suspected recurrent disease in men with a rising posttreatment PSA.</p>

1843</section>

1844</section>

1845<section id="_1916">

1846<h4 id="_1916_toc">

1847Pelvic lymph node dissection (PLND)</h4>

1848<p id="_1485" tabindex="-1">

1849PLND remains the most accurate

1850method to assess metastasis to the pelvic nodes, and laparoscopic PLND has been

1851shown to accurately assess pelvic nodes as effectively as an open procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_2.16">

185216</a>

1853]

1854</p>

1855<p id="_1486" tabindex="-1">

1856The determining factor in deciding whether any type of PLND is indicated is

1857when definitive therapy may be altered. For example, radical prostatectomy is generally reserved for men without lymph node metastasis. Likewise, preoperative seminal

1858vesicle biopsy may be useful in patients with palpable nodules who are being

1859considered for radical prostatectomy (unless they have a low Gleason score)

1860because seminal vesicle involvement could affect the choice of primary therapy and

1861predicts for pelvic lymph node metastasis.[<a href="#cit/section_2.17">

186217</a>

1863]</p>

1864<p id="_2649" tabindex="-1">

1865In patients with clinically localized (stage I or stage II) prostate cancer, Gleason pathological grade and enzymatic serum prostatic acid phosphatase values (even within normal range) predict the likelihood of capsular penetration, seminal vesicle invasion, or regional lymph node involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

186618</a>

1867] Analysis of a series of 166 patients with clinical stage I or stage II prostate cancer undergoing radical prostatectomy revealed an association between Gleason biopsy score and the risk of lymph node metastasis found at surgery. The risks of nodal metastasis for patients grouped according to their Gleason biopsy score was 2% for a Gleason score of 5, 13% for a Gleason score of 6, and 23% for a Gleason score of 8.[<a href="#cit/section_2.19">

186819</a>

1869]</p>

1870<p id="_2572" tabindex="-1">

1871Having all patients undergo a PLND is debatable, but in patients undergoing a radical retropubic

1872prostatectomy, nodal status is usually ascertained as a matter of course. Evidence is mounting that PLND is likely unnecessary in patients with a PSA less than 20 ng/mL and a low Gleason score who are undergoing radical perineal prostatectomy. This is especially true for patients whose malignancy was not palpable but detected on ultrasound.[<a href="#cit/section_2.18">

187318</a>

1874,<a href="#cit/section_2.20">

187520</a>

1876]</p>

1877</section>

1878<section id="_1918">

1879<h4 id="_1918_toc">

1880Transrectal or transperineal biopsy</h4>

1881<p id="_2123" tabindex="-1">

1882The most common means to establish a diagnosis and determine the Gleason score in cases of suspected prostate cancer is by needle biopsy. Most urologists now perform a transrectal biopsy using a bioptic gun with ultrasound guidance. Less frequently, a transperineal ultrasound-guided approach can be used for those patients who may be at increased risk of complications from a transrectal approach.[<a href="#cit/section_2.21">

188321</a>

1884] Over the years, there has been a trend toward taking eight to ten or more biopsy samples from several areas of the prostate with a consequent increased yield of cancer detection after an elevated PSA blood test.[<a href="#cit/section_2.1">

18851</a>

1886] </p>

1887</section>

1888<section id="_1920">

1889<h4 id="_1920_toc">

1890Transrectal ultrasound (TRUS)</h4>

1891<p id="_1921" tabindex="-1">

1892TRUS may facilitate diagnosis by directing needle

1893biopsy; however, ultrasound is operator dependent and does not assess lymph

1894node size. </p>

1895<p id="_2547" tabindex="-1">

1896A prospective multi-institutional study of preoperative

1897TRUS in men with clinically localized prostate cancer eligible for

1898radical prostatectomy showed that TRUS was no better than digital rectal

1899examination in predicting extracapsular tumor extension or seminal vesicle

1900involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_2.22">

190122</a>

1902]</p>

1903</section>

1904<section id="_1922">

1905<h4 id="_1922_toc">

1906Computed tomography (CT) scans</h4>

1907<p id="_1923" tabindex="-1">

1908CT scans can detect grossly enlarged lymph nodes but

1909poorly define intraprostatic features;[<a href="#cit/section_2.23">

191023</a>

1911] therefore, it is not reliable for

1912the staging of pelvic node disease when compared with surgical staging.[<a href="#cit/section_2.24">

191324</a>

1914]</p>

1915</section>

1916<section id="_3226">

1917<h4 id="_3226_toc">

1918Technetium Tc 99m (99mTc)-methylene diphosphonate (MDP) bone scan</h4>

1919<p id="_3227" tabindex="-1">

1920A 99mTc-MDP bone scan is the most widely used test for metastasis to the bone, which is the most common site of

1921distant tumor spread.</p>

1922</section>

1923</section>

1924<section id="_103">

1925<h3 id="_103_toc">

1926Staging Systems </h3>

1927<p id="_104" tabindex="-1">

1928Historically, two systems have been in common use for the staging of prostate cancer.</p>

1929<div class="pdq-content-list">

1930<ul id="_105">

1931<li>

1932In 1975, the Jewett

1933system (stage A through stage D) was described and has since been

1934modified.[<a href="#cit/section_2.25">

193525</a>

1936] This staging system is no longer in common use, but older studies and publications may refer to it.</li>

1937<li>

1938In 1997, the American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and the International Union Against Cancer adopted a revised TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) system, which used the same broad T-stage categories as the Jewett system but included subcategories of T stage, such as a stage to describe patients diagnosed through PSA screening. This revised TNM system more precisely stratifies newly diagnosed patients.</li>

1939</ul>

1940</div>

1941</section>

1942<section id="_60">

1943<h3 id="_60_toc">

1944AJCC Stage Groupings and TNM Definitions </h3>

1945<p id="_1202" tabindex="-1">

1946The AJCC has designated staging by TNM classification.[<a href="#cit/section_2.26">

194726</a>

1948]</p>

1949<table id="_3118" class="table-default expandable-container">

2070<tr>

2071<td colspan="6">

2072The explanations for superscripts b through g are at the end of <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3085">

2073Table 5</a>

2074.</td>

2075</tr>

2076</TFoot>

2077<tbody>

2078<tr>

2079<td rowspan="11">

2080I</td>

2081<td rowspan="8">

2082cT1a&#8211;c, cT2a, N0, M0</td>

2083<td>

2084cT1 = Clinically inapparent tumor that is not palpable.</td>

2085<td rowspan="8">

2086&lt;10</td>

2087<td rowspan="8">

2088Gleason Score, &#8804;6; Gleason Pattern, &#8804;3+3 (1). </td>

2089<td rowspan="11">

2090<figure id="figure_3136" class="image-center-medium">

2091<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795013.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2092Enlarge</a>

2093<img id="_3136" alt="Two panel drawing of stage I prostate cancer; the top panel shows cancer in less than one-half of the right side of the prostate found by needle biopsy. The bottom panel shows cancer in less than one-half of the left side of the prostate found by digital rectal exam. In both panels, the PSA level is less than 10 and the Grade Group is 1. The bladder, rectum, and urethra are also shown." title="Two panel drawing of stage I prostate cancer; the top panel shows cancer in less than one-half of the right side of the prostate found by needle biopsy. The bottom panel shows cancer in less than one-half of the left side of the prostate found by digital rectal exam. In both panels, the PSA level is less than 10 and the Grade Group is 1. The bladder, rectum, and urethra are also shown." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795013-750.jpg">

2094</figure>

2095</td>

2096</tr>

2097<tr>

2098<td>

2099&#8211;cT1a = Tumor incidental histological finding in &#8804;5% of tissue resected.</td>

2100</tr>

2101<tr>

2102<td>

2103&#8211;cT1b = Tumor incidental histological finding in &gt;5% of tissue resected.</td>

2104</tr>

2105<tr>

2106<td>

2107&#8211;cT1c = Tumor identified by needle biopsy found in one or both sides, but not palpable.</td>

2108</tr>

2109<tr>

2110<td>

2111cT2 = Tumor is palpable and confined within prostate.</td>

2112</tr>

2113<tr>

2114<td>

2115&#8211;cT2a = Tumor involves &#189; of one side or less.</td>

2116</tr>

2117<tr>

2118<td>

2119N0 = No positive regional nodes.</td>

2120</tr>

2121<tr>

2122<td>

2123M0 = No distant metastasis.</td>

2124</tr>

2125<tr>

2126<td rowspan="3">

2127pT2, N0, M0</td>

2128<td>

2129pT2 = Organ confined.</td>

2130<td rowspan="3">

2131&lt;10</td>

2132<td rowspan="3">

2133Gleason Score, &#8804;6; Gleason Pattern, &#8804;3+3 (1). </td>

2134</tr>

2135<tr>

2136<td>

2137N0 = No positive regional nodes.</td>

2138</tr>

2139<tr>

2140<td>

2141M0 = No distant metastasis.</td>

2142</tr>

2622<td colspan="6">

2623T = primary tumor; N = regional lymph nodes; M = distant metastasis; cT = clinical T; PSA = prostate-specific antigen; pT = pathological T.</td>

2625<tr>

2626<td colspan="6">

2627<span class="sup">

2628a</span>

2629Adapted from AJCC: Prostate. In: Amin MB, Edge SB, Greene FL, et al., eds.: <em>

2630AJCC Cancer Staging Manual</em>

2631. 8th ed. New York, NY: Springer, 2017, pp. 715&#8211;26.</td>

2632</tr>

2633<tr>

2634<td colspan="6">

2635<span class="sup">

2636b</span>

2637When either PSA or Grade Group is not available, grouping should be determined by T category and/or either PSA or Grade Group as available.</td>

2638</tr>

2639<tr>

2640<td colspan="6">

2641<span class="sup">

2642c</span>

2643There is no pathological T1 classification.</td>

2644</tr>

2645<tr>

2646<td colspan="6">

2647<span class="sup">

2648d</span>

2649Positive surgical margin should be indicated by an R1 descriptor, indicating residual microscopic disease.</td>

2650</tr>

2651<tr>

2652<td colspan="6">

2653<span class="sup">

2654e</span>

2655When more than one site of metastasis is present, the most advanced category is used. M1c is most advanced.</td>

2656</tr>

2657<tr>

2658<td colspan="6">

2659<span class="sup">

2660f</span>

2661PSA values are used to assign this category.</td>

2662</tr>

2663<tr>

2664<td colspan="6">

2665<span class="sup">

2666g</span>

2667Recently the Gleason system has been compressed into so-called Grade Groups.[<a href="#cit/section_2.27">

266827</a>

2669]</td>

2670</tr>

2671</TFoot>

2672<tbody>

2673<tr>

2674<td rowspan="5">

2675IVA</td>

2676<td rowspan="5">

2677Any T, N1, M0</td>

2678<td rowspan="3">

2679Any T = See descriptions in <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3084">

2680Table 4</a>

2681, Stage IIIC.</td>

2682<td rowspan="5">

2683See Any PSA values in <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3084">

2684Table 4</a>

2685, Stage IIIC.</td>

2686<td>

2687Gleason Score, &#8804;6; Gleason Pattern, &#8804;3+3 (1). </td>

2688<td rowspan="5">

2689<figure id="figure_3143" class="image-center">

2690<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795020.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2691Enlarge</a>

2692<img id="_3143" alt="Stage IVA prostate cancer; drawing shows cancer in one side of the prostate and in nearby lymph nodes. The PSA can be any level and the Grade Group is 1 ,2, 3, 4, or 5. Also shown are the bladder, rectum, and urethra." title="Stage IVA prostate cancer; drawing shows cancer in one side of the prostate and in nearby lymph nodes. The PSA can be any level and the Grade Group is 1 ,2, 3, 4, or 5. Also shown are the bladder, rectum, and urethra." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795020-750.jpg">

2693</figure>

2694</td>

2695</tr>

2696<tr>

2697<td>

2698Gleason Score, 7; Gleason Pattern 3+4 (2).</td>

2699</tr>

2700<tr>

2701<td>

2702Gleason Score, 7; Gleason Pattern, 4+3 (3).</td>

2703</tr>

2704<tr>

2705<td>

2706N1 = Metastases in regional node(s).</td>

2707<td>

2708Gleason Score, 8; Gleason Pattern, 4+4, 3+5, or 5+3 (4).</td>

2709</tr>

2710<tr>

2711<td>

2712M0 = No distant metastasis.</td>

2713<td>

2714Gleason Score, 9 or 10; Gleason Pattern, 4+5, 5+4, or 5+5 (5).</td>

2715</tr>

2716<tr>

2717<td rowspan="8">

2718IVB</td>

2719<td rowspan="8">

2720Any T, Any N, M1</td>

2721<td>

2722Any T = See descriptions in <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3084">

2723Table 4</a>

2724, Stage IIIC.</td>

2725<td rowspan="8">

2726See Any PSA values <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3084">

2727Table 4</a>

2728, Stage IIIC.</td>

2729<td rowspan="8">

2730Any Gleason Score; Gleason Pattern (Grade Group) = See above in Stage IVA.</td>

2731<td rowspan="8">

2732<figure id="figure_3144" class="image-center">

2733<a href="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795021.jpg" target="_blank" class="article-image-enlarge">

2734Enlarge</a>

2735<img id="_3144" alt="Stage IVB prostate cancer; drawing shows other parts of the body where prostate cancer may spread, including the distant lymph nodes and bones. An inset shows cancer cells spreading from the prostate, through the blood and lymph system, to another part of the body where metastatic cancer has formed." title="Stage IVB prostate cancer; drawing shows other parts of the body where prostate cancer may spread, including the distant lymph nodes and bones. An inset shows cancer cells spreading from the prostate, through the blood and lymph system, to another part of the body where metastatic cancer has formed." src="https://nci-media.cancer.gov/pdq/media/images/795021-750.jpg">

2736</figure>

2737</td>

2738</tr>

2739<tr>

2740<td>

2741NX = Regional nodes were not assessed.</td>

2742</tr>

2743<tr>

2744<td>

2745N0 = No positive regional nodes.</td>

2746</tr>

2747<tr>

2748<td>

2749N1 = Metastases in regional node(s).</td>

2750</tr>

2751<tr>

2752<td>

2753M1 = Distant metastasis.</td>

2754</tr>

2755<tr>

2756<td>

2757&#8211;M1a = Nonregional lymph node(s).</td>

2758</tr>

2759<tr>

2760<td>

2761&#8211;M1b = Bone(s).</td>

2762</tr>

2763<tr>

2764<td>

2765&#8211;M1c = Other site(s) with or without bone disease.</td>

2766</tr>

2767</tbody>

2768</table>

2769</section>

2886 <h2>

2887Treatment Option Overview for Prostate Cancer</h2>

2889 <div id="_section_62" class="pdq-sections">

2985<a href="#_2279_toc">

2986Neoadjuvant Hormonal Therapy </a>

2987</li>

2988<li>

2989<a href="#_2267_toc">

2990Bicalutamide</a>

2991</li>

2992</ul>

2993</nav>

2994<p id="_2136" tabindex="-1">

2995Local treatment modalities are associated with prolonged disease-free survival (DFS) for many patients with localized prostate cancer but are rarely curative in patients with locally extensive tumors. Because of clinical understaging using current diagnostic techniques, even when the cancer appears clinically localized to the prostate gland, some patients develop disseminated tumors after local therapy with surgery or radiation. </p>

2996<p id="_2137" tabindex="-1">

2997Treatment options for each stage of prostate cancer are presented in <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1050">

2998Table 6</a>

2999.</p>

3000<table id="_1050" class="table-default expandable-container">

3001<caption>

3002Table 6. Treatment Options by Stage for Prostate Cancer</caption>

3003<colgroup>

3004<col width="43.10%">

3005<col width="56.89%">

3006</colgroup>

3007<THead>

3008<tr>

3009<th align="Center" scope="col">

3010Stage (<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_60">

3011TNM Definitions</a>

3012) </th>

3013<th align="Center" scope="col">

3014Treatment Options</th>

3015</tr>

3016</THead>

3020EBRT = external-beam radiation therapy; LH-RH = luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone; PARP = poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase; TURP = transurethral resection of the prostate.</td>

3021</tr>

3068 </td>

3069</tr>

3228BRCA1</em>

3229, <em class="gene-name">

3230BRCA2</em>

3232ATM</em>

3233 mutations</a>

3239Cryosurgery</a>
