3241</tr>

3242</tbody>

3243</table>

3244<p id="_2991" tabindex="-1">

3245Side effects of each of the treatment approaches are covered in the relevant sections below. Patient-reported adverse effects differ substantially across the options for management of clinically localized disease, with few direct comparisons, and include watchful waiting/active surveillance/active monitoring, radical prostatectomy, and radiation therapy. The differences in adverse effects can play an important role in patient choice among treatment options. Detailed comparisons of these effects have been reported in population-based cohort studies, albeit with relatively short follow-up times of 2 to 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_3.1">

32461</a>

3247,<a href="#cit/section_3.2">

32482</a>

3249] </p>

3250<section id="_2283">

3251<h3 id="_2283_toc">

3252Watchful Waiting or Active Surveillance/Active Monitoring</h3>

3253<p id="_2284" tabindex="-1">

3254Asymptomatic patients of advanced age or with concomitant illness may warrant

3255consideration of careful observation without immediate active treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_3.3">

32563</a>

3257,<a href="#cit/section_3.4">

32584</a>

3259] Watch and wait, observation, expectant management, and active surveillance/active monitoring are terms indicating a strategy that does not employ <em>

3260immediate</em>

3261 therapy with curative intent.</p>

3262<p id="_2285" tabindex="-1">

3263Watchful waiting and active surveillance/active monitoring are the most commonly used terms, and the literature does not always clearly distinguish them, making the interpretation of results difficult. The general concept of watchful waiting is patient follow-up with the application of palliative care as needed to alleviate symptoms of tumor progression. There is no planned attempt at curative therapy at any point in follow-up. For example, transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) or hormonal therapy may be used to alleviate tumor-related urethral obstruction should there be local tumor growth; hormonal therapy or bone radiation might be used to alleviate pain from metastases. Radical prostatectomy has been compared with watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring in men with early-stage disease (i.e., clinical stages T1b, T1c, or T2).[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

32645</a>

3265] For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2281">

3266Radical Prostatectomy</a>

3267 section.</p>

3268<p id="_2573" tabindex="-1">

3269In contrast, the strategy behind active surveillance/active monitoring is to defer therapy for clinically localized disease but regularly follow the patient and initiate local therapy with curative intent if there are any signs of local tumor progression.[<a href="#cit/section_3.6">

32706</a>

3271-<a href="#cit/section_3.9">

32729</a>

3273] The intention is to avoid the morbidity of therapy in men who have indolent or nonprogressive disease but preserve the ability to cure them should the tumor progress. Active surveillance/active monitoring often involves the following:</p>

3274<div class="pdq-content-list">

3275<ul id="_2574">

3276<li>

3277Regular patient visits.</li>

3278<li>

3279Digital rectal examinations.</li>

3280<li>

3281Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing.</li>

3282<li>

3283Transrectal ultrasound (in some series).</li>

3284<li>

3285Transrectal needle biopsies (in some series).</li>

3286</ul>

3287</div>

3288<p id="_2575" tabindex="-1">

3289Patient selection, testing intervals, and specific tests, as well as criteria for intervention, are arbitrary and not established in controlled trials. </p>

3290<p id="_2528" tabindex="-1">

3291In the United States, as in other settings with widespread PSA screening, the results of conservative management of localized prostate cancer are particularly favorable. In the aggregate, men managed by watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring (using various criteria, depending upon the study) have had very favorable prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortalities ranging from about 1% to 10% (with the most favorable rates in more recent series).[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

329210</a>

3293-<a href="#cit/section_3.18">

329418</a>

3295] Most men with screen-detected prostate cancer may, therefore, be candidates for active surveillance/active monitoring, with definitive therapy reserved for signs of tumor progression. This has been shown most clearly in the large Prostate Testing for Cancer Treatment (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02044172">

3296ProtecT</a>

3297 [NCT02044172 and ISRCTN20141297]) randomized trial that compared active monitoring, radical prostatectomy, and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

329819</a>

3299] For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2281">

3300Radical Prostatectomy</a>

3301 section.</p>

3302<p id="_2296" tabindex="-1">

3303For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_69">

3304Treatment of Stage II Prostate Cancer</a>

3305 section.</p>

3306</section>

3307<section id="_2281">

3308<h3 id="_2281_toc">

3309Radical Prostatectomy</h3>

3310<p id="_2282" tabindex="-1">

3311A radical prostatectomy is usually reserved for patients who:[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

331220</a>

3313-<a href="#cit/section_3.22">

331422</a>

3315]</p>

3316<div class="pdq-content-list">

3317<ul id="_2151">

3318<li>

3319Are in good health and elect surgical intervention.</li>

3320<li>

3321Have tumor confined to the prostate gland (stage I and stage II).</li>

3322</ul>

3323</div>

3324<p id="_2152" tabindex="-1">

3325Open prostatectomy can be performed by the perineal or retropubic approach. The perineal approach requires a separate incision for lymph node dissection. Laparoscopic lymphadenectomy is technically possible.[<a href="#cit/section_3.23">

332623</a>

3327] Robot-assisted prostatectomy is an alternative to open prostatectomy and has become the most common technique in developed countries. In experienced hands, functional outcomes between open and robot-assisted prostatectomy appear very similar, at least in the short- to mid-term. In a randomized trial of 308 men suitable for prostatectomy, urinary, sexual, and bowel functional outcomes were similar between open retropubic and robotic surgeries at a median follow-up of 24 months.[<a href="#cit/section_3.24">

332824</a>

3329] The sample size and duration of follow-up were too small to detect meaningful differences in cancer outcomes.</p>

3330<p id="_3075" tabindex="-1">

3331For small, well-differentiated nodules, the incidence of positive pelvic nodes is less than 20%, and pelvic node dissection may be omitted.[<a href="#cit/section_3.25">

333225</a>

3333] With larger, less-differentiated tumors, a pelvic lymph node dissection is more important. In these cases, the value of open surgical or laparoscopic pelvic node dissection is not therapeutic, but it spares patients with positive nodes the morbidity of prostatectomy. Radical prostatectomy is usually not performed if a frozen-section evaluation of pelvic nodes reveals metastases; these patients should be considered for entry into existing clinical trials or receive radiation therapy to control local symptoms. </p>

3334<p id="_2577" tabindex="-1">

3335The role of preoperative (neoadjuvant) hormonal therapy is not established.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

333626</a>

3337,<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

333827</a>

3339]</p>

3340<p id="_2153" tabindex="-1">

3341After radical prostatectomy, pathological evaluation stratifies tumor extent into the following classes:</p>

3342<div class="pdq-content-list">

3343<ul id="_2154">

3344<li>

3345 Margin-positive disease&#8212;The incidence of disease recurrence increases when the tumor margins are positive.[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

334610</a>

3347,<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

334828</a>

3349,<a href="#cit/section_3.29">

335029</a>

3351] Results of the outcome of patients with positive surgical margins have not been systematically reported.</li>

3352<li>

3353Specimen-confined disease&#8212;The incidence of disease recurrence increases when the tumor is not specimen-confined (extracapsular).[<a href="#cit/section_3.10">

335410</a>

3355,<a href="#cit/section_3.28">

335628</a>

3357]</li>

3358<li>

3359Organ-confined disease&#8212;Patients with extraprostatic disease (not organ-confined) are suitable candidates for clinical trials of which the Radiation Therapy Oncology Group's (RTOG) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002874">

3360RTOG-9601</a>

3361 trial (NCT00002874), was an example. These trials have included evaluation of postoperative radiation delivery, cytotoxic agents, and hormonal treatment using luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonists and/or antiandrogens. </li>

3362</ul>

3363</div>

3364<section id="_2155">

3365<h4 id="_2155_toc">

3366Radical prostatectomy compared with other treatment options</h4>

3367<p id="_2156" tabindex="-1">

3368In 1993, a structured literature review of 144 papers was done in an attempt to compare the three primary treatment strategies for clinically localized prostate cancer:[<a href="#cit/section_3.30">

336930</a>

3370]</p>

3371<div class="pdq-content-list">

3372<ol id="_2157">

3373<li>

3374 Radical prostatectomy.</li>

3375<li>

3376Definitive radiation therapy.</li>

3377<li>

3378 Observation (watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring).</li>

3379</ol>

3380</div>

3381<p id="_2158" tabindex="-1">

3382The authors concluded that poor reporting and selection factors within all series precluded a valid comparison of efficacy for the three management strategies.</p>

3383<p id="_2159" tabindex="-1">

3384In a literature review of case series of patients with palpable, clinically localized disease, the authors found that 10-year prostate&#8722;cancer-specific survival rates were best in radical prostatectomy series (about 93%), worst in radiation therapy series (about 75%), and intermediate with deferred treatment (about 85%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.31">

338531</a>

3386] Because it is highly unlikely that radiation therapy would worsen disease-specific survival, the most likely explanation is that selection factors affect choice of treatment. Such selection factors make comparisons of therapeutic strategies imprecise.[<a href="#cit/section_3.32">

338732</a>

3388]</p>

3389<p id="_1275" tabindex="-1">

3390Radical prostatectomy has been compared with watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring in men with early-stage disease (i.e., clinical stages T1b, T1c, or T2) in randomized trials, with conflicting results. The difference in results may be the result of differences in how the men were diagnosed with prostate cancer. </p>

3391<p id="_1276" tabindex="-1">

3392Evidence (radical prostatectomy vs. watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring):</p>

3393<div class="pdq-content-list">

3394<ol id="_1988">

3395<li>

3396In a randomized clinical trial performed in Sweden in the pre-PSA screening era, 695 men with prostate cancer were randomly assigned to radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting. Only about 5% of the men in the trial had been diagnosed by PSA screening. Therefore, the men had more extensive local disease than is typically the case in men diagnosed with prostate cancer in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_3.33">

339733</a>

3398-<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

339935</a>

3400]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3401<ul id="_2650">

3402<li>

3403The cumulative overall mortality at 18 years was 56.1% in the radical prostatectomy arm and 68.9% in the watchful waiting study arm (absolute difference, 12.7%; 95% confidence interval [CI], 5.1&#8211;20.3 percentage points; relative risk [RR]<sub>

3404death, </sub>

34050.71; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.86).[<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

340635</a>

3407][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3408Level of evidence A1</a>

3409]</li>

3410<li>

3411 The cumulative incidence of prostate cancer deaths at 18 years was 17.7% versus 28.7% (absolute difference, 11.0%; 95% CI, 4.5&#8211;17.5 percentage points; RR<sub>

3412death</sub>

3413 from prostate cancer, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.77).[<a href="#cit/section_3.35">

341435</a>

3415]</li>

3416<li>

3417In a post-hoc&#8211;subset analysis, the improvement in overall and prostate cancer-specific mortality associated with radical prostatectomy was restricted to men younger than 65 years.

3418</li>

3419</ul>

3420</div>

3421</li>

3422<li>

3423The Prostate Intervention Versus Observation Trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00007644">

3424PIVOT-1</a>

3425 or VA-CSP-407) is a randomized trial conducted in the PSA screening era that directly compared radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting. From November 1994 through January 2002, 731 men aged 75 years or younger with localized prostate cancer (stage T1&#8211;2, NX, M0, with a blood PSA &lt;50 ng/mL) and a life expectancy of at least 10 years were randomly assigned to radical prostatectomy or watchful waiting.[<a href="#cit/section_3.5">

34265</a>

3427,<a href="#cit/section_3.36">

342836</a>

3429,<a href="#cit/section_3.37">

343037</a>

3431][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3432Level of evidence A1</a>

3433]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3434<ul id="_2631">

3435<li>

3436About 50% of the men had nonpalpable, screen-detected disease.</li>

3437<li>

3438After a median follow-up of 12.7 years (range up to about 19.5 years), the all-cause mortality was 61.3% in the prostatectomy arm versus 66.8% in the watchful-waiting study arm, with an absolute difference of 5.5 percentage points (95% CI, -1.5&#8211;12.4) that was not statistically significant (hazard ratio [HR], 0.84; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;1.01). Prostate cancer-specific mortality was 7.4% versus 11.4%, and it also was not statistically significant (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;1.02).</li>

3439<li>

3440 Although treatment for disease progression was given more frequently in the observation arm of the study, most of the treatment was for asymptomatic, local, or biochemical (PSA) progression.</li>

3441<li>

3442 As expected, urinary incontinence and erectile/sexual dysfunction was more common in the prostatectomy group during at least 10 years of follow-up. Absolute differences in patient-reported use of absorbent urinary pads was greater in the surgery group by more than 30 percentage points at all time points for at least 10 years. Disease- or treatment-related limitations in activities of daily living were worse with surgery than with observation through 2 years, but then were similar in both study arms.</li>

3443</ul>

3444</div>

3445</li>

3446<li>

3447In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02044172">

3448ProtecT</a>

3449 trial (NCT02044172 and ISRCTN20141297), 82,429 men were screened with PSA testing, and 2,664 were diagnosed with clinically localized prostate cancer. Among those diagnosed, 1,643 men (median age 62 years, range 50&#8211;69 years) consented to a randomly assigned comparison of active monitoring, radical prostatectomy (nerve-sparing when possible), or external-beam 3-dimensional (3D) conformal radiation therapy (74 Gy in 37 fractions). The primary end point was prostate cancer&#8211;specific mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

345019</a>

3451] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3452<ol id="_2952" class="lower-alpha">

3453<li>

3454With a median follow-up of 10 years, there were 17 deaths from prostate cancer, with no statistically significant differences among the three study arms (<em>

3455P</em>

3456 = .48). The 10-year prostate cancer&#8211;specific survival rates were 98.8% in the active monitoring arm, 99.0% in the radical prostatectomy arm, and 99.6% in the radiation therapy arm.[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

345719</a>

3458][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3459Level of evidence A1</a>

3460]</li>

3461<li>

3462Likewise, all-cause mortality was nearly identical in all three study arms: 10.9 deaths in the active monitoring arm, 10.1 in the radical prostatectomy arm, and 10.3 in the radiation therapy arm per 1,000 person-years (<em>

3463P</em>

3464 = .87).[<a href="#cit/section_3.19">

346519</a>

3466][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3467Level of evidence A1</a>

3468]</li>

3469<li>

3470There were statistically significant differences in progression to metastatic disease among the treatment arms (33 of 545 men in the active monitoring arm; 13 of 553 men in the radical prostatectomy arm; 16 of 545 men in the radiation therapy arm) that began to emerge after 4 years, but these differences had not translated into any difference in mortality after 10 years of follow-up. Over the course of 10 years, 52% of the patients required active intervention.</li>

3471<li>

3472As expected, there were substantial differences in patient-reported outcomes among the three management approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_3.38">

347338</a>

3474][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3475Level of evidence A3</a>

3476] A substudy of patient-reported outcomes up to 6 years after randomization included the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

3477<ul id="_2953">

3478<li>

3479Men in the radical prostatectomy study arm had substantial rates of urinary incontinence (e.g., using one or more absorbent pads qd was reported by 46% at 6 months and by 17% at year 6) with very little incontinence in the other two study arms.</li>

3480<li>

3481Sexual function was also worse in the radical prostatectomy group (e.g., at 6 months, 12% of men reported erections firm enough for intercourse versus 22% in the radiation therapy arm and 52% in the active monitoring arm). </li>

3482<li>

3483Bowel function, however, was worse in the radiation therapy arm (e.g., about 5% reported bloody stools at least half the time at 2 years and beyond vs. none in the radical prostatectomy and active-monitoring study arms).</li>

3484</ul>

3485</div>

3486</li>

3487</ol>

3488</div>

3489</li>

3490</ol>

3491</div>

3492</section>

3493<section id="_2164">

3494<h4 id="_2164_toc">

3495Complications of radical prostatectomy</h4>

3496<p id="_2165" tabindex="-1">

3497Complications of radical prostatectomy include the following:</p>

3498<div class="pdq-content-list">

3499<ul id="_2166">

3500<li>

3501 <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2297">

3502Morbidity and mortality</a>

3503 associated with general anesthesia and a major surgical procedure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

350439</a>

3505-<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

350641</a>

3507]</li>

3508<li>

3509<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2178">

3510 Urinary incontinence and impotence</a>

3511.[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

351242</a>

3513-<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

351449</a>

3515]</li>

3516<li>

3517<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2188">

3518 Penile shortening</a>

3519.[<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

352050</a>

3521-<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

352252</a>

3523]</li>

3524<li>

3525<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2190">

3526 Inguinal hernia</a>

3527.[<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

352853</a>

3529-<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

353057</a>

3531]</li>

3532<li>

3533 <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2195">

3534Fecal incontinence</a>

3535.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

353658</a>

3537]</li>

3538</ul>

3539</div>

3540<p id="_3074" tabindex="-1">

3541Functional outcomes of radical prostatectomy with respect to sexual, urinary, bowel function, and health-related quality of life (QOL), appear to be similar whether the procedure is open retropubic, laparoscopic, or robot-assisted radical prostatectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.59">

354259</a>

3543]</p>

3544<section id="_2297">

3545<h5 id="_2297_toc">

3546Morbidity and mortality associated with radical prostatectomy</h5>

3547<p id="_2298" tabindex="-1">

3548An analysis of Medicare records on 101,604 radical prostatectomies performed from 1991 to 1994 showed the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

354939</a>

3550]</p>

3551<div class="pdq-content-list">

3552<ul id="_2299">

3553<li>

3554A 30-day operative mortality rate of 0.5%.</li>

3555<li>

3556A rehospitalization rate of 4.5%.</li>

3557<li>

3558A major complication rate of 28.6%.</li>

3559</ul>

3560</div>

3561<p id="_2300" tabindex="-1">

3562Over the study period, these rates decreased by 30%, 8%, and 12%, respectively.[<a href="#cit/section_3.39">

356339</a>

3564]</p>

3565<p id="_2301" tabindex="-1">

3566Prostatectomies done at hospitals where fewer of the procedures were performed than those done at hospitals where more were performed were associated with the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.40">

356740</a>

3568,<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

356941</a>

3570]</p>

3571<div class="pdq-content-list">

3572<ul id="_2302">

3573<li>

3574Higher rates of 30-day postoperative mortality.</li>

3575<li>

3576 Major acute surgical complications.</li>

3577<li>

3578 Longer hospital stays.</li>

3579<li>

3580Higher rates of rehospitalization.</li>

3581</ul>

3582</div>

3583<p id="_2303" tabindex="-1">

3584Operative morbidity and mortality rates increase with age. Comorbidity, especially underlying cardiovascular disease and a history of stroke, accounts for a portion of the age-related increase in 30-day mortality. </p>

3585<p id="_2535" tabindex="-1">

3586In a cohort of all men with prostate cancer who underwent radical prostatectomy from 1990 to 1999 in Ontario, 75-year-old men with no comorbidities had a predicted 30-day mortality of 0.74%. Thirty-day surgical complication rates also depended more on comorbidity than age (i.e., about 5% vs. 40% for men with 0 vs. &#8805;4 underlying comorbid conditions, respectively).[<a href="#cit/section_3.41">

358741</a>

3588]</p>

3589</section>

3590<section id="_2178">

3591<h5 id="_2178_toc">

3592Urinary incontinence and impotence</h5>

3593<p id="_2179" tabindex="-1">

3594Urinary incontinence and impotence are complications that can result from radical prostatectomy and have been studied in multiple studies.</p>

3595<p id="_2181" tabindex="-1">

3596Evidence (urinary incontinence and impotence after radical prostatectomy):</p>

3597<div class="pdq-content-list">

3598<ol id="_2182">

3599<li>

3600A large case series of men undergoing the anatomic (nerve-sparing) technique of radical prostatectomy reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.43">

360143</a>

3602]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3603<ul id="_2537">

3604<li>

3605 Approximately 6% of the men required the use of pads for urinary incontinence, but an unknown additional proportion of men had occasional urinary dribbling.</li>

3606<li>

3607 About 40% to 65% of the men who were sexually potent before surgery retained potency adequate for vaginal penetration and sexual intercourse. Preservation of potency with this technique is dependent on tumor stage and patient age, but the operation probably induces at least a partial deficit in nearly all patients.</li>

3608</ul>

3609</div>

3610</li>

3611<li>

3612A national survey of Medicare patients who underwent radical prostatectomy in 1988 to 1990 reported more morbidity than in the case series reported above.[<a href="#cit/section_3.44">

361344</a>

3614]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3615<ul id="_2183">

3616<li>

3617More than 30% of the men reported the need for pads or clamps for urinary wetness, and 63% of all patients reported a current problem with wetness.</li>

3618<li>

3619About 60% of the men reported having no erections since surgery; about 90% of the men had no erections sufficient for intercourse during the month before the survey. </li>

3620<li>

3621About 28% of the patients reported follow-up treatment of cancer with radiation therapy and/or hormonal therapy within 4 years after their prostatectomy.</li>

3622</ul>

3623</div>

3624</li>

3625<li>

3626 A population-based longitudinal cohort (<a href="https://seer.cancer.gov/archive/studies/endresults/study24.html" title="https://seer.cancer.gov/archive/studies/endresults/study24.html">

3627Prostate Cancer Outcomes Study</a>

3628) of 901 men aged 55 to 74 years who had recently undergone radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer reported the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.45">

362945</a>

3630]<div class="pdq-content-list">

3631<ul id="_2184">

3632<li>

363315.4% of the men had either frequent urinary incontinence or no urinary control at 5 years after surgery.</li>

3634<li>

363520.4% of those studied wore pads to stay dry.</li>

3636<li>

3637 79.3% of men reported an inability to have an erection sufficient for intercourse.</li>

3638</ul>

3639</div>

3640</li>

3641<li>

3642 A cross-sectional survey of patients with prostate cancer who were treated with radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or watchful waiting and active surveillance in a managed care setting showed substantial sexual and urinary dysfunction in the prostatectomy group.[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

364346</a>

3644] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3645<ul id="_2582">

3646<li>

3647 Results reported by the patients were consistent with those from the national Medicare survey.</li>

3648<li>

3649In addition, although statistical power was limited, differences in sexual and urinary dysfunction between men who had undergone either nerve-sparing or standard radical prostatectomy were not statistically significant. This issue requires more study.</li>

3650</ul>

3651</div>

3652</li>

3653<li>

3654 Case series of 93, 459, and 89 men who had undergone radical prostatectomy by experienced surgeons showed rates of impotence as high as those in the national Medicare survey when men were carefully questioned about sexual potency, although the men in these case series were on average younger than those in the Medicare survey.[<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

365547</a>

3656-<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

365749</a>

3658] One of the case series used the same questionnaire as that used in the Medicare survey.[<a href="#cit/section_3.47">

365947</a>

3660] The urinary incontinence rate in that series was also similar to that in the Medicare survey.</li>

3661</ol>

3662</div>

3663<p id="_2538" tabindex="-1">

3664Differences are often reported between population-based surveys and case series from individual centers. Reasons could include the following:</p>

3665<div class="pdq-content-list">

3666<ul id="_2515">

3667<li>

3668Age differences among the populations.</li>

3669<li>

3670Surgical expertise at the major reporting centers.</li>

3671<li>

3672Patient selection factors.</li>

3673<li>

3674Publication bias of favorable series.</li>

3675<li>

3676 Different methods of collecting information from patients.</li>

3677</ul>

3678</div>

3679</section>

3680<section id="_2188">

3681<h5 id="_2188_toc">

3682Penile shortening</h5>

3683<p id="_2189" tabindex="-1">

3684Case series of men who have undergone radical prostatectomy have shown shortening of penile length (by an average of 1&#8211;2 cm).[<a href="#cit/section_3.50">

368550</a>

3686-<a href="#cit/section_3.52">

368752</a>

3688] The functional consequence of the shortening is not well studied, but it is noticeable to some men. </p>

3689<p id="_2703" tabindex="-1">

3690In a registry of men with rising PSA after initial treatment of clinically localized prostate cancer, 19 of 510 men (3.7%) who had undergone radical prostatectomy complained of reduced penile size.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

369160</a>

3692] However, the data were based upon physician reporting of patients' complaints rather than direct patient questioning or before-and-after measurement of penile length. Also, the study sample was restricted to patients with known or suspected tumor recurrence, making generalization difficult.</p>

3693<p id="_2992" tabindex="-1">

3694Recovery of penile length to preoperative measurements within 1 to 2 years has been reported in some, but not all, case series in which men were followed longitudinally.[<a href="#cit/section_3.61">

369561</a>

3696]</p>

3697</section>

3698<section id="_2190">

3699<h5 id="_2190_toc">

3700Inguinal hernia</h5>

3701<p id="_2191" tabindex="-1">

3702Inguinal hernia has been reported as a complication of radical prostatectomy.</p>

3703<p id="_2192" tabindex="-1">

3704Evidence (inguinal hernia after radical prostatectomy):</p>

3705<div class="pdq-content-list">

3706<ol id="_2193">

3707<li>

3708Retrospective cohort studies and case series have shown an increased incidence of inguinal hernia, ranging from 7% to 21%, in men undergoing radical prostatectomy, with rates peaking within 2 years of surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

370953</a>

3710-<a href="#cit/section_3.57">

371157</a>

3712]</li>

3713<li>

3714Observational studies suggest that the rates are higher than in comparable men who have undergone prostate biopsy alone, transurethral resections, and simple open prostatectomy for benign disease;[<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

371553</a>

3716,<a href="#cit/section_3.54">

371754</a>

3718] or in men with prostate cancer who have undergone pelvic lymph node dissection alone or radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.53">

371953</a>

3720,<a href="#cit/section_3.55">

372155</a>

3722,<a href="#cit/section_3.56">

372356</a>

3724]</li>

3725</ol>

3726</div>

3727<p id="_2194" tabindex="-1">

3728Although the observations of increased rates of inguinal hernia after radical prostatectomy are consistent, it is conceivable that men with prostate cancer who are being followed carefully by urologists could have higher detection rates of hernia because of frequent examinations or diagnostic imaging (i.e., detection bias). Men should be made aware of this potential complication of prostatectomy.</p>

3729</section>

3730<section id="_2195">

3731<h5 id="_2195_toc">

3732Fecal incontinence</h5>

3733<p id="_2196" tabindex="-1">

3734Radical prostatectomy may cause fecal incontinence, and the incidence may vary with surgical method.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

373558</a>

3736] </p>

3737<p id="_2197" tabindex="-1">

3738Evidence (fecal incontinence after radical prostatectomy): </p>

3739<div class="pdq-content-list">

3740<ol id="_2198">

3741<li>

3742 In a national survey sample of 907 men who had undergone radical prostatectomy at least 1 year before the survey, 32% of the men who had undergone perineal (nerve-sparing) radical prostatectomy and 17% of the men who had undergone a retropubic radical prostatectomy reported accidents of fecal leakage. Ten percent of the respondents reported moderate amounts of fecal leakage, and 4% of the respondents reported large amounts of fecal leakage. Fewer than 15% of men with fecal incontinence had reported it to a physician or health care provider.[<a href="#cit/section_3.58">

374358</a>

3744]</li>

3745</ol>

3746</div>

3747</section>

3748</section>

3749</section>

3750<section id="_2199">

3751<h3 id="_2199_toc">

3752Radiation Therapy and Radiopharmaceutical Therapy</h3>

3753<section id="_2200">

3754<h4 id="_2200_toc">

3755External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) </h4>

3756<p id="_2201" tabindex="-1">

3757Candidates for definitive radiation therapy must have a confirmed pathological diagnosis of cancer that is clinically confined to the prostate and/or surrounding tissues (stage I, stage II, and stage III). Staging laparotomy and lymph node dissection are not required.</p>

3758<p id="_2202" tabindex="-1">

3759Radiation therapy may be a good option for patients who are considered poor medical candidates for radical prostatectomy. These patients can be treated with an acceptably low complication rate if care is given to the delivery technique.[<a href="#cit/section_3.62">

376062</a>

3761] </p>

3762<p id="_2203" tabindex="-1">

3763Long-term results with radiation therapy are dependent on stage and are associated with dosimetry of the radiation. </p>

3764<p id="_2204" tabindex="-1">

3765Evidence (EBRT):</p>

3766<div class="pdq-content-list">

3767<ol id="_2205">

3768<li>

3769A retrospective review of 999 patients treated with megavoltage radiation therapy showed that cause-specific survival rates at 10 years varied substantially by T stage: T1 (79%), T2 (66%), T3 (55%), and T4 (22%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.63">

377063</a>

3771] An initial serum PSA level higher than 15 ng/mL is a predictor of probable failure with conventional radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.64">

377264</a>

3773]</li>

3774<li>

3775Several randomized studies have demonstrated an improvement in freedom from biochemical (PSA-based) recurrence with higher doses of radiation therapy (74&#8211;79 Gy) as compared with lower doses (64&#8211;70 Gy).[<a href="#cit/section_3.65">

377665</a>

3777-<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

377869</a>

3779][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3780Level of evidence B1</a>

3781] None of the studies demonstrated a cause-specific survival benefit to higher doses. <div class="pdq-content-list">

3782<ul id="_2206">

3783<li>

3784The <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003290">

3785MRC-RT01</a>

3786 study (NCT00003290) enrolled 843 men with stage T1b through T3a, N0, M0 prostate cancer. Patients were randomly assigned to receive 64 Gy in 32 fractions versus 74 Gy in 37 fractions by conformal delivery.[<a href="#cit/section_3.68">

378768</a>

3788] Men in both study groups received neoadjuvant LH-RH agonist injections every 4 weeks for 3 to 6 months before the start of radiation therapy and throughout the radiation course. The study was powered to detect differences in both biochemical progression-free survival (PFS) and a 15% difference in overall survival (OS).</li>

3789<li>

3790After a median follow-up of 10 years, despite a statistically significant improvement in biochemical PFS with the higher dose of radiation, the 10-year OS rate was the same in both groups: 71% (HR, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.77&#8211;1.28; <em>

3791P</em>

3792 = .96). Likewise, there were no differences in prostate&#8212;cancer-specific survival.</li>

3793<li>

3794Likewise, in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00033631">

3795RTOG-0126</a>

3796 trial (NCT00033631), 1,532 men with stage cT1b to T2b (Gleason score 2 to 6 and PSA 10 to &lt;20 ng/mL or Gleason score 7 and PSA &lt;15 ng/mL) prostate cancer were randomly assigned to receive 79.2 Gy in 44 fractions compared with 70.2 Gy in 39 fractions (using 3D conformal or intensity-modulated radiation therapy [IMRT]).[<a href="#cit/section_3.69">

379769</a>

3798] With a median follow-up of 8.4 years (maximum, 13.0 years), 8-year OS rates were 76% and 75% (HR, 1.00; 95% CI, 0.83&#8211;1.20; <em>

3799P</em>

3800 = .98). However, the high-dose radiation was associated with increased late-grade 2 or greater gastrointestinal and genitourinary toxicities (21% and 12% with 79.2 Gy and 15% and 7% with 70.2 Gy).</li>

3801</ul>

3802</div>

3803</li>

3804</ol>

3805</div>

3806<p id="_2954" tabindex="-1">

3807For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2155">

3808Radical prostatectomy compared with other treatment options</a>

3809 section.</p>

3810<p id="_2207" tabindex="-1">

3811Prophylactic radiation therapy to clinically or pathologically uninvolved pelvic lymph nodes does not appear to improve OS or prostate cancer-specific survival as was seen in the RTOG-7706 trial, for example.[<a href="#cit/section_3.70">

381270</a>

3813][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3814Level of evidence A1</a>

3815] </p>

3816<section id="_2897">

3817<h5 id="_2897_toc">

3818 Conventional versus hypofractionated EBRT</h5>

3819<p id="_2898" tabindex="-1">

3820The more convenient schedules of hypofractionated radiation therapy (using fewer fractions at higher doses per fraction) appear to yield similar outcomes to conventional schedules of radiation, at least with respect to the intermediate outcomes of DFS and failure-free survival (low levels of evidence not known to translate into health outcomes), and early data on OS rates. However, hypofractionated radiation may incur more toxicity than standard doses, depending on the schedules used.[<a href="#cit/section_3.71">

382171</a>

3822]</p>

3823<p id="_2899" tabindex="-1">

3824Evidence (conventional vs. hypofractionated EBRT):</p>

3825<div class="pdq-content-list">

3826<ol id="_2900">

3827<li>

3828In a small randomized trial, primarily from one treatment center, conventional hypofractionation was not found to be superior to conventional fractionation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

382972</a>

3830] In the trial, 303 assessable men were randomly assigned to receive IMRT for a total of 76 Gy in 38 fractions at 2.0 Gy per fraction (conventional IMRT [CIMRT]) versus IMRT for a total of 70.2 Gy in 26 fractions at 2.7 per fraction (hypofractionated IMRT [HIMRT]). <div class="pdq-content-list">

3831<ul id="_2901">

3832<li>

3833The primary end point was biochemical or clinical disease failure (BCDF). The 5-year BCDF rates in the two arms were 21.4% for the CIMRT arm (95% CI, 14.8%&#8211;28.7%) and 23.3% for the HIMRT arm (95% CI, 16.4%&#8211;31.0%; <em>

3834P</em>

3835 = .75).</li>

3836<li>

3837 Likewise, there were no statistically significant differences in the secondary end points of overall mortality, prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality, prostate local failure, or distant failure, despite low mortality rates, and the trial was underpowered for mortality end points.[<a href="#cit/section_3.72">

383872</a>

3839][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3840Level of evidence B1</a>

3841]</li>

3842</ul>

3843</div>

3844</li>

3845<li>

3846The much larger, multicenter <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00392535">

3847CHHiP</a>

3848 trial (NCT00392535) evaluated conventional or hypofractionated high-dose intensity-modulated radiotherapy in 3,216 men with prostate cancer. The men had stages T1b&#8211;T3a, N0, M0 cancer and an estimated risk of seminal vesicle involvement of less than 30% and were randomly assigned to receive either 74 Gy in 37 fractions (the conventional-fraction arm), 60 Gy in 20 fractions, or 57 Gy in 19 fractions (1:1:1 ratio).[<a href="#cit/section_3.73">

384973</a>

3850,<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

385174</a>

3852] The trial was designed as a noninferiority study.<div class="pdq-content-list">

3853<ul id="_2902">

3854<li>

3855 The primary end point of biochemical or clinical treatment failure was reported after a median follow-up of 62.4 months. The 5-year failure-free survival rates were 88.3% (conventional, 74 Gy group), 90.6% (60 Gy group), and 85.9% (57 Gy group). The 60 Gy hypofractionated group fulfilled noninferiority criteria compared with conventional 74 Gy fractionation, but the 57 Gy group did not.[<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

385674</a>

3857][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3858Level of evidence B1</a>

3859] </li>

3860<li>

3861 Overall mortality rates were very similar in the three groups: 9%, 7%, and 8%.[<a href="#cit/section_3.74">

386274</a>

3863][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3864Level of evidence A1</a>

3865]</li>

3866<li>

3867A QOL substudy was conducted with 2,100 participants and showed nearly identical patient-reported outcomes in each of the three arms at 2 years after study entry (median follow-up, 50 months).[<a href="#cit/section_3.73">

386873</a>

3869][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3870Level of evidence A3</a>

3871]</li>

3872<li>

3873The primary patient-reported outcome was bowel bother. Frequency of moderate bother was 5%, 6%, and 5% in the three study groups. Severe bother was reported in less than 1% of men in each study group.</li>

3874<li>

3875 Likewise, there were no differences in any of the secondary outcomes, which included overall QOL, overall urinary bother, or overall sexual bother.</li>

3876</ul>

3877</div>

3878</li>

3879<li>

3880The multicenter, randomized, phase III HYPRO trial (ISRCTN85138529) enrolled 820 men with intermediate- or high-risk prostate cancer (stages T1b&#8211;T4, NX&#8211;0, MX&#8211;0). The men were randomly assigned to receive either conventional radiation therapy (78 Gy in 39 fractions over 8 weeks) or hypofractionated radiation therapy (64.6 Gy in 19 fractions over 6.5 weeks) in a noninferiority design for hypofractionation.[<a href="#cit/section_3.75">

388175</a>

3882,<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

388376</a>

3884] Median follow-up was 60 months. <div class="pdq-content-list">

3885<ul id="_2915">

3886<li>

3887 The primary end point, 5-year relapse-free survival, was similar in the two study arms: 80.5% (95% CI, 75.7%&#8211;84.4%) with hypofractionation versus 77.1% (95% CI, 71.9%&#8211;81.5%), with conventional fractionation (HR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.63&#8211;1.16; <em>

3888P</em>

3889 = .36).[<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

389076</a>

3891][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3892Level of evidence B1</a>

3893] The overall 5-year survival rate in the two arms was also similar: 86.2% (95% CI, 82.3%&#8211;89.4%) with hypofractionation versus 85.9% (95% CI, 81.8%&#8211;89.2%) with conventional fractionation (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.71&#8211;1.46; <em>

3894P</em>

3895 = .92).[<a href="#cit/section_3.76">

389676</a>

3897][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3898Level of evidence A1</a>

3899]</li>

3900<li>

3901With respect to toxicity (key end points of genitourinary [GU] or gastrointestinal [GI] grade 2+ toxicities at 3 years), noninferiority for hypofractionated radiation therapy could not be established after a median follow-up of 5 years: cumulative GU toxicity of 41.3% with hypofractionated radiation therapy versus 39% with conventional radiation therapy doses (HR, 1.16; 90% CI, 0.98&#8211;1.38); GI toxicity of 21.9% versus 17.7% (HR, 1.19; 90% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.52).</li>

3902<li>

3903Cumulative GU grade 3+ toxicity was higher in the hypofractionation group: 19.0% versus 12.9% (<em>

3904P</em>

3905 = .02).</li>

3906<li>

3907 Stool frequency (&#8805;6 qd) was higher in the hypofractionation group: 7% versus 3% (<em>

3908P</em>

3909 = .034).</li>

3910<li>

3911In a substudy of 322 men who had a baseline assessment and at least one follow-up assessment, and either no or short-term androgen therapy, erectile dysfunction was similar between the two study arms during 3 years of follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_3.77">

391277</a>

3913]

3914</li>

3915</ul>

3916</div>

3917</li>

3918<li>

3919The RTOG reported a noninferiority trial of 1,115 men with low-risk prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;T2c) who were randomly assigned to receive hypofractionated radiation therapy (70 Gy in 28 fractions over 5.6 weeks) versus conventional radiation therapy doses (73.8 Gy in 41 fractions over 8.2 weeks).[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

392078</a>

3921] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3922<ul id="_2916">

3923<li>

3924 After a median follow-up of 5.8 years, the hypofractionated radiation therapy arm met the prospective noninferiority criterion with respect to DFS: 86.3% with hypofractionated radiation therapy versus 85.3% with conventional radiation therapy doses (consistent with HR, &lt;1.52; <em>

3925P</em>

3926 &lt; .001 for the hypothesis of noninferiority).[<a href="#cit/section_3.78">

392778</a>

3928][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3929Level of evidence B1</a>

3930]</li>

3931<li>

3932 There were 49 deaths in the hypofractionated radiation therapy arm and 51 deaths in the conventional radiation therapy doses arm (HR for OS, 0.95; conventional radiation therapy doses vs. hypofractionated radiation therapy; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;1.41).</li>

3933<li>

3934 However, late GI grade 2+ toxicity was worse in the hypofractionated radiation therapy arm: 22.4% versus 14.0% (<em>

3935P</em>

3936 = .002); there was also a trend toward worse late GU grade 2+ toxicity: 29.7% versus 22.8% (<em>

3937P</em>

3938 = .06).</li>

3939</ul>

3940</div>

3941</li>

3942<li>

3943In a multicenter trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00304759">

3944NCT00304759</a>

3945), 1,206 men with intermediate-risk prostate cancer (T1&#8211;2a Gleason score &#8804;6, PSA 10.1&#8211;20 ng/mL; T2b&#8211;2c Gleason &#8804;6, PSA &#8804;20 ng/mL; or T1&#8211;2 Gleason = 7, PSA &#8804;20 ng/mL) were randomly assigned in a noninferiority trial design to receive conventional radiation therapy (78 Gy in 39 fractions) versus hypofractionated radiation therapy (60 Gy over 20 fractions).[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

394679</a>

3947] <div class="pdq-content-list">

3948<ul id="_2993">

3949<li>

3950 After a median follow-up of 6 years (maximum 10 years), the primary end point of biochemical clinical failure (87%, PSA failure) was nearly identical with each radiation therapy schedule (85% in both arms; [DFS, 95% CI, 82%&#8211;88%]; HR, 0.96; 90% CI, 0.77&#8211;1.20).[<a href="#cit/section_3.79">

395179</a>

3952][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3953Level of evidence B1</a>

3954]</li>

3955<li>

3956 The trial was severely underpowered to detect any differences in overall or prostate-specific mortality. Only 12 deaths in the conventional radiation therapy arm and 10 deaths in the hypofractionated radiation therapy arm were from prostate cancer. Only 14% of all deaths were attributed to prostate cancer.</li>

3957<li>

3958Short- and long-term genitourinary and gastrointestinal toxicities were similar in both study groups.</li>

3959</ul>

3960</div>

3961</li>

3962</ol>

3963</div>

3964</section>

3965</section>

3966<section id="_2208">

3967<h4 id="_2208_toc">

3968Brachytherapy </h4>

3969<p id="_2209" tabindex="-1">

3970Patients undergoing brachytherapy are often selected for favorable characteristics that include the following:</p>

3971<div class="pdq-content-list">

3972<ul id="_2210">

3973<li>

3974 Low Gleason score.</li>

3975<li>

3976 Low PSA level.</li>

3977<li>

3978Stage T1 to T2 tumors.</li>

3979</ul>

3980</div>

3981<p id="_2211" tabindex="-1">

3982More information and further study are required to better define the effects of modern interstitial brachytherapy on disease control and QOL and to determine the contribution of favorable patient selection to outcomes.[<a href="#cit/section_3.80">

398380</a>

3984][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

3985Level of evidence C3</a>

3986]</p>

3987<p id="_2212" tabindex="-1">

3988Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

3989NCI website</a>

3990.</p>

3991</section>

3992<section id="_2790">

3993<h4 id="_2790_toc">

3994Radiopharmaceutical therapy</h4>

3995<section id="_2716">

3996<h5 id="_2716_toc">

3997Alpha emitter radiation</h5>

3998<p id="_2717" tabindex="-1">

3999Radium Ra 223 (223Ra) emits alpha particles (i.e., two protons and two neutrons bound together, identical to a helium nucleus) with a half-life of 11.4 days. It is administered intravenously and selectively taken up by newly formed bone stroma. The high-energy alpha particles have a short range of less than 100 mcM. 223Ra improved OS in patients with prostate cancer metastatic to bone. In a double-blind, randomized, controlled trial, 921 men with symptomatic castration-resistant prostate cancer, two or more metastases, and no known visceral metastases were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to 223Ra versus placebo. 223Ra statistically significantly improved OS (median 14.9 months vs. 11.3 months), rate of symptomatic skeletal events (33% vs. 38%), and spinal cord compression (4% vs. 7%).[<a href="#cit/section_3.81">

400081</a>

4001,<a href="#cit/section_3.82">

400282</a>

4003][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4004Level of evidence A1</a>

4005] With administration at a dose of 50kBq per kg body weight every 4 weeks for six injections, the side effects were similar to those of a placebo.</p>

4006</section>

4007</section>

4008<section id="_2213">

4009<h4 id="_2213_toc">

4010Complications of radiation therapy </h4>

4011<p id="_2214" tabindex="-1">

4012Definitive EBRT can result in acute cystitis,

4013proctitis, and enteritis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.20">

401420</a>

4015,<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

401642</a>

4017,<a href="#cit/section_3.49">

401849</a>

4019,<a href="#cit/section_3.83">

402083</a>

4021-<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

402285</a>

4023] These conditions are generally reversible

4024but may be chronic and rarely require surgical intervention.[<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

402585</a>

4026] </p>

4027<p id="_2215" tabindex="-1">

4028A cross-sectional survey of patients with prostate cancer

4029who had been treated in a managed care setting by radical prostatectomy,

4030radiation therapy, or watchful waiting and active surveillance showed substantial sexual and urinary

4031dysfunction in the radiation therapy group.[<a href="#cit/section_3.46">

403246</a>

4033]

4034</p>

4035<p id="_2216" tabindex="-1">

4036Radiation is also carcinogenic.[<a href="#cit/section_3.86">

403786</a>

4038-<a href="#cit/section_3.88">

403988</a>

4040] EBRT for prostate cancer is associated with an increased risk of bladder and gastrointestinal cancer. Brachytherapy is associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.</p>

4041</section>

4042<section id="_2217">

4043<h4 id="_2217_toc">

4044Reducing complications</h4>

4045<p id="_2218" tabindex="-1">

4046Potency, in most cases, is preserved with radiation therapy in the short term but appears to

4047diminish over time.[<a href="#cit/section_3.85">

404885</a>

4049] Sildenafil citrate may be effective in the management of sexual dysfunction after radiation therapy in some men.</p>

4050<p id="_2219" tabindex="-1">

4051Evidence (reducing complications):</p>

4052<div class="pdq-content-list">

4053<ol id="_2499">

4054<li>

4055In a completed, randomized, placebo-controlled, crossover design study (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00057759">

4056RTOG-0215</a>

4057 [NCT00057759]) of 60 men who had undergone radiation therapy for clinically localized prostate cancer, and who reported erectile dysfunction that began after their radiation therapy, 55% reported successful intercourse after sildenafil versus 18% after placebo (<em>

4058P</em>

4059 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_3.89">

406089</a>

4061][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4062Level of evidence A3</a>

4063]</li>

4064<li>

4065A randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00931528">

4066RTOG-0831</a>

4067 [NCT00931528]) of 121 men with intact erectile function compared daily preventive tadalafil (5 mg PO qd) with placebo for 24 weeks beginning at the start of either EBRT or brachytherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.90">

406890</a>

4069][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4070Level of evidence A3</a>

4071] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4072<ul id="_2755">

4073<li>

4074There were no statistically significant differences in spontaneous erectile function (the primary end point) or any other measures of sexual function.</li>

4075</ul>

4076</div>

4077</li>

4078</ol>

4079</div>

4080<p id="_2500" tabindex="-1">

4081Morbidity may be reduced with the employment of sophisticated radiation therapy techniques&#8212;such as the use of linear accelerators&#8212;and careful simulation and treatment planning.[<a href="#cit/section_3.91">

408291</a>

4083,<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

408492</a>

4085]</p>

4086<p id="_2501" tabindex="-1">

4087Evidence (3D conformal vs. conventional radiation therapy):</p>

4088<div class="pdq-content-list">

4089<ol id="_2220">

4090<li>

4091The side effects of similar doses of 3D conformal radiation therapy and conventional radiation therapy (total dose, 60&#8211;64 Gy) have been compared in a

4092randomized nonblinded study.[<a href="#cit/section_3.92">

409392</a>

4094][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4095Level of evidence A3</a>

4096] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4097<ul id="_2495">

4098<li>

4099No

4100differences were observed in acute morbidity, and late side effects serious enough to require

4101hospitalization were infrequent with both techniques; however, the cumulative

4102incidence of mild or greater proctitis was lower in the conformal radiation arm than in

4103the standard therapy arm (37% vs. 56%; <em>

4104P</em>

4105 = .004). Urinary symptoms were

4106similar in the two treatment groups, as were local tumor control and OS rates

4107at 5 years of follow-up. </li>

4108</ul>

4109</div>

4110</li>

4111</ol>

4112</div>

4113<p id="_2222" tabindex="-1">

4114Radiation therapy can be delivered after an

4115extraperitoneal lymph node dissection without an increase in complications if

4116careful attention is paid to radiation technique. The treatment field should

4117not include the area that contained the dissected pelvic nodes. Previous TURP is associated with an increased risk of stricture above that seen with radiation

4118therapy alone, but, if radiation therapy is delayed 4 to 6 weeks after the TURP, the risk of

4119stricture is lower.[<a href="#cit/section_3.93">

412093</a>

4121-<a href="#cit/section_3.95">

412295</a>

4123] Pretreatment TURP to relieve

4124obstructive symptoms has been associated with tumor dissemination; however, multivariable

4125analysis in pathologically staged cases indicates that this may be due to a worse

4126underlying prognosis of the cases that require TURP rather

4127than the result of the procedure itself.[<a href="#cit/section_3.96">

412896</a>

4129]</p>

4130</section>

4131<section id="_2223">

4132<h4 id="_2223_toc">

4133Comparison of complications from radiation therapy and from radical prostatectomy</h4>

4134<p id="_2651" tabindex="-1">

4135In general, radical prostatectomy is associated with a higher rate of urinary incontinence and early sexual impotence but a lower rate of stool incontinence and rectal injury. However, over time, the differences in sexual impotence diminish because the risk rises with time since radiation. Many side effects of definitive local therapy for prostate cancer persist well beyond a decade after therapy, and urinary problems in addition to sexual impotence may worsen with age.[<a href="#cit/section_3.97">

413697</a>

4137] </p>

4138<p id="_2225" tabindex="-1">

4139Evidence (complications of radical prostatectomy vs. radiation therapy):</p>

4140<div class="pdq-content-list">

4141<ol id="_2226">

4142<li>

4143A population-based survey of Medicare recipients who had received radiation

4144therapy as primary treatment for prostate cancer (similar in design to the

4145survey of Medicare patients who underwent radical prostatectomy,[<a href="#cit/section_3.44">

414644</a>

4147] described above) has been reported, showing substantial differences in posttreatment

4148morbidity profiles between surgery and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.98">

414998</a>

4150]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4151<ul id="_2227">

4152<li>

4153Although the men who had

4154undergone radiation therapy were older at the time of initial therapy, they were less

4155likely to report the need for pads or clamps to control urinary wetness (7%

4156vs. &gt;30%).</li>

4157<li>

4158A larger proportion of patients treated with radiation

4159therapy before surgery reported the ability to have an erection sufficient for

4160intercourse in the month before the survey (men &lt;70 years, 33% who

4161received radiation therapy vs. 11% who underwent surgery alone; men &#8805;70 years, 27% who received radiation therapy vs. 12% who underwent surgery alone).</li>

4162<li>

4163Men receiving radiation therapy, however, were more likely to report problems with bowel

4164function, especially frequent bowel movements (10% vs. 3%).</li>

4165<li>

4166As in the results of the

4167surgical patient survey, about 24% of patients who received radiation reported additional

4168subsequent treatment for known or suspected cancer persistence or recurrence

4169within 3 years of primary therapy.

4170</li>

4171</ul>

4172</div>

4173</li>

4174<li>

4175A prospective, community-based cohort study of men aged 55 to 74 years treated with

4176radical prostatectomy (n = 1,156) or EBRT (n = 435)

4177attempted to compare the acute and chronic complications of the two treatment

4178strategies after adjusting for baseline differences in patient characteristics

4179and underlying health.[<a href="#cit/section_3.99">

418099</a>

4181]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4182<ul id="_2229">

4183<li>

4184Regarding acute treatment-related morbidity,

4185radical prostatectomy was associated with higher rates of cardiopulmonary

4186complications (5.5% vs. 1.9%) and the need for treatment of urinary

4187strictures (17.4% vs. 7.2%). Radiation therapy was associated with more acute

4188rectal proctitis (18.7% vs. 1.6%).</li>

4189<li>

4190With regard to chronic treatment-related

4191morbidity, radical prostatectomy was associated with more urinary incontinence

4192(9.6% vs. 3.5%) and impotence (80% vs. 62%). Radiation therapy was associated

4193with slightly greater declines in bowel function.</li>

4194</ul>

4195</div>

4196</li>

4197</ol>

4198</div>

4199</section>

4200</section>

4201<section id="_2230">

4202<h3 id="_2230_toc">

4203Hormonal Therapy and Its Complications</h3>

4204<p id="_2231" tabindex="-1">

4205Several different hormonal approaches are used in the management of various stages of prostate cancer. </p>

4206<p id="_2232" tabindex="-1">

4207These approaches include the following:</p>

4208<div class="pdq-content-list">

4209<ul id="_2233">

4210<li>

4211<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2998">

4212 Abiraterone acetate</a>

4213 (added to androgen deprivation therapy [ADT]).</li>

4214<li>

4215<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2235">

4216Bilateral orchiectomy</a>

4217.</li>

4218<li>

4219<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2242">

4220 Estrogen therapy</a>

4221.</li>

4222<li>

4223<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2245">

4224Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonist therapy</a>

4225.</li>

4226<li>

4227<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2248">

4228Antiandrogen therapy</a>

4229.</li>

4230<li>

4231<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2584">

4232ADT</a>

4233.</li>

4234<li>

4235<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2264">

4236Antiadrenal therapy</a>

4237.<div class="pdq-content-list">

4238<ul id="_2234" class="list-dash">

4239<li>

4240Ketoconazole. </li>

4241<li>

4242Aminoglutethimide.</li>

4243</ul>

4244</div>

4245</li>

4246</ul>

4247</div>

4248<section id="_2998">

4249<h4 id="_2998_toc">

4250Abiraterone acetate</h4>

4251<p id="_2999" tabindex="-1">

4252Abiraterone acetate has been shown to improve OS when added to ADT in men with advanced prostate cancer who have castration-sensitive disease. Abiraterone acetate is generally well-tolerated; however, it is associated with an increase in the mineralocorticoid effects of grade 3 or 4 hypertension and hypokalemia compared with ADT alone.[<a href="#cit/section_3.100">

4253100</a>

4254] It may also be associated with a small increase in respiratory disorders.[<a href="#cit/section_3.101">

4255101</a>

4256] </p>

4257</section>

4258<section id="_2235">

4259<h4 id="_2235_toc">

4260Bilateral orchiectomy </h4>

4261<p id="_2236" tabindex="-1">

4262Benefits of bilateral orchiectomy include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

426342</a>

4264]</p>

4265<div class="pdq-content-list">

4266<ul id="_2237">

4267<li>

4268Ease of the procedure.</li>

4269<li>

4270Compliance.</li>

4271<li>

4272Immediacy in lowering testosterone levels.</li>

4273<li>

4274Low cost relative to the other forms of ADT.</li>

4275</ul>

4276</div>

4277<p id="_2238" tabindex="-1">

4278Disadvantages of bilateral orchiectomy include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.42">

427942</a>

4280,<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

4281102</a>

4282]</p>

4283<div class="pdq-content-list">

4284<ul id="_2239">

4285<li>

4286Psychological effects.</li>

4287<li>

4288Loss of libido.</li>

4289<li>

4290Less reversible impotence.</li>

4291<li>

4292 Hot flashes.</li>

4293<li>

4294Osteoporosis.[<a href="#cit/section_3.102">

4295102</a>

4296]</li>

4297</ul>

4298</div>

4299<p id="_2240" tabindex="-1">

4300Bilateral orchiectomy has also been associated with an elevated risk of coronary heart disease and myocardial infarction.[<a href="#cit/section_3.103">

4301103</a>

4302-<a href="#cit/section_3.106">

4303106</a>

4304]</p>

4305<p id="_2241" tabindex="-1">

4306For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/hot-flashes-hp-pdq">

4307Hot Flashes and Night Sweats</a>

4308.</p>

4309</section>

4310<section id="_2242">

4311<h4 id="_2242_toc">

4312Estrogen therapy</h4>

4313<p id="_2243" tabindex="-1">

4314Estrogens at a dose of 3 mg qd of

4315diethylstilbestrol (DES) will achieve castrate levels of testosterone. Like

4316orchiectomy, estrogens may cause loss of libido and impotence. Estrogens also cause gynecomastia, and prophylactic low-dose radiation therapy to the breasts is given to prevent this complication.</p>

4317<p id="_2244" tabindex="-1">

4318DES is no longer manufactured or marketed in the United States and is seldom used today because of the risk of serious side effects, including myocardial infarction, cerebrovascular accidents, and pulmonary embolism. </p>

4319</section>

4320<section id="_2245">

4321<h4 id="_2245_toc">

4322Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonist therapy</h4>

4323<p id="_2539" tabindex="-1">

4324LH-RH agonists, such as leuprolide, goserelin, and buserelin, lower testosterone to castrate levels. Like orchiectomy and estrogens, LH-RH agonists cause impotence, hot flashes, and loss of libido. Tumor flare reactions may occur transiently but can be prevented by antiandrogens or short-term estrogens at a low dose for several weeks.</p>

4325<p id="_2246" tabindex="-1">

4326 There is some evidence that LH-RH agonists are associated with increased risk of cardiovascular morbidity or mortality, although the results are conflicting.[<a href="#cit/section_3.103">

4327103</a>

4328-<a href="#cit/section_3.107">

4329107</a>

4330]</p>

4331<p id="_2540" tabindex="-1">

4332Evidence (LH-RH agonists and cardiovascular disease):</p>

4333<div class="pdq-content-list">

4334<ol id="_2541">

4335<li>

4336In a population-based study within the Department of Veterans Affairs' system, LH-RH agonists were associated with an increased risk of diabetes as well as cardiovascular disease, including coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, sudden death, and stroke.[<a href="#cit/section_3.103">

4337103</a>

4338-<a href="#cit/section_3.105">

4339105</a>

4340]</li>

4341<li>

4342A systematic evidence review and meta-analysis of eight trials (4,141 patients) of men with nonmetastatic prostate cancer who were randomly assigned to receive or not to receive LH-RH agonists found no difference in cardiovascular death rates (11.0% vs. 11.2%; RR<sub>

4343death,</sub>

4344 0.93; 95% CI, 0.79&#8211;1.10; <em>

4345P</em>

4346 = .41).[<a href="#cit/section_3.108">

4347108</a>

4348] Median follow-up in those studies was 7.6 to 13.2 years. No excess risk of LH-RH agonists was found regardless of treatment duration or patient age (median age of &lt;70 years or &#8805;70 years).</li>

4349</ol>

4350</div>

4351</section>

4352<section id="_2248">

4353<h4 id="_2248_toc">

4354Antiandrogen therapy </h4>

4355<p id="_2249" tabindex="-1">

4356Antiandrogen agents used in the treatment of prostate cancer include flutamide and bicalutamide. A systematic evidence review compared nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy with surgical or medical castration from 11 randomized trials in 3,060 men with locally advanced, metastatic, or recurrent disease after local therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

4357109</a>

4358] Use of nonsteroidal antiandrogens as monotherapy decreased OS and increased the rate of clinical progression and treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_3.109">

4359109</a>

4360][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4361Level of evidence A1</a>

4362]</p>

4363<p id="_2963" tabindex="-1">

4364The pure antiandrogen, flutamide, may cause diarrhea, breast tenderness, and nausea. Case reports show fatal and nonfatal liver toxic effects.[<a href="#cit/section_3.110">

4365110</a>

4366] For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/constipation/GI-complications-hp-pdq">

4367Gastrointestinal Complications</a>

4368.</p>

4369<p id="_2250" tabindex="-1">

4370Bicalutamide may cause nausea, breast tenderness, hot flashes, loss of libido, and impotence.[<a href="#cit/section_3.111">

4371111</a>

4372] For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/nausea/nausea-hp-pdq">

4373Nausea and Vomiting Related to Cancer Treatment</a>

4374 and <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/hot-flashes-hp-pdq">

4375Hot Flashes and Night Sweats</a>

4376.</p>

4377<p id="_2251" tabindex="-1">

4378The steroidal antiandrogen, megestrol acetate, suppresses androgen production incompletely and is generally not used as initial therapy.</p>

4379<p id="_2583" tabindex="-1">

4380Additional studies that evaluate the effects of various hormone therapies on QOL are required.[<a href="#cit/section_3.112">

4381112</a>

4382]</p>

4383<section id="_2584">

4384<h5 id="_2584_toc">

4385ADT</h5>

4386<p id="_2252" tabindex="-1">

4387A national Medicare survey of men who had undergone radical prostatectomy for prostate cancer and either had or had not undergone androgen depletion (either medically or surgically induced) showed a decrease with androgen depletion in all seven health-related QOL measures, including the following:[<a href="#cit/section_3.113">

4388113</a>

4389][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4390Level of evidence C1</a>

4391] </p>

4392<div class="pdq-content-list">

4393<ul id="_2253">

4394<li>

4395Impact of cancer and treatment.</li>

4396<li>

4397Concern regarding body image.</li>

4398<li>

4399Mental health.</li>

4400<li>

4401 General health.</li>

4402<li>

4403 Activity.</li>

4404<li>

4405 Worries about cancer and dying.</li>

4406<li>

4407 Energy.</li>

4408</ul>

4409</div>

4410<p id="_2256" tabindex="-1">

4411ADT can cause osteoporosis and bone fractures. In a population-based sample of 50,613 Medicare patients aged 66 years or older followed for a median of 5.1 years, men who had been treated with either a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) or orchiectomy had a 19.4% bone fracture rate compared with 12.6% in men who had not received hormone deprivation therapy. The effect was similar in men whether or not they had metastatic bone disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.114">

4412114</a>

4413]</p>

4414<p id="_2704" tabindex="-1">

4415The use of ADT may be associated with complaints of penile shortening, although the data are very limited.[<a href="#cit/section_3.60">

441660</a>

4417] In a registry study of men with rising PSA after initial treatment of clinically localized prostate cancer treated with radiation therapy plus ADT, 6 of 225 men (2.7%) complained of reduced penile size. Of the 213 men treated with radiation therapy but no ADT, none complained of changes in penile size. However, the data were based upon physician reporting of patients' complaints rather than direct patient questioning or before-and-after measurement of penile length. Also, the study sample was restricted to patients with known or suspected tumor recurrence, making generalization difficult.</p>

4418<p id="_2669" tabindex="-1">

4419Placebo-controlled, randomized trials have shown that treatment of bone loss with bisphosphonates decreases the risk of bone fracture in men receiving ADT for prostate cancer (RR, 0.80 in a meta-analysis of 15 trials; 95% CI, 0.69&#8211;0.94). In the meta-analysis, zoledronate appeared to have the largest effect.[<a href="#cit/section_3.115">

4420115</a>

4421]</p>

4422<p id="_2260" tabindex="-1">

4423The use of ADT has also been associated with an increased risk of colorectal cancer.</p>

4424<p id="_2261" tabindex="-1">

4425Evidence (increased risk of colorectal cancer):</p>

4426<div class="pdq-content-list">

4427<ol id="_2262">

4428<li>

4429Using the Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results (SEER) Medicare database, investigators assessed the risk of subsequent colorectal cancer in 107,859 men aged 67 years and older after an initial diagnosis of prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.116">

4430116</a>

4431]<div class="pdq-content-list">

4432<ul id="_2263">

4433<li>

4434The rates of colorectal cancer per 1,000 person-years were 6.3 (95% CI, 5.3&#8211;7.5) in men who had orchiectomy, 4.4 (95% CI, 4.0&#8211;4.9) in men treated with GnRH agonists, and 3.7 (95% CI, 3.5&#8211;3.9) in men who had no androgen deprivation.</li>

4435<li>

4436In men treated with GnRH agonists, the risk increased with increasing duration of treatment (<em>

4437P</em>

4438 for trend = .01).</li>

4439</ul>

4440</div>

4441</li>

4442</ol>

4443</div>

4444</section>

4445</section>

4446<section id="_2264">

4447<h4 id="_2264_toc">

4448Antiadrenal therapy</h4>

4449<p id="_2265" tabindex="-1">

4450Antiadrenal agents used in the treatment of prostate cancer include ketoconazole and aminoglutethimide. Long-term use of ketoconazole can result in impotence, pruritus, nail changes, and adrenal insufficiency. Aminoglutethimide commonly causes sedation and skin rashes. For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/skin-nail-changes/pruritus-hp-pdq">

4451Pruritus</a>

4452.</p>

4453</section>

4454</section>

4455<section id="_2272">

4456<h3 id="_2272_toc">

4457Cryosurgery </h3>

4458<p id="_2273" tabindex="-1">

4459Cryosurgery, or cryotherapy, is under evaluation for the treatment of localized prostate cancer. It is a surgical technique that involves destruction of prostate cancer cells by intermittent freezing of the prostate with cryoprobes, followed by thawing.[<a href="#cit/section_3.117">

4460117</a>

4461][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4462Level of evidence C1</a>

4463]; [<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

4464118</a>

4465,<a href="#cit/section_3.119">

4466119</a>

4467][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4468Level of evidence C3</a>

4469] There is limited evidence regarding its efficacy and safety compared with standard prostatectomy and radiation therapy, and the technique is evolving in an attempt to reduce local toxicity and normal tissue damage. The quality of evidence on efficacy is low, currently limited to case series of relatively small size, short follow-up, and surrogate outcomes of efficacy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

4470120</a>

4471]</p>

4472<p id="_2275" tabindex="-1">

4473Serious toxic effects associated with cryosurgery include bladder outlet injury, urinary incontinence, sexual impotence, and rectal injury. Impotence is common, ranging from about 47% to 100%. </p>

4474<p id="_2276" tabindex="-1">

4475The frequency of other side effects and the probability of cancer control at 5 years' follow-up have varied among reporting centers, and series are small compared with surgery and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_3.118">

4476118</a>

4477,<a href="#cit/section_3.119">

4478119</a>

4479] Other major complications include urethral sloughing, urinary fistula or stricture, and bladder neck obstruction.[<a href="#cit/section_3.120">

4480120</a>

4481]</p>

4482</section>

4483<section id="_2277">

4484<h3 id="_2277_toc">

4485Proton-Beam Therapy </h3>

4486<p id="_2278" tabindex="-1">

4487There is interest in the use of proton-beam therapy for the treatment of prostate cancer. Although the dose distribution of this form of charged-particle radiation could theoretically improve the therapeutic ratio of prostate radiation, allowing for an increase in dose to the tumor without a substantial increase in side effects, no randomized controlled trials have been reported that compare its efficacy and toxicity with those of other forms of radiation therapy.</p>

4488</section>

4489<section id="_3049">

4490<h3 id="_3049_toc">

4491Photodynamic Therapy</h3>

4492<p id="_3050" tabindex="-1">

4493Vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy using a photosensitizing agent has been tested in men with low-risk prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_3.121">

4494121</a>

4495] </p>

4496</section>

4497<section id="_2279">

4498<h3 id="_2279_toc">

4499Neoadjuvant Hormonal Therapy </h3>

4500<p id="_2280" tabindex="-1">

4501The role of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy is not established.[<a href="#cit/section_3.26">

450226</a>

4503,<a href="#cit/section_3.27">

450427</a>

4505]</p>

4506</section>

4507<section id="_2267">

4508<h3 id="_2267_toc">

4509Bicalutamide</h3>

4510<p id="_2268" tabindex="-1">

4511Bicalutamide has not been shown to improve OS in patients with localized or locally advanced prostate cancer.</p>

4512<p id="_2269" tabindex="-1">

4513Evidence (bicalutamide):</p>

4514<div class="pdq-content-list">

4515<ol id="_2270">

4516<li>

4517The Early Prostate Cancer program is a large, randomized, placebo-controlled, international trial that compared bicalutamide (150 mg PO qd) plus standard care (radical prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or watchful waiting, depending on local custom) with standard care alone for men with nonmetastatic localized or locally advanced prostate cancer (T1&#8211;2, N0, and NX; T3&#8211;4, any N; or any T, N+). Less than 2% of the 8,113 men had known nodal disease.[<a href="#cit/section_3.122">

4518122</a>

4519][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

4520Level of evidence A1</a>

4521] <div class="pdq-content-list">

4522<ul id="_2496">

4523<li>

4524At a median follow-up of 7.4 years, there was no difference in OS between the bicalutamide and placebo groups (about 76% in both arms [HR, 0.99; CI, 95%, 0.91&#8211;1.09; <em>

4525P</em>

4526 = .89]).</li>

4527</ul>

4528</div>

4529</li>

4530</ol>

4531</div>

4532</section>

4533<p id="_2842" tabindex="-1">

4534Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials">

4535NCI website</a>

4536.</p>

4602[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4606[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4607</li>
