4610[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4611</li>

4612<li id="section_3.19">

4613Hamdy FC, Donovan JL, Lane JA, et al.: 10-Year Outcomes after Monitoring, Surgery, or Radiotherapy for Localized Prostate Cancer. N Engl J Med 375 (15): 1415-1424, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27626136&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=27626136&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4614[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4615</li>

4616<li id="section_3.20">

4617Catalona WJ, Bigg SW: Nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy: evaluation of results after 250 patients. J Urol 143 (3): 538-43; discussion 544, 1990.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2304166&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2304166&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4618[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

N Engl J Med 377 (4): 352-360, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28578607&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28578607&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4938[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4939</li>

4940<li id="section_3.101">

4941James ND, de Bono JS, Spears MR, et al.: Abiraterone for Prostate Cancer Not Previously Treated with Hormone Therapy. N Engl J Med 377 (4): 338-351, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28578639&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28578639&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4942[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4943</li>

4944<li id="section_3.102">

4945Daniell HW: Osteoporosis after orchiectomy for prostate cancer. J Urol 157 (2): 439-44, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8996327&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8996327&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4946[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4947</li>

J Natl Cancer Inst 102 (1): 39-46, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19996060&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19996060&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4950[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4951</li>

4955</li>

4971</li>

4975</li>

Ann Intern Med 118 (11): 860-4, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7683180&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7683180&amp;dopt=Abstract">

4978[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4979</li>

4982[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

4983</li>

4984<li id="section_3.112">

4985Kirschenbaum A: Management of hormonal treatment effects. Cancer 75 (7 Suppl): 1983-86, 1995.</li>

4989</li>

4993</li>

4997</li>

5004[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5005</li>

5006<li id="section_3.118">

5007Donnelly BJ, Saliken JC, Ernst DS, et al.: Prospective trial of cryosurgical ablation of the prostate: five-year results. Urology 60 (4): 645-9, 2002.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12385926&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12385926&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5008[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5009</li>

5016[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5017</li>

5018<li id="section_3.121">

5019Azzouzi AR, Vincendeau S, Barret E, et al.: Padeliporfin vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy versus active surveillance in men with low-risk prostate cancer (CLIN1001 PCM301): an open-label, phase 3, randomised controlled trial. Lancet Oncol 18 (2): 181-191, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007457&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007457&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5020[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5021</li>

BJU Int 97 (2): 247-54, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16430622&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16430622&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5026</ol>

5027</div>

5028

5029 </section>

5030

5031

5032

5033 <section id="_68">

5034

5035 <h2>

5036Treatment of Stage I Prostate Cancer</h2>

5037

5038 <div id="_section_68" class="pdq-sections">

5039<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5040<h6>

5041In This Section</h6>

5042<ul>

5043<li>

5044<a href="#_1211_toc">

5045Overview</a>

5046</li>

5047<li>

5048<a href="#_1811_toc">

5049Treatment Options for Stage I Prostate Cancer <ul>

5050<li>

5051<a href="#_1830_toc">

5052Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

5053</li>

5054<li>

5055<a href="#_1832_toc">

5056Radical prostatectomy</a>

5057</li>

5058<li>

5059<a href="#_1834_toc">

5060External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT)</a>

5061</li>

5062<li>

5063<a href="#_1836_toc">

5064Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</a>

5065</li>

5066<li>

5067<a href="#_3229_toc">

5068Photodynamic therapy</a>

5069</li>

5070</ul>

5071</a>

5072</li>

5073<li>

5074<a href="#_TrialSearch_68_sid_4_toc">

5075Current Clinical Trials</a>

5076</li>

5077</ul>

5078</nav>

5079<section id="_1211">

5080<h3 id="_1211_toc">

5081Overview</h3>

5082<p id="_900" tabindex="-1">

5083Stage I prostate cancer is defined by the American Joint Committee on Cancer's TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification system:[<a href="#cit/section_4.1">

50841</a>

5085]</p>

5086<div class="pdq-content-list">

5087<ul id="_901">

5088<li>

5089 cT1a&#8211;c, N0, M0, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) &lt;10 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5090<li>

5091cT2a, N0, M0, PSA &lt;10 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5092<li>

5093pT2, N0, M0, PSA &lt;10 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5094</ul>

5095</div>

5096<p id="_2548" tabindex="-1">

5097The frequency of clinically silent, nonmetastatic prostate cancer that can be found at autopsy greatly increases with age and may be as high as 50% to 60% in men aged 90 years and older. Undoubtedly, the incidental discovery of these occult cancers at prostatic surgery performed for other reasons accounts for the similar survival of men with stage I prostate cancer, compared with the normal male population, adjusted for age.</p>

5098<p id="_2307" tabindex="-1">

5099 Many stage I cancers are well differentiated and only focally involve the gland (T1a, N0, M0); most require no treatment other than careful follow-up.[<a href="#cit/section_4.2">

51002</a>

5101]</p>

5102<p id="_2311" tabindex="-1">

5103In younger patients (aged 50&#8211;60 years) whose expected survival is long, treatment should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

51043</a>

5105] Radical prostatectomy, external-beam radiation therapy (EBRT), interstitial implantation of radioisotopes, and watchful waiting and active surveillance/active monitoring yield apparently similar survival rates in noncontrolled, selected series. The decision to treat should be made in the context of the patient&#8217;s age, associated medical illnesses, and personal desires.[<a href="#cit/section_4.3">

51063</a>

5107]</p>

5108</section>

5109<section id="_1811">

5110<h3 id="_1811_toc">

5111Treatment Options for Stage I Prostate Cancer </h3>

5112<p id="_980" tabindex="-1">

5113Treatment options for patients with <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_68">

5114stage I prostate cancer</a>

5115 include the following:</p>

5116<div class="pdq-content-list">

5117<ol id="_1812">

5118<li>

5119<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1830">

5120Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

5121.</li>

5122<li>

5123<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1832">

5124Radical prostatectomy</a>

5125.</li>

5126<li>

5127<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1834">

5128External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT)</a>

5129.</li>

5130<li>

5131<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1836">

5132Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</a>

5133. </li>

5134<li>

5135High-intensity focused ultrasound therapy (under clinical evaluation).[<a href="#cit/section_4.4">

51364</a>

5137-<a href="#cit/section_4.7">

51387</a>

5139]</li>

5140<li>

5141<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3229">

5142Photodynamic therapy</a>

5143 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

5144</ol>

5145</div>

5146<section id="_1830">

5147<h4 id="_1830_toc">

5148Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</h4>

5149<p id="_2312" tabindex="-1">

5150Asymptomatic patients of advanced age or with concomitant illness may warrant consideration of careful observation without immediate active treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

51518</a>

5152-<a href="#cit/section_4.10">

515310</a>

5154] Watch and wait, observation, expectant management, and active surveillance/active monitoring are terms indicating a strategy that does not employ immediate therapy with curative intent. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2283">

5155Watchful Waiting or Active Surveillance/Active Monitoring</a>

5156 section.</p>

5157<p id="_2585" tabindex="-1">

5158Evidence (observation with delayed hormonal therapy):</p>

5159<div class="pdq-content-list">

5160<ol id="_2586">

5161<li>

5162In a retrospective pooled analysis, 828 men with clinically localized prostate cancer were managed by initial conservative therapy with subsequent hormonal therapy given at the time of symptomatic disease progression.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5163<ul id="_2587">

5164<li>

5165This study showed that the patients with grade 1 or grade 2 tumors experienced a disease-specific survival of 87% at 10 years and that their overall survival (OS) closely approximated the expected survival among men of similar ages in the general population.[<a href="#cit/section_4.8">

51668</a>

5167]</li>

5168</ul>

5169</div>

5170</li>

5171</ol>

5172</div>

5173</section>

5174<section id="_1832">

5175<h4 id="_1832_toc">

5176Radical prostatectomy</h4>

5177<p id="_2313" tabindex="-1">

5178Radical prostatectomy, usually with pelvic lymphadenectomy (with or without

5179the nerve-sparing technique designed to preserve potency) is the most commonly applied therapy with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_4.11">

518011</a>

5181-<a href="#cit/section_4.13">

518213</a>

5183] Radical

5184prostatectomy may be difficult after a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).</p>

5185<p id="_2549" tabindex="-1">

5186Because about 40% to 50% of men with clinically organ-confined disease are found to have pathological extension beyond the prostate capsule or surgical margins, the role of postprostatectomy adjuvant radiation therapy has been studied.</p>

5187<p id="_1833" tabindex="-1">

5188 Consideration may also be given to postoperative radiation therapy (PORT) for patients who

5189are found to have seminal vesicle invasion by tumor at

5190the time of prostatectomy or who have a detectable level of PSA more than 3 weeks after surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

519114</a>

5192-<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

519316</a>

5194] Because duration of follow-up

5195in available studies is still relatively short, the value of PORT has not been determined; however, PORT does reduce local recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_4.14">

519614</a>

5197] Careful treatment planning is

5198necessary to avoid morbidity. </p>

5199<p id="_2314" tabindex="-1">

5200Evidence (radical prostatectomy followed by radiation therapy):</p>

5201<div class="pdq-content-list">

5202<ol id="_2315">

5203<li>

5204In a randomized trial of 425 men with pathological T3, N0, and M0 disease, postsurgical EBRT (60&#8211;64 Gy to the prostatic fossa over 30&#8211;32 fractions) was compared with observation.[<a href="#cit/section_4.15">

520515</a>

5206][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5207Level of evidence A1</a>

5208]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5209<ul id="_2316">

5210<li>

5211The primary end point, metastasis-free survival, could be affected by serial PSA monitoring and resulting metastatic work-up for PSA increase. This could have biased the primary end point in favor of radiation therapy, which was associated with a lower rate of PSA rise. Nevertheless, metastasis-free survival was not statistically different between the two study arms (<em>

5212P</em>

5213 = .06). After a median follow-up of about 10.6 years, the overall median survival was 14.7 years in the radiation therapy group versus 13.8 years in the observation group (<em>

5214P</em>

5215 = .16).</li>

5216<li>

5217Although the OS rates were not statistically different, complication rates were substantially higher in the radiation therapy group: overall complications were 23.8% versus 11.9%, rectal complications were 3.3% versus 0%, and urethral stricture was 17.8% versus 9.5%.</li>

5218<li>

5219After a median follow-up of about 12.5 years, however, OS was better in the radiation therapy arm; hazard ratio (HR)<sub>

5220death,</sub>

5221 0.72 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.55&#8211;0.96; <em>

5222P</em>

5223 = .023). The 10-year estimated survival rates were 74% in the radiation therapy arm and 66% in the control arm. The 10-year estimated metastasis-free survivals were 73% and 65% (<em>

5224P</em>

5225 = .016).[<a href="#cit/section_4.16">

522616</a>

5227][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5228Level of evidence A1</a>

5229]</li>

5230</ul>

5231</div>

5232</li>

5233<li>

5234Another randomized trial came to a different conclusion with respect to the effect of postoperative radiation therapy on OS.[<a href="#cit/section_4.17">

523517</a>

5236][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5237Level of evidence A1</a>

5238] In the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC) trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002511">

5239EORTC-22911</a>

5240 [NCT00002511]), 1,005 men aged 75 years and younger with clinical T0 to T3 prostate cancer were randomly assigned after prostatectomy to receive PORT (60 Gy) or observation, with subsequent therapy delayed until the occurrence of either biochemical or clinical relapse. The recommended treatment for local recurrence was radiation.<div class="pdq-content-list">

5241<ul id="_2652">

5242<li>

5243With a median follow-up of 10.6 years (up to 16.6 years), the biochemical progression-free survival (PFS) rates were higher in the observation study arm (60.6% vs. 41.1%; HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.59; <em>

5244P</em>

5245 &lt; .0001). Locoregional relapse rates were 8.4% versus 17.3% in favor of immediate radiation (HR, 0.45; 95% CI, 0.32&#8211;0.68; <em>

5246P</em>

5247 &lt; .0001). </li>

5248<li>

5249However, the large differences in biochemical relapse-free survival and local recurrence did not translate into an advantage in either distant metastasis (11.0% vs. 11.3%; HR, 0.99; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;1.44; <em>

5250P</em>

5251 = .94) or in OS (76.9% with immediate radiation vs. 80.7% with observation; HR, 1.18; 95% CI, 0.91&#8211;1.53; <em>

5252P</em>

5253 = .2). Nor was there a difference in prostate&#8211; cancer-specific mortality (3.9% vs. 5.2%; HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.46&#8211;1.33; <em>

5254P</em>

5255 = .34)</li>

5256<li>

5257 The 10-year cumulative risk of severe (grade 3) late toxicity in the immediate radiation study group was 5.3% versus 2.5% in the observation group (<em>

5258P</em>

5259 = .052). Late adverse effects of any grade were also higher in the immediate radiation group (70.8% vs. 59.7%; <em>

5260P</em>

5261 = .001).</li>

5262</ul>

5263</div>

5264</li>

5265</ol>

5266</div>

5267<p id="_2505" tabindex="-1">

5268Radical prostatectomy has been compared with watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2155">

5269Radical prostatectomy compared with other treatment options</a>

5270 section.</p>

5271<p id="_2653" tabindex="-1">

5272Evidence (radical prostatectomy compared with watchful waiting):</p>

5273<div class="pdq-content-list">

5274<ol id="_2654">

5275<li>

5276The Prostate Intervention Versus Observation Trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00007644">

5277PIVOT-1</a>

5278 or VA-CSP-407

5279[NCT00007644]) is a randomized trial conducted in the PSA screening era that directly compared radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting. From November 1994 through January 2002, 731 men aged 75 years or younger with localized prostate cancer (stage T1&#8211;2, NX, M0, with a blood PSA &lt;50 ng/mL) and a life expectancy of at least 10 years were randomly assigned to radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting.[<a href="#cit/section_4.18">

528018</a>

5281-<a href="#cit/section_4.20">

528220</a>

5283][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5284Level of evidence A1</a>

5285] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5286<ul id="_2655">

5287<li>

5288About 50% of the men had nonpalpable, screen-detected disease.</li>

5289<li>

5290After a median follow-up of 12.7 years (range up to about 19.5 years), the all-cause mortality was 61.3% versus 66.8% in the prostatectomy and watchful-waiting study arms, respectively, an absolute difference of 5.5 percentage points (95% CI -1.5 to 12.4) that was not statistically significant (HR, 0.84; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;1.01). Prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality was 7.4% versus 11.4%, and it also was not statistically significant (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;1.02).</li>

5291<li>

5292 Although treatment for disease progression was given more frequently in the observation arm of the study, most of the treatment was for asymptomatic, local, or biochemical (PSA) progression.</li>

5293<li>

5294 As expected, urinary incontinence and erectile/sexual dysfunction was more common in the prostatectomy group for at least 10 years of follow-up. Absolute differences in patient-reported use of absorbent urinary pads was greater in the surgery group by more than 30 percentage points at all time points for at least 10 years. Disease- or treatment-related limitations in activities of daily living were worse with surgery than with observation through 2 years, but then were similar in both study arms.</li>

5295</ul>

5296</div>

5297</li>

5298</ol>

5299</div>

5300</section>

5301<section id="_1834">

5302<h4 id="_1834_toc">

5303External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT)</h4>

5304<p id="_1835" tabindex="-1">

5305EBRT is another treatment option used with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_4.21">

530621</a>

5307-<a href="#cit/section_4.25">

530825</a>

5309] Definitive radiation therapy should

5310be delayed 4 to 6 weeks after TURP to reduce the incidence of

5311stricture.[<a href="#cit/section_4.26">

531226</a>

5313] Adjuvant hormonal therapy should be considered for patients with bulky T2b to T2c tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_4.27">

531427</a>

5315,<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

531628</a>

5317] </p>

5318<p id="_2624" tabindex="-1">

5319Evidence (EBRT with or without adjuvant hormonal therapy):</p>

5320<div class="pdq-content-list">

5321<ol id="_2320">

5322<li>

5323In the Radiation Therapy Oncology Group (RTOG) trial RTOG-7706, prophylactic radiation therapy to clinically or pathologically uninvolved pelvic lymph nodes did not appear to improve OS or prostate cancer-specific survival.[<a href="#cit/section_4.29">

532429</a>

5325][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5326Level of evidence A1</a>

5327]</li>

5328<li>

5329The phase III randomized <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00769548">

5330RTOG-9413</a>

5331 trial (NCT00769548) included 1,323 men with localized prostate cancer, an elevated PSA, and an estimated risk of lymph node involvement of 15%. Patients were randomly assigned to one of four treatment arms: whole-pelvic radiation therapy plus neoadjuvant and concurrent hormonal therapy; prostate-only radiation therapy plus neoadjuvant and concurrent hormonal therapy; whole-pelvic radiation therapy plus adjuvant hormonal therapy; or pelvic-only radiation therapy plus adjuvant hormonal therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_4.30">

533230</a>

5333]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.31">

533431</a>

5335][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5336Level of evidence B1</a>

5337]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5338<ul id="_2618">

5339<li>

5340Although RTOG-9413 showed increased PFS at 4 years for patients who had a 15% estimated risk of lymph node involvement and received whole-pelvic radiation therapy compared with prostate-only radiation therapy, OS and PSA failure rates were not significantly different.</li>

5341</ul>

5342</div>

5343</li>

5344<li>

5345 In a randomized trial, 875 men with locally advanced nonmetastatic prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;T2 moderately or poorly differentiated tumors; T3 tumors of any grade) were randomly assigned to receive 3 months of a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone agonist plus long-term flutamide (250 mg PO tid) with or without EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_4.28">

534628</a>

5347][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5348Level of evidence A1</a>

5349]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5350<ul id="_2322">

5351<li>

5352 Nineteen percent of the men had tumor stage T2, and 78% of the men had T3. At 10 years, both overall mortality (29.6% vs. 39.4%; 95% CI for the difference, 0.8%&#8211;18.8%) and the prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality (11.9% vs. 23.9%; 95% CI for the difference, 4.9%&#8211;19.1%) favored combined hormonal and radiation therapy.</li>

5353<li>

5354Although flutamide might not be considered a standard hormonal monotherapy in the setting of T2 or T3 tumors, radiation therapy provided a disease-free survival or tumor-specific survival advantage even though this monotherapy was applied. This analysis rests on the assumption that flutamide does not shorten life expectancy and cancer-specific survival. Radiation therapy was not delivered by current standards of dose and technique.</li>

5355</ul>

5356</div>

5357</li>

5358</ol>

5359</div>

5360</section>

5361<section id="_1836">

5362<h4 id="_1836_toc">

5363Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</h4>

5364<p id="_1837" tabindex="-1">

5365Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes (i.e., iodine I 125 [125I], palladium, and iridium Ir 192) done through a transperineal technique with either ultrasound or computed-tomography guidance, is

5366being used in patients with T1 or T2a tumors. Short-term

5367results in these patients are similar to those for radical prostatectomy or

5368EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

536932</a>

5370,<a href="#cit/section_4.33">

537133</a>

5372]; [<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

537334</a>

5374][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5375Level of evidence C3</a>

5376]</p>

5377<p id="_588" tabindex="-1">

5378Factors for consideration in the use of interstitial implants include the following:</p>

5379<div class="pdq-content-list">

5380<ul id="_1536">

5381<li>

5382The implant is performed as outpatient surgery.</li>

5383<li>

5384The rate of

5385maintenance of sexual potency with interstitial implants has been reported to

5386be 86% to 92%.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

538732</a>

5388,<a href="#cit/section_4.34">

538934</a>

5390] In contrast, rates of maintenance of sexual potency with radical prostatectomy were 10% to 40% and 40% to 60% with EBRT. </li>

5391<li>

5392Typical side effects from interstitial implants that subside with time include urinary tract frequency, urgency, and less commonly, urinary retention.</li>

5393<li>

5394Rectal ulceration may also be seen. In one series, a 10% 2-year actuarial genitourinary grade 2 complication rate and a 12% risk of rectal ulceration were seen. This risk decreased with increased operator experience and modification of the implant technique.[<a href="#cit/section_4.32">

539532</a>

5396]</li>

5397</ul>

5398</div>

5399<p id="_2323" tabindex="-1">

5400Long-term

5401follow-up of these patients is necessary to assess treatment efficacy and side

5402effects.</p>

5403<p id="_591" tabindex="-1">

5404Retropubic freehand implantation with 125I has been associated with an

5405increased local failure and complication rate [<a href="#cit/section_4.35">

540635</a>

5407,<a href="#cit/section_4.36">

540836</a>

5409] and is now rarely done.

5410</p>

5411</section>

5412<section id="_3229">

5413<h4 id="_3229_toc">

5414Photodynamic therapy</h4>

5415<p id="_3230" tabindex="-1">

5416Vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy using a photosensitizing agent has been tested in men with low-risk prostate cancer. In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01310894">

5417CLIN1001 PCM301</a>

5418 (NCT01310894) randomized trial, 413 men with low-risk cancer (tumor stage T1&#8211;T2c, PSA &#8804;10 ng/mL, generally Gleason score 3 + 3) were randomly assigned in an open-label trial to receive either the photosensitizing agent, padeliporfin (4 mg/kg intravenously [IV] over 10 minutes, and optical fibers inserted into the target area of the prostate, then activated by 753 nm laser light at 150 mW/cm for 22 minutes 15 seconds), or active surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

541937</a>

5420] Median time to local disease progression was 28.3 months for patients who received padeliporfin and 14.1 months for patients who were assigned to active surveillance (HR, 0.34; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.46; <em>

5421P</em>

5422 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_4.37">

542337</a>

5424][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5425Level of evidence B1</a>

5426] However, the appropriate population for photodynamic therapy may be quite narrow, as it may overtreat men with very low-risk disease and undertreat men with higher-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_4.38">

542738</a>

5428]</p>

5429</section>

5430</section>

5431<section id="_TrialSearch_68_sid_4">

5432<h3 id="_TrialSearch_68_sid_4_toc">

5433Current Clinical Trials</h3>

5434<p id="_TrialSearch_68_22" tabindex="-1">

5435Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

5436advanced clinical trial search</a>

5437 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

5438General information</a>

5439 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

5440</section>

5508[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

N Engl J Med 367 (3): 203-13, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22808955&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22808955&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5512[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
