5514<li id="section_4.19">

5515Wilt TJ: The Prostate Cancer Intervention Versus Observation Trial: VA/NCI/AHRQ Cooperative Studies Program #407 (PIVOT): design and baseline results of a randomized controlled trial comparing radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting for men with clinically localized prostate cancer. J Natl Cancer Inst Monogr 2012 (45): 184-90, 2012.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23271771&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=23271771&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5516[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5517</li>

5518<li id="section_4.20">

5519Wilt TJ, Jones KM, Barry MJ, et al.: Follow-up of Prostatectomy versus Observation for Early Prostate Cancer. N Engl J Med 377 (2): 132-142, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28700844&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28700844&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5520[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5521</li>

5522<li id="section_4.21">

5523Bagshaw MA: External radiation therapy of carcinoma of the prostate. Cancer 45 (7 Suppl): 1912-21, 1980.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7370942&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7370942&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5524[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5525</li>

5526<li id="section_4.22">

5527Forman JD, Zinreich E, Lee DJ, et al.: Improving the therapeutic ratio of external beam irradiation for carcinoma of the prostate. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 11 (12): 2073-80, 1985.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=4066439&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=4066439&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5528[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5529</li>

5530<li id="section_4.23">

5531Ploysongsang S, Aron BS, Shehata WM, et al.: Comparison of whole pelvis versus small-field radiation therapy for carcinoma of prostate. Urology 27 (1): 10-6, 1986.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3079933&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3079933&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5532[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5533</li>

5534<li id="section_4.24">

5535Pilepich MV, Bagshaw MA, Asbell SO, et al.: Definitive radiotherapy in resectable (stage A2 and B) carcinoma of the prostate--results of a nationwide overview. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 13 (5): 659-63, 1987.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3570891&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3570891&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5536[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5537</li>

5538<li id="section_4.25">

5539Amdur RJ, Parsons JT, Fitzgerald LT, et al.: The effect of overall treatment time on local control in patients with adenocarcinoma of the prostate treated with radiation therapy. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 19 (6): 1377-82, 1990.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2262361&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2262361&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5540[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5541</li>

5542<li id="section_4.26">

5543Seymore CH, el-Mahdi AM, Schellhammer PF: The effect of prior transurethral resection of the prostate on post radiation urethral strictures and bladder neck contractures. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 12 (9): 1597-600, 1986.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3759585&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3759585&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5544[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5545</li>

5546<li id="section_4.27">

5547Seidenfeld J, Samson DJ, Aronson N, et al.: Relative effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of methods of androgen suppression in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. Evid Rep Technol Assess (Summ) (4): i-x, 1-246, I1-36, passim, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11098244&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11098244&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5548[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5549</li>

5550<li id="section_4.28">

5551Widmark A, Klepp O, Solberg A, et al.: Endocrine treatment, with or without radiotherapy, in locally advanced prostate cancer (SPCG-7/SFUO-3): an open randomised phase III trial. Lancet 373 (9660): 301-8, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19091394&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19091394&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5552[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5553</li>

5554<li id="section_4.29">

5555Asbell SO, Martz KL, Shin KH, et al.: Impact of surgical staging in evaluating the radiotherapeutic outcome in RTOG #77-06, a phase III study for T1BN0M0 (A2) and T2N0M0 (B) prostate carcinoma. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 40 (4): 769-82, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9531360&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9531360&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5556[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5557</li>

5558<li id="section_4.30">

5559Roach M, DeSilvio M, Lawton C, et al.: Phase III trial comparing whole-pelvic versus prostate-only radiotherapy and neoadjuvant versus adjuvant combined androgen suppression: Radiation Therapy Oncology Group 9413. J Clin Oncol 21 (10): 1904-11, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743142&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743142&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5560[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5561</li>

5562<li id="section_4.31">

5563Pollack A: A call for more with a desire for less: pelvic radiotherapy with androgen deprivation in the treatment of prostate cancer. J Clin Oncol 21 (10): 1899-901, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743140&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743140&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5564[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5565</li>

5566<li id="section_4.32">

5567Wallner K, Roy J, Harrison L: Tumor control and morbidity following transperineal iodine 125 implantation for stage T1/T2 prostatic carcinoma. J Clin Oncol 14 (2): 449-53, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8636756&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8636756&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5568[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5569</li>

5570<li id="section_4.33">

5571D'Amico AV, Coleman CN: Role of interstitial radiotherapy in the management of clinically organ-confined prostate cancer: the jury is still out. J Clin Oncol 14 (1): 304-15, 1996.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8558212&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=8558212&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5572[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5573</li>

5574<li id="section_4.34">

5575Ragde H, Blasko JC, Grimm PD, et al.: Interstitial iodine-125 radiation without adjuvant therapy in the treatment of clinically localized prostate carcinoma. Cancer 80 (3): 442-53, 1997.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9241078&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9241078&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5576[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5577</li>

5578<li id="section_4.35">

5579Kuban DA, el-Mahdi AM, Schellhammer PF: I-125 interstitial implantation for prostate cancer. What have we learned 10 years later? Cancer 63 (12): 2415-20, 1989.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2720587&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2720587&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5580[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5581</li>

5582<li id="section_4.36">

5583Fuks Z, Leibel SA, Wallner KE, et al.: The effect of local control on metastatic dissemination in carcinoma of the prostate: long-term results in patients treated with 125I implantation. Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 21 (3): 537-47, 1991.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1869452&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=1869452&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5584[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5585</li>

5586<li id="section_4.37">

5587Azzouzi AR, Vincendeau S, Barret E, et al.: Padeliporfin vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy versus active surveillance in men with low-risk prostate cancer (CLIN1001 PCM301): an open-label, phase 3, randomised controlled trial. Lancet Oncol 18 (2): 181-191, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007457&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007457&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5588[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5589</li>

5590<li id="section_4.38">

5591Freedland SJ: Low-risk prostate cancer: to treat or not to treat. Lancet Oncol 18 (2): 156-157, 2017.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007456&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=28007456&amp;dopt=Abstract">

5592[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

5593</li>

5594</ol>

5595</div>

5596

5597 </section>

5598

5599

5600

5601 <section id="_69">

5602

5603 <h2>

5604Treatment of Stage II Prostate Cancer</h2>

5605

5606 <div id="_section_69" class="pdq-sections">

5607<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

5608<h6>

5609In This Section</h6>

5610<ul>

5611<li>

5612<a href="#_604_toc">

5613Overview<ul>

5614<li>

5615<a href="#_2333_toc">

5616Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) changes as markers of tumor progression</a>

5617</li>

5618<li>

5619<a href="#_2337_toc">

5620Bisphosphonates and risk of bone metastases</a>

5621</li>

5622</ul>

5623</a>

5624</li>

5625<li>

5626<a href="#_1814_toc">

5627Treatment Options for Stage II Prostate Cancer <ul>

5628<li>

5629<a href="#_1838_toc">

5630Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

5631</li>

5632<li>

5633<a href="#_1840_toc">

5634Radical prostatectomy </a>

5635</li>

5636<li>

5637<a href="#_1842_toc">

5638External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

5639</li>

5640<li>

5641<a href="#_2357_toc">

5642Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</a>

5643</li>

5644<li>

5645<a href="#_3231_toc">

5646Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</a>

5647</li>

5648<li>

5649<a href="#_3235_toc">

5650High-intensity focused ultrasound</a>

5651</li>

5652<li>

5653<a href="#_3237_toc">

5654Proton-beam radiation therapy</a>

5655</li>

5656<li>

5657<a href="#_3239_toc">

5658Photodynamic therapy</a>

5659</li>

5660</ul>

5661</a>

5662</li>

5663<li>

5664<a href="#_TrialSearch_69_sid_5_toc">

5665Current Clinical Trials</a>

5666</li>

5667</ul>

5668</nav>

5669<section id="_604">

5670<h3 id="_604_toc">

5671Overview</h3>

5672<p id="_605" tabindex="-1">

5673Stage II prostate cancer is defined by the American Joint Committee on Cancer's TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification system:[<a href="#cit/section_5.1">

56741</a>

5675]</p>

5676<p id="_3088" tabindex="-1">

5677<strong>

5678Stage IIA</strong>

5679</p>

5680<div class="pdq-content-list">

5681<ul id="_3086">

5682<li>

5683cT1a&#8211;c, N0, M0, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) &#8805;10 &lt;20 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5684<li>

5685cT2a, N0, M0, PSA &#8805;10 &lt;20 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5686<li>

5687pT2, N0, M0, PSA &#8805;10 &lt;20 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5688<li>

5689cT2b&#8211;c, N0, M0, PSA &lt;20 ng/mL, Gleason &#8804;6.</li>

5690</ul>

5691</div>

5692<p id="_3089" tabindex="-1">

5693<strong>

5694Stage IIB</strong>

5695</p>

5696<div class="pdq-content-list">

5697<ul id="_3087">

5698<li>

5699T1&#8211;2, N0, M0, PSA &lt;20 ng/mL, Gleason 7.</li>

5700</ul>

5701</div>

5702<p id="_3090" tabindex="-1">

5703<strong>

5704Stage IIC</strong>

5705</p>

5706<div class="pdq-content-list">

5707<ul id="_3091">

5708<li>

5709T1&#8211;2, N0, M0, PSA &lt;20, Gleason 7 or 8.</li>

5710</ul>

5711</div>

5712<p id="_2326" tabindex="-1">

5713Radical prostatectomy, external-beam radiation therapy (EBRT), and interstitial implantation of radioisotopes are each employed in the treatment of stage II prostate cancer with apparently similar therapeutic effects. Radical prostatectomy and radiation therapy yield apparently similar survival rates with as many as 10 years of follow-up. For well-selected patients, radical prostatectomy is associated with a 15-year survival comparable with an age-matched population without prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

57142</a>

5715] Unfortunately, randomized comparative trials of these treatment methods with prolonged follow-up are lacking. </p>

5716<p id="_2327" tabindex="-1">

5717Patients with a small, palpable cancer (T2a, N0, and M0) fare better than patients in whom the disease involves both sides of the gland (T2c, N0, and M0). Patients proven free of node metastases by pelvic lymphadenectomy fare better than patients in whom this staging procedure is not performed; however, this is the result of selection of patients who have a more favorable prognosis. </p>

5718<p id="_2328" tabindex="-1">

5719Side effects of the various forms of therapy&#8212;including impotence, incontinence, and bowel injury&#8212;should be considered in determining the type of treatment to employ. </p>

5720<section id="_2333">

5721<h4 id="_2333_toc">

5722Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) changes as markers of tumor progression</h4>

5723<p id="_2334" tabindex="-1">

5724Often, changes in PSA are thought to be markers of tumor progression. Even though a tumor marker or characteristic may be consistently associated with a high risk of prostate cancer progression or death, it may be a very poor predictor of very limited utility in making therapeutic decisions.</p>

5725<p id="_2589" tabindex="-1">

5726Baseline PSA and rate of PSA change were associated with subsequent metastasis or prostate cancer death in a cohort of 267 men with clinically localized prostate cancer who were managed by watchful waiting or active surveillance in the control arm of a randomized trial comparing radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting.[<a href="#cit/section_5.3">

57273</a>

5728,<a href="#cit/section_5.4">

57294</a>

5730] Nevertheless, the accuracy of classifying men into groups whose cancer remained indolent versus those whose cancer progressed was poor at all examined cut points of PSA or PSA rate of change.</p>

5731</section>

5732<section id="_2337">

5733<h4 id="_2337_toc">

5734Bisphosphonates and risk of bone metastases</h4>

5735<p id="_2338" tabindex="-1">

5736Patients with locally advanced nonmetastatic disease (T2&#8211;T4, N0&#8211;N1, and M0) are at risk of developing bone metastases. Bisphosphonates are being studied as a strategy to decrease this risk.</p>

5737<p id="_2339" tabindex="-1">

5738Evidence (bisphosphonates and risk of bone metastases):</p>

5739<div class="pdq-content-list">

5740<ol id="_2340">

5741<li>

5742A placebo-controlled randomized trial (MRC-PR04) evaluated a 5-year regimen of the first-generation bisphosphonate clodronate in high oral doses (2,080 mg qd). Clodronate therapy had no favorable impact on either time to symptomatic bone metastasis or survival.[<a href="#cit/section_5.5">

57435</a>

5744][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5745Level of evidence A1</a>

5746] </li>

5747</ol>

5748</div>

5749</section>

5750</section>

5751<section id="_1814">

5752<h3 id="_1814_toc">

5753Treatment Options for Stage II Prostate Cancer </h3>

5754<p id="_1815" tabindex="-1">

5755Treatment options for patients with <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_69">

5756stage II prostate cancer </a>

5757 include the following:</p>

5758<div class="pdq-content-list">

5759<ol id="_1218">

5760<li>

5761<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1838">

5762Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

5763.</li>

5764<li>

5765<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1840">

5766Radical prostatectomy</a>

5767.</li>

5768<li>

5769<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1842">

5770External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

5771.</li>

5772<li>

5773<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2357">

5774Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</a>

5775.</li>

5776<li>

5777<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3231">

5778Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</a>

5779 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

5780<li>

5781<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3235">

5782High-intensity focused ultrasound</a>

5783 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

5784<li>

5785<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3237">

5786Proton-beam radiation therapy</a>

5787 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

5788<li>

5789<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3239">

5790Photodynamic therapy</a>

5791 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

5792</ol>

5793</div>

5794<p id="_3249" tabindex="-1">

5795Patients with stage II prostate cancer are candidates for clinical trials, including trials of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy followed by radical prostatectomy.</p>

5796<section id="_1838">

5797<h4 id="_1838_toc">

5798Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</h4>

5799<p id="_2341" tabindex="-1">

5800Asymptomatic patients of advanced age or with concomitant illness may warrant consideration of careful observation without immediate active treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

58016</a>

5802-<a href="#cit/section_5.8">

58038</a>

5804] Watch and wait, observation, expectant management, and active surveillance/active monitoring are terms indicating a strategy that does not employ <em>

5805immediate</em>

5806 therapy with curative intent. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_62">

5807Treatment Option Overview for Prostate Cancer</a>

5808 section.</p>

5809<p id="_2590" tabindex="-1">

5810Evidence (observation with delayed hormonal therapy):</p>

5811<div class="pdq-content-list">

5812<ol id="_2591">

5813<li>

5814 In a retrospective pooled analysis, 828 men with clinically localized prostate cancer were managed by initial conservative therapy with subsequent hormonal therapy given at the time of symptomatic disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_5.6">

58156</a>

5816]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5817<ul id="_2592">

5818<li>

5819Patients with well-differentiated tumors or moderately well-differentiated tumors experienced a disease-specific survival of 87% at 10 years. Overall survival (OS) closely approximated the expected survival among men of similar ages in the general population.</li>

5820<li>

5821The decision to treat should be made in the context of the patient&#8217;s age, associated medical illnesses, and personal desires.</li>

5822</ul>

5823</div>

5824</li>

5825</ol>

5826</div>

5827</section>

5828<section id="_1840">

5829<h4 id="_1840_toc">

5830Radical prostatectomy </h4>

5831<p id="_2342" tabindex="-1">

5832Radical prostatectomy, usually with pelvic lymphadenectomy (with or without the nerve-sparing technique designed to preserve potency) is the most commonly applied therapy with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_5.2">

58332</a>

5834,<a href="#cit/section_5.9">

58359</a>

5836,<a href="#cit/section_5.10">

583710</a>

5838] Radical prostatectomy may be difficult after a transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). </p>

5839<p id="_2550" tabindex="-1">

5840Because about 40% to 50% of men with clinically organ-confined disease are found to have pathological extension beyond the prostate capsule or surgical margins, the role of postprostatectomy adjuvant radiation therapy has been studied. </p>

5841<p id="_2343" tabindex="-1">

5842Consideration may also be given to postoperative radiation therapy (PORT) for patients who are found to have seminal vesicle invasion by tumor at the time of prostatectomy or who have a detectable level of PSA more than 3 weeks after surgery.[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

584311</a>

5844-<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

584513</a>

5846] Because the duration of follow-up in available studies is relatively short, the value of PORT has not been determined; however, PORT does reduce local recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_5.11">

584711</a>

5848] Careful treatment planning is necessary to avoid morbidity.</p>

5849<p id="_2345" tabindex="-1">

5850Evidence (radical prostatectomy followed by radiation therapy):</p>

5851<div class="pdq-content-list">

5852<ol id="_2642">

5853<li>

5854In a randomized trial of 425 men with pathological T3, N0, M0 disease, postsurgical EBRT (60&#8211;64 Gy to the prostatic fossa over 30&#8211;32 fractions) was compared with observation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.12">

585512</a>

5856][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5857Level of evidence A1</a>

5858]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5859<ul id="_2643">

5860<li>

5861The primary end point, metastasis-free survival, could be affected by serial PSA monitoring and resulting metastatic work-up for PSA increase. This could have biased the primary end point in favor of radiation therapy, which was associated with a lower rate of PSA rise. Nevertheless, metastasis-free survival was not statistically different between the two study arms (<em>

5862P</em>

5863 = .06). After a median follow-up of about 10.6 years, overall median survival was 14.7 years in the radiation therapy group versus 13.8 years in the observation group (<em>

5864P</em>

5865 = .16).</li>

5866<li>

5867Although the OS rates were not statistically different, complication rates were substantially higher in the radiation therapy group compared with the observation group: overall complications were 23.8% versus 11.9%, rectal complications were 3.3% versus 0%, and urethral stricture was 17.8% versus 9.5%, respectively. </li>

5868<li>

5869After a median follow-up of about 12.5 years, however, OS was better in the radiation therapy arm; hazard ratio (HR)<sub>

5870death,</sub>

5871 0.72 (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.55&#8211;0.96; <em>

5872P</em>

5873 = .023). The 10-year estimated survival rates were 74% in the radiation therapy arm and 66% in the control arm. The 10-year estimated metastasis-free survivals were 73% and 65% (<em>

5874P</em>

5875 = .016).[<a href="#cit/section_5.13">

587613</a>

5877][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5878Level of evidence A1</a>

5879]</li>

5880</ul>

5881</div>

5882</li>

5883</ol>

5884</div>

5885<p id="_2644" tabindex="-1">

5886Evidence (radical prostatectomy compared directly with watchful waiting/active surveillance/active monitoring and/or external-beam radiation therapy):</p>

5887<div class="pdq-content-list">

5888<ol id="_2346">

5889<li>

5890In a randomized clinical trial performed in Sweden in the pre-PSA screening era, 695 men with prostate cancer were randomly assigned to radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting. Only about 5% of the men in the trial had been diagnosed by PSA screening. Therefore, the men had more extensive local disease than is typically the case in men diagnosed with prostate cancer in the United States.[<a href="#cit/section_5.14">

589114</a>

5892-<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

589316</a>

5894]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5895<ul id="_2746">

5896<li>

5897 The cumulative overall mortality at 18 years was 56.1% in the radical prostatectomy arm and 68.9% in the watchful waiting study arm (absolute difference, 12.7%; 95% CI, 5.1&#8211;20.3 percentage points; relative risk [RR]<sub>

5898death,</sub>

5899 0.71; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.86.[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

590016</a>

5901][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5902Level of evidence A1</a>

5903]</li>

5904<li>

5905 The cumulative incidence of prostate cancer deaths at 18 years was 17.7% versus 28.7% (absolute difference, 11.0%; 95% CI, 4.5&#8211;17.5 percentage points; RR<sub>

5906death</sub>

5907 from prostate cancer, 0.56; 95% CI, 0.41&#8211;0.77).[<a href="#cit/section_5.16">

590816</a>

5909]</li>

5910<li>

5911 In a post-hoc&#8211;subset analysis, the improvement in overall and prostate cancer-specific mortality associated with radical prostatectomy was restricted to men younger than 65 years. </li>

5912</ul>

5913</div>

5914</li>

5915<li>

5916The Prostate Intervention Versus Observation Trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00007644">

5917PIVOT-1</a>

5918 or VA-CSP-407) is a randomized trial conducted in the PSA screening era that directly compared radical prostatectomy with watchful waiting. From November 1994 through January 2002, 731 men aged 75 years or younger with localized prostate cancer (stage T1&#8211;2, NX, M0, with a blood PSA &lt;50 ng/mL) and a life expectancy of at least 10 years were randomly assigned to radical prostatectomy versus watchful waiting.[<a href="#cit/section_5.17">

591917</a>

5920-<a href="#cit/section_5.19">

592119</a>

5922][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5923Level of evidence A1</a>

5924] <div class="pdq-content-list">

5925<ul id="_2636">

5926<li>

5927About 50% of the men had palpable tumors.</li>

5928<li>

5929After a median follow-up of 12.7 years (range up to about 19.5 years), the all-cause mortality was 61.3% versus 66.8% in the radical-prostatectomy and watchful-waiting study arms, respectively, an absolute difference of 5.5 percentage points (95% CI -1.5 to 12.4) that was not statistically significant (HR, 0.84; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;1.01). Prostate cancer&#8211;specific mortality was 7.4% versus 11.4%, and it also was not statistically significant (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;1.02).

5930

5931</li>

5932<li>

5933 Although treatment for disease progression was given more frequently in the observation arm of the study, most such treatment was for asymptomatic, local, or biochemical (PSA) progression.</li>

5934<li>

5935 As expected, urinary incontinence and erectile/sexual dysfunction was more common in the prostatectomy group for at least 10 years of follow-up. Absolute differences in patient-reported use of absorbent urinary pads was greater in the surgery group by more than 30 percentage points at all time points for at least 10 years. Disease- or treatment-related limitations in activities of daily living were worse with surgery than with observation through 2 years, but then were similar in both study arms.</li>

5936</ul>

5937</div>

5938</li>

5939<li>

5940In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02044172">

5941ProtecT</a>

5942 trial (NCT02044172 and ISRCTN20141297), 82,429 men were screened with PSA testing, and 2,664 were diagnosed with clinically localized prostate cancer. Among those diagnosed, 1,643 men (median age 62 years, range 50&#8211;69 years) consented to a randomly assigned comparison of active monitoring, radical prostatectomy (nerve-sparing when possible), or external-beam 3D conformal radiation (74 Gy in 37 fractions). The primary end point was prostate cancer-specific mortality.[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

594320</a>

5944]<div class="pdq-content-list">

5945<ol id="_2955" class="lower-alpha">

5946<li>

5947With a median follow-up of 10 years, there were a total of 17 deaths from prostate cancer, with no statistically significant differences among the three study arms (<em>

5948P</em>

5949 = .48). The 10-year prostate cancer&#8211;specific survival rates were 98.8% in the active monitoring arm, 99.0% in the radical prostatectomy arm, and 99.6% radiation therapy arms.[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

595020</a>

5951][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5952Level of evidence A1</a>

5953]</li>

5954<li>

5955Likewise, all-cause mortality was nearly identical in all three study arms: 10.9 deaths in the active monitoring arm, 10.1 in the radical prostatectomy arm, and 10.3 in the radiation therapy arm per 1,000 person-years (<em>

5956P</em>

5957 = .87).[<a href="#cit/section_5.20">

595820</a>

5959][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5960Level of evidence A1</a>

5961]</li>

5962<li>

5963There were statistically significant differences in progression to metastatic disease among the treatment arms (33 of 545 men in the active monitoring arm; 13 of 553 men in the radical prostatectomy arm; 16 of 545 men in the radiation therapy arm) that began to emerge after 4 years, but these differences had not translated into any difference in mortality after 10-years of follow-up. Over the course of 10 years, 52% of the patients required active intervention.</li>

5964<li>

5965As expected, there were substantial differences in patient-reported outcomes among the three management approaches.[<a href="#cit/section_5.21">

596621</a>

5967][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

5968Level of evidence A3</a>

5969] A substudy of patient-reported outcomes up to 6 years after randomization included the following: <div class="pdq-content-list">

5970<ul id="_2956">

5971<li>

5972Men in the radical prostatectomy study arm had substantial rates of urinary incontinence (e.g., using one or more absorbent pads qd was reported by 46% at 6 months and by 17% at year 6) with very little incontinence in the other two study arms.</li>

5973<li>

5974Sexual function was also worse in the radical prostatectomy group (e.g., at 6 months, 12% of men reported erections firm enough for intercourse vs. 22% in the radiation therapy arm and 52% in the active-monitoring arm). </li>

5975<li>

5976Bowel function, however, was worse in the radiation therapy arm (e.g., about 5% reported bloody stools at least half the time at 2 years and beyond versus none in the radical prostatectomy and active-monitoring study arms).</li>

5977</ul>

5978</div>

5979</li>

5980</ol>

5981</div>

5982</li>

5983</ol>

5984</div>

5985</section>

5986<section id="_1842">

5987<h4 id="_1842_toc">

5988External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</h4>

5989<p id="_1843" tabindex="-1">

5990EBRT is another treatment option often used with curative intent.[<a href="#cit/section_5.22">

599122</a>

5992-<a href="#cit/section_5.26">

599326</a>

5994] Definitive radiation therapy should be delayed 4 to 6 weeks after TURP to reduce the incidence of stricture.[<a href="#cit/section_5.27">

599527</a>

5996] Adjuvant hormonal therapy should be considered for patients with bulky T2b to T2c tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

599728</a>

5998]</p>

5999<p id="_2551" tabindex="-1">

6000The role of adjuvant hormonal therapy in patients with locally advanced disease has been analyzed by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (now the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality). Most patients had more advanced disease, but patients with bulky T2b to T2c tumors were included in the studies that were re-evaluating the role of adjuvant hormonal therapy in patients with locally advanced disease.</p>

6001<p id="_981" tabindex="-1">

6002Evidence (EBRT with or without adjuvant hormonal therapy):</p>

6003<div class="pdq-content-list">

6004<ol id="_2027">

6005<li>

6006The Radiation Therapy Oncology Group's (RTOG) trial 7706 (RTOG-7706).[<a href="#cit/section_5.29">

600729</a>

6008][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6009Level of evidence A1</a>

6010]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6011<ul id="_2593">

6012<li>

6013 Prophylactic radiation therapy to clinically or pathologically uninvolved pelvic lymph nodes does not appear to improve OS or prostate cancer-specific survival. </li>

6014</ul>

6015</div>

6016</li>

6017<li>

6018RTOG-9413 (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00769548">

6019RTOG-9413</a>

6020 [NCT00769548]) trial.[<a href="#cit/section_5.30">

602130</a>

6022,<a href="#cit/section_5.31">

602331</a>

6024][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6025Level of evidence B1</a>

6026]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6027<ul id="_2594">

6028<li>

6029Although RTOG-9413 showed increased progression-free survival at 4 years for patients who had a 15% estimated risk of lymph node involvement and received whole-pelvic radiation therapy compared with prostate-only radiation therapy, OS and PSA failure rates were not significantly different.</li>

6030</ul>

6031</div>

6032</li>

6033<li>

6034In a randomized trial, 875 men with locally advanced nonmetastatic prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;T2 moderately or poorly differentiated tumors; T3 tumors of any grade) were randomly assigned to receive 3 months of a luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonist plus long-term flutamide (250 mg PO tid) with or without EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.32">

603532</a>

6036][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6037Level of evidence A1</a>

6038]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6039<ul id="_2351">

6040<li>

6041Nineteen percent of the men had tumor stage T2, and 78% of the men had tumor stage T3. At 10 years, both overall mortality (29.6% vs. 39.4%; 95% CI for the difference, 0.8%&#8211;18.8%) and prostate cancer-specific mortality (11.9% vs. 23.9%; 95% CI for the difference, 4.9%&#8211;19.1%) favored combined hormonal and radiation therapy.</li>

6042<li>

6043Although flutamide might not be considered a standard hormonal monotherapy in the setting of T2 or T3 tumors, radiation therapy provided a disease-free survival or tumor-specific survival advantage even though this monotherapy was applied. This analysis rests on the assumption that flutamide does not shorten life expectancy and cancer-specific survival. Radiation therapy was not delivered by current standards of dose and technique.</li>

6044</ul>

6045</div>

6046</li>

6047<li>

6048Another trial compared androgen deprivation therapy (ADT: an LH-RH agonist or orchiectomy) with ADT plus radiation therapy (65&#8211;69 Gy to the prostate by 4-field box technique, including 45 Gy to the whole pelvis, seminal vesicles, and external/internal iliac nodes unless the lymph nodes were histologically negative). This trial, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002633">

6049NCIC CTG PR.3/MRC UKPRO7</a>

6050 [NCT00002633], from the National Cancer Institute of Canada randomly assigned 1,205 patients with high-risk (PSA &gt;40 ng/mL or PSA &gt;20 ng/mL and Gleason score &#8805;8), T2 (12%&#8211;13% of the patients), T3 (83% of the patients), and T4 (4%&#8211;5% of the patients) with clinical or pathologically staged N0, M0 disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.33">

605133</a>

6052,<a href="#cit/section_5.34">

605334</a>

6054][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6055Level of evidence A1</a>

6056]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6057<ul id="_2595">

6058<li>

6059At a median follow-up of 8 years (maximum, 13 years), OS was superior in the ADT-plus-radiation therapy group (HR<sub>

6060death,</sub>

6061 0.77; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.85, <em>

6062P</em>

6063 = .001). The OS rate at 10 years was 55% for the ADT-plus-radiation therapy group versus 49% for the ADT-alone group.</li>

6064<li>

6065Although radiation therapy had the expected bowel and urinary side effects, quality of life was the same in each study group by 24 months and beyond.[<a href="#cit/section_5.35">

606635</a>

6067]</li>

6068</ul>

6069</div>

6070</li>

6071<li>

6072A meta-analysis of randomized clinical trial evidence comparing radiation therapy with radiation therapy plus prolonged androgen suppression has been published. The meta-analysis found a difference in 5-year OS in favor of radiation therapy plus continued androgen suppression (LH-RH agonist or orchiectomy) as compared with radiation therapy alone (HR, 0.631; 95% CI, 0.479&#8211;0.831).[<a href="#cit/section_5.28">

607328</a>

6074][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6075Level of evidence A1</a>

6076]

6077</li>

6078<li>

6079In a randomized, prospective clinical trial, 18 months of androgen suppression with an LH-RH agonist appears to have provided results that were similar to 36 months with respect to OS and disease-specific survival.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

608036</a>

6081][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6082Level of evidence A1</a>

6083] In a multicenter trial, 630 men with stage II to stage IVA cancer (clinical stage T3&#8211;T4, or PSA &gt;20 ng/ml, or Gleason score &gt;7) received 70 Gy of radiation in 35 fractions plus a total of either 18 or 36 months of goserelin acetate.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6084<ul id="_3101">

6085<li>

6086 With a median follow-up of 9.4 years, OS was nearly identical in each study arm (62% at 10 years; HR<sub>

6087death</sub>

6088, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.29; <em>

6089P</em>

6090 = .8), as was prostate cancer&#8211;specific survival (HR<sub>

6091prostate death</sub>

6092, 0.95; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;0.55; <em>

6093P</em>

6094 = .8).</li>

6095<li>

6096 Global quality of life was nearly identical on both study arms, but sexual activity and interest in sex was moderately better in the 18-month arm.[<a href="#cit/section_5.36">

609736</a>

6098][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6099Level of evidence A3</a>

6100]</li>

6101</ul>

6102</div>

6103</li>

6104<li>

6105A meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials comparing early hormonal treatment (adjuvant or neoadjuvant) to deferred hormonal treatment (LH-RH agonists and/or antiandrogens) in patients with locally advanced prostate cancer, whether treated with prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring, showed improved overall mortality for patients receiving early treatment (RR, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.91).[<a href="#cit/section_5.37">

610637</a>

6107][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6108Level of evidence A1</a>

6109] </li>

6110<li>

6111Short-term neoadjuvant&#8722;androgen therapy administered before and during radiation therapy has shown benefit in at least some patients with clinically localized prostate cancer. In an open-label, randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002597">

6112RTOG-9408 </a>

6113 [NCT00002597]), 1,979 men with nonmetastatic stage T1b&#8211;c, T2a, or T2b tumors and a PSA level of 20 ng/mL or less were randomly assigned to receive radiation therapy (66.6 Gy prostate dose in 1.8 Gy daily fractions) with or without 4 months of ADT (flutamide 250 mg PO tid plus either monthly goserelin 3.6 mg subcutaneously (SQ) or leuprolide 7.5 mg intramuscularly), beginning 2 months before radiation therapy. Median follow-up was about 9 years.[<a href="#cit/section_5.38">

611438</a>

6115][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6116Level of evidence A1</a>

6117] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6118<ul id="_2596">

6119<li>

6120The 10-year OS rate was 57% in the radiation-only group versus 62% in the combined-therapy group (HR<sub>

6121death,</sub>

6122 1.17; 95% CI, 1.01&#8211;1.35; <em>

6123P</em>

6124 = .03).</li>

6125<li>

6126In a post-hoc analysis, there was no statistically significant interaction between the treatment effect and baseline-risk category of the patients. However, there appeared to be little, if any, benefit associated with combined therapy in the lowest-risk category of patients (Gleason score &#8804;6; PSA &#8804;10 ng/mL; and clinical stage &#8804;T2a).</li>

6127<li>

6128The OS benefit was most apparent in men with intermediate-risk tumors (Gleason score 7; or Gleason score &#8804;6 and PSA &gt;10 ng/mL; or clinical stage T2b).</li>

6129</ul>

6130</div>

6131</li>

6132<li>

6133The duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy has been tested in a randomized trial (TROG 96.01 [ACTRN12607000237482]) involving 818 men with locally advanced (T2b, T2c, T3, and T4) nonmetastatic cancer treated with radiation therapy (i.e., 66 Gy in 2 Gy daily fractions to the prostate and seminal vesicles but not including regional lymph nodes).[<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

613439</a>

6135] In an open-label design, patients were randomly assigned to receive radiation therapy alone, 3 months of neoadjuvant androgen deprivation therapy (NADT) (goserelin 3.6 mg SQ each month plus flutamide 250 mg PO tid) for 2 months before and during radiation, or 6 months of NADT for 5 months before and during radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_5.39">

613639</a>

6137][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6138Level of evidence A1</a>

6139]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6140<ul id="_2597">

6141<li>

6142After a median follow-up of 10.6 years, there were no statistically significant differences between the radiation-alone group and the radiation-plus-3-months-of NADT group.</li>

6143<li>

6144 However, the 6-month NADT arm showed better prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality and overall mortality than the radiation-alone group; 10-year all-cause mortality 29.2% versus 42.5% (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.83, <em>

6145P</em>

6146 = .0008).</li>

6147</ul>

6148</div>

6149</li>

6150<li>

6151The duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy was tested in another trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005044">

6152RTOG-9910</a>

6153 [NCT00005044]) of 1,489 eligible men with intermediate-risk prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 2&#8211;6, and PSA &gt;10 but &#8804;100 ng/mL; T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 7, and PSA &lt;20; or T1b&#8211;1c, Gleason score 8&#8211;10, and PSA &lt;20) and no evidence of metastases. The men were randomly assigned to receive short-course neoadjuvant&#8211;androgen suppression (an LH-RH agonist plus bicalutamide or flutamide for 8 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy) or long-course neoadjuvant&#8211;androgen suppression (28 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy). Both groups received 70.2 Gy radiation in 39 daily fractions to the prostate and 46.8 Gy to the iliac lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

615440</a>

6155][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6156Level of evidence A1</a>

6157] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6158<ul id="_2818">

6159<li>

6160After a median of 9.4 years, 10-year prostate-specific mortality, the primary end point, was low in both study arms: 5% versus 4% (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;1.39).[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

616140</a>

6162][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6163Level of evidence A1</a>

6164]</li>

6165<li>

6166 No statistically significant differences in overall mortality or in locoregional disease progression were found.[<a href="#cit/section_5.40">

616740</a>

6168][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6169Level of evidence A1</a>

6170]</li>

6171<li>

6172 There was also no apparent differential effect of androgen suppression duration among any of the risk-group subsets.</li>

6173</ul>

6174</div>

6175</li>

6176<li>

6177

6178

6179Addition of androgen suppression therapy to EBRT may benefit men who are at an elevated risk of disease recurrence and death from prostate cancer (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00767286">

6180RTOG-9202</a>

6181 [NCT00767286]). </li>

6182</ol>

6183</div>

6184</section>

6185<section id="_2357">

6186<h4 id="_2357_toc">

6187Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes</h4>

6188<p id="_2358" tabindex="-1">

6189Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes (i.e., iodine I 125 [125I], palladium, and iridium), using a transperineal technique with either ultrasound or computed tomography guidance,

6190is

6191being done in patients with T1 or T2a tumors. Short-term

6192results in these patients are similar to those for radical prostatectomy or

6193EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

619441</a>

6195,<a href="#cit/section_5.42">

619642</a>

6197]; [<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

619843</a>

6199][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6200Level of evidence C3</a>

6201] </p>

6202<p id="_2359" tabindex="-1">

6203Factors for consideration in the use of interstitial implants include the following:</p>

6204<div class="pdq-content-list">

6205<ul id="_2360">

6206<li>

6207The implant is performed as outpatient surgery.</li>

6208<li>

6209The rate of maintenance of sexual potency with interstitial implants has been reported to be 86% to 92%.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

621041</a>

6211,<a href="#cit/section_5.43">

621243</a>

6213] In contrast, rates of maintenance of sexual potency with radical prostatectomy were 10% to 40% and 40% to 60% with EBRT.</li>

6214<li>

6215Typical side effects from interstitial implants that are seen in most patients but subside with time include urinary tract frequency, urgency, and less commonly, urinary retention.</li>

6216<li>

6217 Rectal ulceration may also be seen.[<a href="#cit/section_5.41">

621841</a>

6219] In one series, a 10% 2-year actuarial genitourinary grade 2 complication rate and a 12% risk of rectal ulceration were seen. This risk decreased with increased operator experience and modification of the implant technique.[<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

622044</a>

6221]</li>

6222</ul>

6223</div>

6224<p id="_2361" tabindex="-1">

6225Long-term follow-up of these patients is necessary to assess treatment efficacy and side effects.</p>

6226<p id="_2362" tabindex="-1">

6227Retropubic freehand implantation with 125I has been associated with an increased local failure and complication rate [<a href="#cit/section_5.44">

622844</a>

6229,<a href="#cit/section_5.45">

623045</a>

6231] and is now rarely done.</p>

6232</section>

6233<section id="_3231">

6234<h4 id="_3231_toc">

6235Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</h4>

6236<p id="_3232" tabindex="-1">

6237Cryosurgery is a surgical technique that involves destruction of prostate

6238cancer cells by intermittent freezing of the prostate with cryoprobes followed by thawing.[<a href="#cit/section_5.46">

623946</a>

6240][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6241Level of evidence C1</a>

6242]; [<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

624347</a>

6244,<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

624548</a>

6246][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6247Level of evidence C3</a>

6248] Cryosurgery is less well

6249established than standard prostatectomy, and long-term outcomes are not as well established as with prostatectomy or radiation therapy.

6250Serious toxic effects include:</p>

6251<div class="pdq-content-list">

6252<ul id="_3233">

6253<li>

6254 Bladder outlet injury.</li>

6255<li>

6256Urinary incontinence.</li>

6257<li>

6258Sexual impotence.</li>

6259<li>

6260Rectal injury.</li>

6261</ul>

6262</div>

6263<p id="_3234" tabindex="-1">

6264The frequency of other side effects and the probability of cancer control at 5 years' follow-up have varied among reporting centers, and series are small compared with surgery and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_5.47">

626547</a>

6266,<a href="#cit/section_5.48">

626748</a>

6268]</p>

6269</section>

6270<section id="_3235">

6271<h4 id="_3235_toc">

6272High-intensity focused ultrasound</h4>

6273<p id="_3236" tabindex="-1">

6274High-intensity focused ultrasound has been reported in case series to produce good local disease control. However, it has not been directly compared with more standard therapies, and experience with it is more limited.[<a href="#cit/section_5.49">

627549</a>

6276-<a href="#cit/section_5.51">

627751</a>

6278]</p>

6279</section>

6280<section id="_3237">

6281<h4 id="_3237_toc">

6282Proton-beam radiation therapy</h4>

6283<p id="_3238" tabindex="-1">

6284There is growing interest in the use of proton-beam radiation therapy for the treatment of prostate cancer. Although the dose distribution of this form of charged-particle radiation has the potential to improve the therapeutic ratio of prostate radiation, allowing for an increase in dose to the tumor without a substantial increase in side effects, no randomized controlled trials have been reported that compare its efficacy and toxicity with those of other forms of radiation therapy. </p>

6285</section>

6286<section id="_3239">

6287<h4 id="_3239_toc">

6288Photodynamic therapy</h4>

6289<p id="_3240" tabindex="-1">

6290Vascular-targeted photodynamic therapy using a photosensitizing agent has been tested in men with low-risk prostate cancer. In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01310894">

6291CLIN1001 PCM301</a>

6292 (NCT01310894) randomized trial, 413 men with low-risk cancer (tumor stage T1&#8211;T2c, PSA &#8804;10 ng/mL, generally Gleason score 3 + 3) were randomly assigned in an open-label trial to receive either the photosensitizing agent, padeliporfin (4 mg/kg IV over 10 minutes, and optical fibers inserted into the target area of the prostate, then activated by 753 nm laser light at 150 mW/cm for 22 minutes 15 seconds), or active surveillance.[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

629352</a>

6294] Median time to local disease progression was 28.3 months for patients who received padeliporfin and 14.1 months for patients who were assigned to active surveillance (HR, 0.34; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.46; <em>

6295P</em>

6296 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_5.52">

629752</a>

6298][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6299Level of evidence B1</a>

6300] However, the appropriate population for photodynamic therapy may be quite narrow, as it may overtreat men with very low-risk disease and undertreat men with higher-risk disease.[<a href="#cit/section_5.53">

630153</a>

6302]</p>

6303</section>

6304</section>

6305<section id="_TrialSearch_69_sid_5">

6306<h3 id="_TrialSearch_69_sid_5_toc">

6307Current Clinical Trials</h3>

6308<p id="_TrialSearch_69_22" tabindex="-1">

6309Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

6310advanced clinical trial search</a>

6311 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

6312General information</a>

6313 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

6314</section>

Int J Radiat Oncol Biol Phys 40 (4): 769-82, 1998.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9531360&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=9531360&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6430[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6432<li id="section_5.30">

6433Roach M, DeSilvio M, Lawton C, et al.: Phase III trial comparing whole-pelvic versus prostate-only radiotherapy and neoadjuvant versus adjuvant combined androgen suppression: Radiation Therapy Oncology Group 9413. J Clin Oncol 21 (10): 1904-11, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743142&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743142&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6434[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6435</li>

6436<li id="section_5.31">

6437Pollack A: A call for more with a desire for less: pelvic radiotherapy with androgen deprivation in the treatment of prostate cancer. J Clin Oncol 21 (10): 1899-901, 2003.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743140&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=12743140&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6438[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6439</li>

6440<li id="section_5.32">

6441Widmark A, Klepp O, Solberg A, et al.: Endocrine treatment, with or without radiotherapy, in locally advanced prostate cancer (SPCG-7/SFUO-3): an open randomised phase III trial. Lancet 373 (9660): 301-8, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19091394&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19091394&amp;dopt=Abstract">

6442[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6446[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6450[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

6451</li>

6452<li id="section_5.35">

6453Brundage M, Sydes MR, Parulekar WR, et al.: Impact of Radiotherapy When Added to Androgen-Deprivation Therapy for Locally Advanced Prostate Cancer: Long-Term Quality-of-Life Outcomes From the NCIC CTG PR3/MRC PR07 Randomized Trial. 6454[PUBMED Abstract]</a>
