6529</div>

6530

6531 </section>

6532

6533

6534

6535 <section id="_70">

6536

6537 <h2>

6538Treatment of Stage III Prostate Cancer</h2>

6539

6540 <div id="_section_70" class="pdq-sections">

6541<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

6542<h6>

6543In This Section</h6>

6544<ul>

6545<li>

6546<a href="#_697_toc">

6547Overview</a>

6548</li>

6549<li>

6550<a href="#_699_toc">

6551Treatment Options for Stage III Prostate Cancer<ul>

6552<li>

6553<a href="#_1848_toc">

6554External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

6555</li>

6556<li>

6557<a href="#_1850_toc">

6558Hormonal manipulations (with or without radiation therapy) </a>

6559</li>

6560<li>

6561<a href="#_1852_toc">

6562Radical prostatectomy with or without EBRT</a>

6563</li>

6564<li>

6565<a href="#_1854_toc">

6566Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

6567</li>

6568</ul>

6569</a>

6570</li>

6571<li>

6572<a href="#_1824_toc">

6573Treatment of Symptoms <ul>

6574<li>

6575<a href="#_3190_toc">

6576Radiation therapy</a>

6577</li>

6578<li>

6579<a href="#_3192_toc">

6580Hormonal manipulation</a>

6581</li>

6582<li>

6583<a href="#_3197_toc">

6584Interstitial implantation combined with EBRT</a>

6585</li>

6586<li>

6587<a href="#_3199_toc">

6588Alternative forms of radiation therapy</a>

6589</li>

6590<li>

6591<a href="#_3203_toc">

6592Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</a>

6593</li>

6594</ul>

6595</a>

6596</li>

6597<li>

6598<a href="#_TrialSearch_70_sid_6_toc">

6599Current Clinical Trials</a>

6600</li>

6601</ul>

6602</nav>

6603<section id="_697">

6604<h3 id="_697_toc">

6605Overview</h3>

6606<p id="_698" tabindex="-1">

6607Stage III prostate cancer is defined by the American Joint Committee on Cancer's TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification system:[<a href="#cit/section_6.1">

66081</a>

6609]</p>

6610<p id="_3092" tabindex="-1">

6611<strong>

6612Stage IIIA</strong>

6613</p>

6614<div class="pdq-content-list">

6615<ul id="_3093">

6616<li>

6617T1&#8211;2, N0, M0, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) &#8805;20, Gleason &#8804;6&#8211;8.</li>

6618</ul>

6619</div>

6620<p id="_3094" tabindex="-1">

6621<strong>

6622Stage IIIB</strong>

6623</p>

6624<div class="pdq-content-list">

6625<ul id="_3095">

6626<li>

6627T3&#8211;4, N0, M0, any PSA, Gleason &#8804;6&#8211;8.</li>

6628</ul>

6629</div>

6630<p id="_3096" tabindex="-1">

6631<strong>

6632Stage IIIC</strong>

6633</p>

6634<div class="pdq-content-list">

6635<ul id="_3097">

6636<li>

6637Any T, N0, M0, any PSA, Gleason 9 or 10.</li>

6638</ul>

6639</div>

6640<p id="_1580" tabindex="-1">

6641Extraprostatic extension with microscopic bladder neck invasion (T4) is included with T3a.</p>

6642<p id="_2619" tabindex="-1">

6643External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT), interstitial implantation of radioisotopes, and radical prostatectomy are used to treat stage III prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.2">

66442</a>

6645] Prognosis is greatly affected by whether regional lymph nodes are evaluated and proven not to be involved.</p>

6646<p id="_2364" tabindex="-1">

6647 EBRT using a linear accelerator is the most common treatment for patients with stage III prostate cancer, and large series support its success in achieving local disease control and disease-free survival (DFS).[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

66483</a>

6649,<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

66504</a>

6651] The results of radical prostatectomy in stage III patients are greatly inferior compared with results in patients with stage II cancer. Interstitial implantation of radioisotopes is technically difficult in large tumors.</p>

6652<p id="_2598" tabindex="-1">

6653The patient&#8217;s symptoms related to cancer, age, and coexisting medical illnesses should be considered before deciding on a therapeutic plan. In a series of 372 patients treated with radiation therapy and followed for 20 years, 47% eventually died of prostate cancer, but 44% died of intercurrent illnesses without evidence of prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.4">

66544</a>

6655]</p>

6656</section>

6657<section id="_699">

6658<h3 id="_699_toc">

6659Treatment Options for Stage III Prostate Cancer</h3>

6660<p id="_1823" tabindex="-1">

6661 Treatment options for patients with <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_70">

6662stage III prostate cancer</a>

6663 include the following:</p>

6664<div class="pdq-content-list">

6665<ol id="_1233">

6666<li>

6667<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1848">

6668External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

6669.</li>

6670<li>

6671<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1850">

6672Hormonal manipulations (with or without radiation therapy)</a>

6673.</li>

6674<li>

6675<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1852">

6676Radical prostatectomy with or without EBRT</a>

6677.</li>

6678<li>

6679<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1854">

6680Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

6681.</li>

6682</ol>

6683</div>

6684<section id="_1848">

6685<h4 id="_1848_toc">

6686External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</h4>

6687<p id="_1849" tabindex="-1">

6688EBRT alone,[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

66893</a>

6690-<a href="#cit/section_6.7">

66917</a>

6692] luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonist, or orchiectomy, in addition to EBRT, should be considered.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

66938</a>

6694-<a href="#cit/section_6.16">

669516</a>

6696] Definitive radiation therapy should be delayed until 4 to 6 weeks after transurethral resection to reduce the incidence of stricture.[<a href="#cit/section_6.17">

669717</a>

6698]</p>

6699<p id="_2599" tabindex="-1">

6700Hormonal therapy should be considered in conjunction with radiation therapy especially in men who do not have underlying moderate or severe comorbidities.[<a href="#cit/section_6.8">

67018</a>

6702,<a href="#cit/section_6.9">

67039</a>

6704] Several studies have investigated its use in patients with locally advanced disease. </p>

6705<p id="_1016" tabindex="-1">

6706Evidence (EBRT with or without hormonal therapy): </p>

6707<div class="pdq-content-list">

6708<ol id="_2045">

6709<li>

6710Although patients in the Radiation Therapy Oncology Group (RTOG) <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00769548">

6711RTOG-9413</a>

6712 trial (NCT00769548) showed a 15% estimated risk of lymph node involvement and received whole-pelvic radiation therapy compared with prostate-only radiation therapy, overall survival (OS) and PSA failure rates were not significantly different.[<a href="#cit/section_6.18">

671318</a>

6714]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.19">

671519</a>

6716][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6717Level of evidence B1</a>

6718] </li>

6719<li>

6720In a randomized trial, 875 men with locally advanced nonmetastatic prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;T2 moderately or poorly differentiated tumors; T3 tumors of any grade) were randomly assigned to receive 3 months of an LH-RH agonist plus long-term flutamide (250 mg PO tid) with or without EBRT. Nineteen percent of the men had tumor stage T2, and 78% of the men had stage T3.[<a href="#cit/section_6.20">

672120</a>

6722][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6723Level of evidence A1</a>

6724]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6725<ul id="_2370">

6726<li>

6727At 10 years, both overall mortality (29.6% vs. 39.4%; 95% confidence interval [CI] for the difference, 0.8%&#8211;8.8%) and the prostate cancer-specific mortality (11.9% vs. 23.9%; 95% CI for the difference, 4.9%&#8211;19.1%) favored combined hormonal and radiation therapy.</li>

6728<li>

6729Although flutamide might not be considered a standard hormonal monotherapy in the setting of T2 or T3 tumors, radiation therapy provided a DFS or tumor-specific survival advantage even though this monotherapy was applied. This analysis rests on the assumption that flutamide does not shorten life expectancy and cancer-specific survival. Radiation therapy was not delivered by current standards of dose and technique.</li>

6730</ul>

6731</div>

6732 </li>

6733<li>

6734Another trial compared androgen deprivation therapy (ADT: an LH-RH agonist or orchiectomy) to ADT plus radiation therapy (65&#8211;69 Gy to the prostate by 4-field box technique, including 45 Gy to the whole pelvis, seminal vesicles, and external/internal iliac nodes unless the lymph nodes were histologically negative). This trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002633">

6735NCIC CTG PR.3/MRC UKPRO7</a>

6736 [NCT00002633]) from the National Cancer Institute of Canada, randomly assigned 1,205 patients with high-risk (PSA &gt;40 ng/mL or PSA &gt;20 ng/mL and Gleason score &#8805;8), T2 (12%&#8211;13% of the patients), T3 (83% of the patients), and T4 (4%&#8211;5% of the patients) with clinical or pathologically staged N0, M0 disease.[<a href="#cit/section_6.21">

673721</a>

6738,<a href="#cit/section_6.22">

673922</a>

6740][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6741Level of evidence A1</a>

6742] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6743<ul id="_2600">

6744<li>

6745At a median follow-up of 8 years (maximum, 13 years), OS was superior in the ADT-plus-radiation therapy group (hazard ratio [HR]<sub>

6746death</sub>

6747, 0.77; 95% CI, 0.57&#8211;0.85, <em>

6748P</em>

6749 = .001). The OS rate at 10 years was 55% for the ADT-plus-radiation therapy group versus 49% for the ADT-alone group.</li>

6750<li>

6751Although radiation therapy had the expected bowel and urinary side effects, quality of life (QOL) was the same in each study group by 24 months and beyond.[<a href="#cit/section_6.23">

675223</a>

6753]</li>

6754</ul>

6755</div>

6756</li>

6757<li>

6758The RTOG performed a prospective randomized trial (RTOG-8531) in patients with T3, N0, or any T, N1, M0 disease who received prostatic and pelvic radiation therapy and then were randomly assigned to receive immediate adjuvant goserelin or observation with administration of goserelin at time of relapse. In patients assigned to receive adjuvant goserelin, the drug was started during the last week of the radiation therapy course and was continued indefinitely or until signs of progression.[<a href="#cit/section_6.24">

675924</a>

6760][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6761Level of evidence A1</a>

6762] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6763<ul id="_2512">

6764<li>

6765The actuarial 10-year OS rate for the entire population of 945 analyzable patients was 49% on the adjuvant arm versus 39% on the observation arm (<em>

6766P</em>

6767 = .002). There was also an improved actuarial 10-year local failure rate (23% vs. 38%, <em>

6768P</em>

6769 &lt; .001).</li>

6770</ul>

6771</div>

6772</li>

6773<li>

6774A similar trial was performed by the European Organisation for Research and Treatment of Cancer (EORTC). Patients with T1, T2 (World Health Organization grade 3), N0&#8211;NX or T3, T4, N0 disease were randomly assigned to receive either pelvic/prostate radiation therapy or identical radiation therapy and adjuvant goserelin (with cyproterone acetate for 1 month) starting with radiation therapy and continuing for 3 years. The 401 patients available for analysis were followed for a median of 9.1 years.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

677510</a>

6776,<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

677725</a>

6778][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6779A1</a>

6780 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6781B1</a>

6782] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6783<ul id="_2368">

6784<li>

6785The Kaplan-Meier estimates of OS rates at 10 years were 58.1% in the adjuvant goserelin arm and 39.8% in the radiation alone arm (<em>

6786P</em>

6787 = .0004). Similarly, 10-year DFS rates (47.7% vs. 22.7%, <em>

6788P</em>

6789 &lt; .0001) and local control rates (94.0% vs. 76.5%, <em>

6790P</em>

6791 &lt; .001) favored the adjuvant arm.[<a href="#cit/section_6.10">

679210</a>

6793,<a href="#cit/section_6.25">

679425</a>

6795]</li>

6796<li>

6797Two smaller studies, with 78 and 91 patients each, have shown similar results.[<a href="#cit/section_6.26">

679826</a>

6799,<a href="#cit/section_6.27">

680027</a>

6801]

6802</li>

6803</ul>

6804</div>

6805</li>

6806<li>

6807The role of adjuvant hormonal therapy in patients with locally advanced disease has been analyzed by the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (AHCPR; now the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality). Randomized clinical trial evidence comparing radiation therapy with radiation therapy with prolonged androgen suppression (with an LH-RH agonist or orchiectomy) was evaluated in a meta-analysis. Most patients had more advanced disease, but patients with bulky T2b tumors were included in the study.[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

680811</a>

6809][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6810Level of evidence A1</a>

6811] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6812<ul id="_2369">

6813<li>

6814The meta-analysis found a difference in 5-year OS in favor of radiation therapy plus continued androgen suppression compared with radiation therapy alone (HR, 0.631; 95% CI, 0.479&#8211;0.831).[<a href="#cit/section_6.11">

681511</a>

6816]</li>

6817</ul>

6818</div>

6819</li>

6820<li>

6821 Additionally, the RTOG did a study (RTOG-8610) in patients with bulky local disease (T2b, T2c, T3, or T4), with or without nodal involvement below the common iliac chain: 456 men were randomly assigned to receive either radiation therapy alone or radiation therapy with androgen ablation, which was started 8 weeks before radiation therapy and continued for 16 weeks. This trial assessed only short-term hormonal therapy, not long-term therapy, as the studies analyzed by the AHCPR did.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

682212</a>

6823,<a href="#cit/section_6.28">

682428</a>

6825]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6826<ul id="_2372">

6827<li>

6828At 10 years, OS was not statistically significantly different; however, disease-specific mortality rates (23% vs. 36%) and DFS rates (11% vs. 3%) favored the combined treatment arm.[<a href="#cit/section_6.12">

682912</a>

6830][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6831Level of evidence A1</a>

6832]</li>

6833</ul>

6834</div>

6835 </li>

6836<li>

6837 A subset analysis of the RTOG-8610 trial and the RTOG-8531 trial that involved 575 patients with T3, N0, M0 disease indicated that long-term hormones compared with short-term hormones resulted in improved biochemical DFS and cause-specific survival.[<a href="#cit/section_6.29">

683829</a>

6839] </li>

6840<li>

6841This finding was confirmed by <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00767286">

6842RTOG-9202</a>

6843 (NCT00767286), which reported that radiation therapy plus 28 months of androgen deprivation resulted in longer 10-year disease-specific survival rates (23% vs. 13%; <em>

6844P</em>

6845 &lt; .0001) but not OS rates (53.9% vs. 51.6%; <em>

6846P</em>

6847 = .36).[<a href="#cit/section_6.13">

684813</a>

6849]<div class="pdq-content-list">

6850<ul id="_2601">

6851<li>

6852An unplanned post-hoc subgroup analysis found increased OS with longer androgen deprivation (28 months vs. 4 months) (45% vs. 32%; <em>

6853P</em>

6854 = .0061) in men with high-grade cancers and Gleason scores of 8 through 10.</li>

6855</ul>

6856</div>

6857</li>

6858<li>

6859 In a randomized, prospective clinical trial, 18 months of androgen suppression with an LH-RH agonist appears to have provided results that were similar to 36 months with respect to OS and disease-specific survival.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

686030</a>

6861][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6862Level of evidence A1</a>

6863] In the trial, 630 men with stage II to stage IVA cancer (clinical stage T3&#8211;T4, or PSA &gt;20 ng/ml, or Gleason score &gt;7) received 70 Gy of radiation in 35 fractions alone plus a total of either 18 or 36 months of goserelin acetate.<div class="pdq-content-list">

6864<ul id="_3078">

6865<li>

6866 With a median follow-up of 9.4 years, OS was nearly identical in each study arm (62% at 10 years; HR<sub>

6867death</sub>

6868, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.29, <em>

6869P</em>

6870 = .8), as was prostate cancer&#8211;specific survival (HR<sub>

6871prostate death</sub>

6872, 0.95; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;1.55, <em>

6873P</em>

6874 = .8).</li>

6875<li>

6876 Global quality of life was nearly identical on both study arms, but sexual activity and interest in sex was moderately better in the 18-month arm.[<a href="#cit/section_6.30">

687730</a>

6878][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6879Level of evidence A3</a>

6880]</li>

6881</ul>

6882</div>

6883</li>

6884<li>

6885Likewise, a meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials comparing early hormonal treatment (adjuvant or neoadjuvant) with deferred hormonal treatment (LH-RH agonists and/or antiandrogens) in patients with locally advanced prostate cancer, whether treated by prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring, showed improved overall mortality for patients receiving early treatment (relative risk, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.91).[<a href="#cit/section_6.31">

688631</a>

6887][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6888Level of evidence A1</a>

6889]</li>

6890<li>

6891The duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy has been tested in a randomized trial (TROG 96.01 [ACTRN12607000237482]) involving 818 men with locally advanced (T2b, T2c, T3, and T4) nonmetastatic cancer treated with radiation therapy (i.e., 66 Gy in 2 Gy daily fractions to the prostate and seminal vesicles but not including regional lymph nodes). In an open-label design, patients were randomly assigned to radiation therapy alone, 3 months of neoadjuvant androgen deprivation therapy (NADT) (goserelin 3.6 mg subcutaneously each month plus flutamide 250 mg PO tid) for 2 months before and during radiation, or 6 months of NADT for 5 months before and during radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.14">

689214</a>

6893][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6894Level of evidence A1</a>

6895] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6896<ul id="_2602">

6897<li>

6898After a median follow-up of 10.6 years, there were no statistically significant differences between the radiation-alone group and the radiation plus 3 months of NADT group.</li>

6899<li>

6900However, the 6-month NADT arm showed better prostate cancer-specific mortality and overall mortality than radiation alone; 10-year all-cause mortality 29.2% versus 42.5% (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.83, <em>

6901P</em>

6902 = .0008).</li>

6903</ul>

6904</div>

6905</li>

6906<li>

6907The duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy was tested in another trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005044">

6908RTOG-9910</a>

6909 [NCT00005044]) of 1,489 eligible men with intermediate-risk prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 2&#8211;6, and PSA &gt;10 but &#8804;100 ng/mL; T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 7, and PSA &lt;20; or T1b&#8211;1c, Gleason score 8&#8211;10, and PSA &lt;20) and no evidence of metastases. The men were randomly assigned to receive short-course neoadjuvant&#8211;androgen suppression (an LH-RH agonist plus bicalutamide or flutamide for 8 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy) or long-course neoadjuvant&#8211;androgen suppression (28 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy). Both groups received 70.2 Gy radiation in 39 daily fractions to the prostate and 46.8 Gy to the iliac lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

691032</a>

6911][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6912Level of evidence A1</a>

6913] <div class="pdq-content-list">

6914<ul id="_2819">

6915<li>

6916After a median of 9.4 years, 10-year prostate-specific mortality, the primary end point, was low in both study arms: 5% versus 4% (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;1.39).[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

691732</a>

6918][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6919Level of evidence A1</a>

6920]</li>

6921<li>

6922 No statistically significant differences in overall mortality or in locoregional disease progression were found.[<a href="#cit/section_6.32">

692332</a>

6924][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6925Level of evidence A1</a>

6926]</li>

6927<li>

6928 There was also no apparent differential effect of androgen suppression duration among any of the risk-group subsets.</li>

6929</ul>

6930</div>

6931</li>

6932</ol>

6933</div>

6934</section>

6935<section id="_1850">

6936<h4 id="_1850_toc">

6937Hormonal manipulations (with or without radiation therapy) </h4>

6938<p id="_1851" tabindex="-1">

6939Hormonal manipulations (orchiectomy or LH-RH agonists) may be used in the treatment of stage III prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

694033</a>

6941][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6942Level of evidence A1</a>

6943]

6944</p>

6945<p id="_3000" tabindex="-1">

6946 Some data suggest that the efficacy of orchiectomy or LH-RH agonists may be enhanced by the addition of abiraterone acetate in men with locally advanced tumors. In the randomized, open-label, <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00268476">

6947STAMPEDE</a>

6948 trial (NCT00268476) trial, 1,917 men (about 95% newly diagnosed; about 50% had metastatic disease and about 50% had locally advanced or node-positive disease) were treated with ADT alone or ADT plus abiraterone acetate (1,000 mg PO qd) and prednisolone (5 mg PO qd).[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

694934</a>

6950] Local radiation therapy was mandated after 6 to 9 months for men with node-negative nonmetastatic disease and optional for those with node-positive nonmetastatic disease. Hormone therapy was curtailed at 2 years or until progression. Radiation therapy was planned in about 40% of the study participants.</p>

6951<div class="pdq-content-list">

6952<ul id="_3001">

6953<li>

6954 With a median follow-up of 40 months, the 3-year OS rate was 83% in the abiraterone study group compared with 76% in the ADT-only study group (HR<sub>

6955death,</sub>

6956 0.63; 95% CI, 0.52&#8211;0.76; <em>

6957P</em>

6958 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_6.34">

695934</a>

6960][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6961Level of evidence A1</a>

6962] Although there was no clear evidence of heterogeneity in relative treatment differences in metastatic disease versus nonmetastatic disease, absolute differences were much smaller in men with nonmetastatic disease and not statistically significant, perhaps because of the short follow-up (HR<sub>

6963death</sub>

6964, 0.75; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;1.18). </li>

6965<li>

6966 The main additional differences in toxicity associated with abiraterone compared with ADT alone were hypertension (5% vs. 1%), mild increase in blood aminotransferase levels (6% vs. &lt;1%), and respiratory disorders (5% vs. 2%). </li>

6967</ul>

6968</div>

6969<p id="_2374" tabindex="-1">

6970Antiandrogen monotherapy has also been evaluated in men with locally advanced prostate cancer as an alternative to castration. </p>

6971<p id="_2964" tabindex="-1">

6972Evidence (nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy vs. surgical or medical castration):</p>

6973<div class="pdq-content-list">

6974<ol id="_2965">

6975<li>

6976 A systematic evidence review compared nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy with surgical or medical castration from 11 randomized trials in 3,060 men with locally advanced, metastatic, or recurrent disease after local therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

697735</a>

6978] Use of nonsteroidal antiandrogens as monotherapy decreased OS and increased the rate of clinical progression and treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_6.35">

697935</a>

6980][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6981Level of evidence A1</a>

6982] </li>

6983</ol>

6984</div>

6985<p id="_2375" tabindex="-1">

6986Evidence (orchiectomy vs. LH-RH agonist):</p>

6987<div class="pdq-content-list">

6988<ol id="_2376">

6989<li>

6990In a randomized equivalence study involving 480 men with locally advanced (T3 and T4) disease, those who were treated with castration had a median OS of 70 months, whereas those treated with bicalutamide (150 mg qd) had a median OS of 63.5 months (HR, 1.05; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.36); these results failed to meet the prespecified criteria for equivalence.[<a href="#cit/section_6.36">

699136</a>

6992][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

6993Level of evidence A1</a>

6994]</li>

6995</ol>

6996</div>

6997<section id="_2377">

6998<h5 id="_2377_toc">

6999Immediate versus deferred hormonal therapy</h5>

7000<p id="_2378" tabindex="-1">

7001In patients who are not candidates for or who are unwilling to undergo radical prostatectomy or radiation therapy, immediate hormonal therapy has been compared with deferred treatment (i.e., watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring with hormonal therapy at progression). </p>

7002<p id="_2379" tabindex="-1">

7003Evidence (immediate vs. deferred hormonal therapy):</p>

7004<div class="pdq-content-list">

7005<ol id="_2380">

7006<li>

7007A randomized trial looked at immediate hormonal treatment (orchiectomy or LH-RH agonist) versus deferred treatment in men with locally advanced or asymptomatic metastatic prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.33">

700833</a>

7009][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7010Level of evidence A1</a>

7011]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7012<ul id="_2381">

7013<li>

7014 Initial results showed better OS and prostate cancer-specific survival with the immediate treatment. This subsequently lost statistical significance as was recorded in abstract form.[<a href="#cit/section_6.37">

701537</a>

7016] </li>

7017<li>

7018The incidence of pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and ureteric obstruction were also lower in the immediate treatment arm. </li>

7019</ul>

7020</div>

7021</li>

7022<li>

7023In another trial, 197 men with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer were randomly assigned to receive bilateral orchiectomy at diagnosis or at the time of symptomatic progression (or at the time of new metastases that were deemed likely to cause symptoms).[<a href="#cit/section_6.38">

702438</a>

7025][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7026Level of evidence A1</a>

7027]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7028<ul id="_2382">

7029<li>

7030No statistically significant difference in OS was seen over a 12-year period of follow-up.</li>

7031</ul>

7032</div>

7033</li>

7034<li>

7035In the <a href="https://www.eortc.org/research_field/clinical-detail/30891/" title="https://www.eortc.org/research_field/clinical-detail/30891/">

7036EORTC-30891</a>

7037 trial (NCT01819285), 985 patients newly diagnosed with prostate cancer, stage T0&#8211;4, N0&#8211;2, M0, and a median age of 73 years were randomly assigned to receive androgen deprivation, either immediately or on symptomatic disease progression. The study was designed to demonstrate the noninferiority of deferred treatment as compared with immediate treatment in relation to OS.[<a href="#cit/section_6.39">

703839</a>

7039][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7040Level of evidence A1</a>

7041]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7042<ul id="_2383">

7043<li>

7044At a median follow-up of 7.8 years, approximately 50% of the patients in the deferred treatment group had initiated androgen deprivation.</li>

7045<li>

7046The median OS in the immediate treatment group was 7.4 years, and, in the deferred treatment group, it was 6.5 years, corresponding to a mortality HR of 1.25 (95% CI, 1.05&#8211;1.48), which failed to meet the criteria for noninferiority.</li>

7047</ul>

7048</div>

7049</li>

7050</ol>

7051</div>

7052</section>

7053<section id="_2506">

7054<h5 id="_2506_toc">

7055Continuous versus intermittent hormonal therapy</h5>

7056<p id="_2507" tabindex="-1">

7057When used as the primary therapy for patients with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer, androgen suppression with hormonal therapy is usually given continuously until there is disease progression. Some investigators have proposed intermittent androgen suppression as a strategy to attain maximal tumor cytoreduction followed by a period without therapy to allow tumor repopulation by hormone-sensitive cells. Theoretically, this strategy might provide tumor hormone responsiveness for a longer period. An animal model suggested that intermittent androgen deprivation (IAD) could prolong the duration of androgen dependence of hormone-sensitive tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_6.40">

705840</a>

7059]</p>

7060<p id="_2553" tabindex="-1">

7061Evidence (continuous vs. intermittent hormonal therapy):</p>

7062<div class="pdq-content-list">

7063<ol id="_2554">

7064<li>

7065A systematic review of 15 randomized trials that compared continuous androgen deprivation versus IAD therapy for patients with advanced or recurrent prostate cancer found no significant difference in OS, which was reported in eight of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.11); prostate&#8211;cancer-specific survival, reported in five of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;1.19); or progression-free survival, reported in four of the trials (HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.05). The meta-analysis fulfilled prespecified criteria for noninferiority of OS (upper bound of 1.15 for the HR<sub>

7066death,</sub>

7067 1.15).[<a href="#cit/section_6.41">

706841</a>

7069][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7070Level of evidence A1</a>

7071] However, of the 15 trials, all but one had an unclear or high risk of bias according to prespecified criteria.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7072<ul id="_2845">

7073<li>

7074 There was minimal difference in patient-reported QOL, but most trials found better physical and sexual functioning in patients in the IAD arms.</li>

7075</ul>

7076</div>

7077</li>

7078</ol>

7079</div>

7080</section>

7081</section>

7082<section id="_1852">

7083<h4 id="_1852_toc">

7084Radical prostatectomy with or without EBRT</h4>

7085<p id="_1853" tabindex="-1">

7086Radical prostatectomy may be used with or without EBRT (in highly selected

7087patients).[<a href="#cit/section_6.42">

708842</a>

7089] Because about 40% to 50% of men with clinically organ-confined disease are found to have pathological extension beyond the prostate capsule or surgical margins, the role of postprostatectomy adjuvant radiation therapy has been studied.</p>

7090<p id="_1019" tabindex="-1">

7091Evidence (radical prostatectomy with or without EBRT): </p>

7092<div class="pdq-content-list">

7093<ol id="_2047">

7094<li>

7095In a randomized trial of 425 men with pathological T3, N0, M0 disease, postsurgical EBRT (60&#8211;64 Gy to the prostatic fossa over 30&#8211;32 fractions) was compared with observation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.43">

709643</a>

7097,<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

709844</a>

7099]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7100<ul id="_2384">

7101<li>

7102After a median follow-up of about 12.5 years, OS was better in the radiation therapy arm; HR<sub>

7103death</sub>

7104, 0.72 (95% CI, 0.55&#8211;0.96; <em>

7105P</em>

7106 = .023). The 10-year estimated survival rates were 74% in the radiation therapy arm and 66% in the control arm.</li>

7107<li>

7108The 10-year estimated metastasis-free survival rates were 73% and 65% (<em>

7109P</em>

7110 = .016).[<a href="#cit/section_6.44">

711144</a>

7112][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7113Level of evidence A1</a>

7114]</li>

7115<li>

7116Short-term complication rates were substantially higher in the radiation therapy group: overall complications were 23.8% versus 11.9%, rectal complications were 3.3% versus 0%, and urethral stricture was 17.8% versus 9.5%.</li>

7117<li>

7118The role of

7119preoperative (neoadjuvant) hormonal therapy is not established.[<a href="#cit/section_6.45">

712045</a>

7121,<a href="#cit/section_6.46">

712246</a>

7123] Also, the morphologic changes induced by neoadjuvant androgen

7124ablation may even complicate assessment of surgical margins and capsular

7125involvement.[<a href="#cit/section_6.47">

712647</a>

7127]</li>

7128</ul>

7129</div>

7130</li>

7131</ol>

7132</div>

7133</section>

7134<section id="_1854">

7135<h4 id="_1854_toc">

7136Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</h4>

7137<p id="_1855" tabindex="-1">

7138Careful observation without further immediate treatment may be used in the treatment of stage III prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_6.48">

713948</a>

7140,<a href="#cit/section_6.49">

714149</a>

7142]</p>

7143<p id="_2510" tabindex="-1">

7144Asymptomatic patients of advanced age or with concomitant illness may warrant consideration of careful observation without immediate active treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_6.50">

714550</a>

7146-<a href="#cit/section_6.52">

714752</a>

7148] Watch and wait, observation, expectant management, and active surveillance/active monitoring are terms indicating a strategy that does not employ <em>

7149immediate</em>

7150 therapy with curative intent. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_62">

7151Treatment Option Overview for Prostate Cancer</a>

7152 section.</p>

7153</section>

7154</section>

7155<section id="_1824">

7156<h3 id="_1824_toc">

7157Treatment of Symptoms </h3>

7158<p id="_1825" tabindex="-1">

7159Because many stage III patients have urinary symptoms, control of symptoms is an

7160important consideration in treatment. The following modalities may be used to improve local control of disease and subsequent symptoms:</p>

7161<div class="pdq-content-list">

7162<ul id="_2385">

7163<li>

7164<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3190">

7165Radiation therapy</a>

7166.</li>

7167<li>

7168<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3192">

7169Hormonal manipulation</a>

7170.</li>

7171<li>

7172Palliative surgery (transurethral resection of the prostate [TURP]).</li>

7173<li>

7174<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3197">

7175Interstitial implantation combined with EBRT</a>

7176.</li>

7177<li>

7178<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3199">

7179Alternative forms of radiation therapy</a>

7180 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

7181<li>

7182<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3203">

7183Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</a>

7184 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

7185</ul>

7186</div>

7187<section id="_3190">

7188<h4 id="_3190_toc">

7189Radiation therapy</h4>

7190<p id="_3191" tabindex="-1">

7191Radiation therapy may be used.[<a href="#cit/section_6.3">

71923</a>

7193-<a href="#cit/section_6.6">

71946</a>

7195] EBRT designed to

7196decrease exposure of normal tissues using methods such as computed tomography&#8211;based 3-dimensional conformal radiation therapy treatment planning is under clinical evaluation.</p>

7197</section>

7198<section id="_3192">

7199<h4 id="_3192_toc">

7200Hormonal manipulation</h4>

7201<p id="_3193" tabindex="-1">

7202Hormonal manipulations effectively used as <strong>

7203initial</strong>

7204 therapy for prostate cancer include the following:</p>

7205<div class="pdq-content-list">

7206<ul id="_3194">

7207<li>

7208Orchiectomy.</li>

7209<li>

7210Leuprolide or other LH-RH agonists (e.g., goserelin) in daily or depot

7211preparations. These agents may be associated with tumor flare.</li>

7212<li>

7213Estrogens (diethylstilbestrol [DES] is no longer available in the

7214United States).</li>

7215<li>

7216Nonsteroidal antiandrogens (e.g., flutamide, nilutamide,

7217and bicalutamide) or steroidal antiandrogen (e.g., cyproterone acetate).

7218</li>

7219</ul>

7220</div>

7221<p id="_3195" tabindex="-1">

7222A meta-analysis of randomized trials comparing various hormonal monotherapies

7223in men with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer (predominantly stage IV) came to

7224the following conclusions:[<a href="#cit/section_6.53">

722553</a>

7226][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7227Level of evidence A1</a>

7228]

7229</p>

7230<div class="pdq-content-list">

7231<ul id="_3196">

7232<li>

7233The OS at 2 years using any of the LH-RH agonists was

7234similar to treatment with orchiectomy or 3 mg qd of DES (HR, 1.26; 95% CI, 0.92&#8211;1.39).</li>

7235<li>

7236Survival rates at 2 years were similar or worse with nonsteroidal

7237antiandrogens compared with orchiectomy (HR, 1.22; 95%

7238CI, 0.99&#8211;1.50).</li>

7239<li>

7240Treatment withdrawals, used as a surrogate for adverse effects,

7241occurred less with LH-RH agonists (0%&#8211;4%) than with nonsteroidal

7242antiandrogens (4%&#8211;10%).</li>

7243</ul>

7244</div>

7245</section>

7246<section id="_3197">

7247<h4 id="_3197_toc">

7248Interstitial implantation combined with EBRT</h4>

7249<p id="_3198" tabindex="-1">

7250Interstitial implantation combined with EBRT is

7251being used in selected T3 patients, but little information is available.[<a href="#cit/section_6.54">

725254</a>

7253]</p>

7254</section>

7255<section id="_3199">

7256<h4 id="_3199_toc">

7257Alternative forms of radiation therapy</h4>

7258<p id="_3200" tabindex="-1">

7259Alternative forms of radiation therapy are being employed in clinical trials. </p>

7260<div class="pdq-content-list">

7261<ul id="_3201">

7262<li>

7263A

7264randomized trial from the RTOG reported improved local control and survival

7265with mixed-beam (neutron/photon) radiation therapy compared with standard photon

7266radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.55">

726755</a>

7268] </li>

7269<li>

7270A subsequent randomized study from the same group

7271compared fast-neutron radiation therapy with standard photon radiation therapy.

7272Local-regional control was improved with neutron treatment, but no difference in

7273 OS was seen, although follow-up was shorter in this trial.

7274Fewer complications were seen with the use of a multileaf collimator.[<a href="#cit/section_6.56">

727556</a>

7276] </li>

7277</ul>

7278</div>

7279<p id="_3202" tabindex="-1">

7280Proton-beam radiation therapy is also under investigation.[<a href="#cit/section_6.57">

728157</a>

7282]</p>

7283</section>

7284<section id="_3203">

7285<h4 id="_3203_toc">

7286Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery</h4>

7287<p id="_3204" tabindex="-1">

7288Ultrasound-guided percutaneous cryosurgery is under clinical evaluation. </p>

7289<p id="_3205" tabindex="-1">

7290Cryosurgery is a surgical technique under development that involves destruction of prostate

7291cancer cells by intermittent freezing of the prostate with cryoprobes,

7292followed by thawing.[<a href="#cit/section_6.58">

729358</a>

7294][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810035&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7295Level of evidence C1</a>

7296]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

729759</a>

7298]; [<a href="#cit/section_6.60">

729960</a>

7300][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810039&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7301Level of evidence C3</a>

7302] Cryosurgery is less well

7303established than standard prostatectomy, and long-term outcomes are not as well established as with prostatectomy or radiation therapy.

7304Serious toxic effects include bladder outlet injury, urinary incontinence, sexual impotence, and rectal injury. The technique of cryosurgery is under

7305development. Impotence is common. The frequency of other side effects and the probability of cancer control after 5 years of follow-up have varied among reporting centers, and series are small compared with surgery and radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_6.59">

730659</a>

7307,<a href="#cit/section_6.60">

730860</a>

7309]</p>

7310</section>

7311</section>

7312<section id="_TrialSearch_70_sid_6">

7313<h3 id="_TrialSearch_70_sid_6_toc">

7314Current Clinical Trials</h3>

7315<p id="_TrialSearch_70_22" tabindex="-1">

7316Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

7317advanced clinical trial search</a>

7318 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

7319General information</a>

7320 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

7321</section>

7399[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7400</li>

7401<li id="section_6.21">

7402Warde P, Mason M, Ding K, et al.: Combined androgen deprivation therapy and radiation therapy for locally advanced prostate cancer: a randomised, phase 3 trial. Lancet 378 (9809): 2104-11, 2011.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22056152&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=22056152&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7403[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7404</li>

7405<li id="section_6.22">

7406Mason MD, Parulekar WR, Sydes MR, et al.: Final Report of the Intergroup Randomized Study of Combined Androgen-Deprivation Therapy Plus Radiotherapy Versus Androgen-Deprivation Therapy Alone in Locally Advanced Prostate Cancer. J Clin Oncol 33 (19): 2143-50, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25691677&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=25691677&amp;dopt=Abstract">

7407[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

7408</li>

7409<li id="section_6.23">
