7566 <section id="_71">

7567

7568 <h2>

7569Treatment of Stage IV Prostate Cancer</h2>

7570

7571 <div id="_section_71" class="pdq-sections">

7572<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

7573<h6>

7574In This Section</h6>

7575<ul>

7576<li>

7577<a href="#_798_toc">

7578Overview</a>

7579</li>

7580<li>

7581<a href="#_808_toc">

7582Treatment Options for Stage IV Prostate Cancer <ul>

7583<li>

7584<a href="#_1869_toc">

7585 Hormonal manipulations</a>

7586</li>

7587<li>

7588<a href="#_2938_toc">

7589Hormonal manipulations with chemotherapy</a>

7590</li>

7591<li>

7592<a href="#_2429_toc">

7593Bisphosphonates</a>

7594</li>

7595<li>

7596<a href="#_1871_toc">

7597External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

7598</li>

7599<li>

7600<a href="#_1873_toc">

7601Palliative radiation therapy</a>

7602</li>

7603<li>

7604<a href="#_1875_toc">

7605 Palliative surgery with transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)</a>

7606</li>

7607<li>

7608<a href="#_1876_toc">

7609Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

7610</li>

7611<li>

7612<a href="#_3243_toc">

7613Radical prostatectomy with immediate orchiectomy</a>

7614</li>

7615</ul>

7616</a>

7617</li>

7618<li>

7619<a href="#_TrialSearch_71_sid_7_toc">

7620Current Clinical Trials</a>

7621</li>

7622</ul>

7623</nav>

7624<section id="_798">

7625<h3 id="_798_toc">

7626Overview</h3>

7627<p id="_799" tabindex="-1">

7628Stage IV prostate cancer is defined by the American Joint Committee on Cancer's TNM (tumor, node, metastasis) classification system:[<a href="#cit/section_7.1">

76291</a>

7630]</p>

7631<p id="_3098" tabindex="-1">

7632<strong>

7633Stage IVA</strong>

7634</p>

7635<div class="pdq-content-list">

7636<ul id="_800">

7637<li>

7638Any T, N1, M0, any prostate-specific antigen (PSA), any Gleason.</li>

7639</ul>

7640</div>

7641<p id="_3099" tabindex="-1">

7642<strong>

7643Stage IVB</strong>

7644</p>

7645<div class="pdq-content-list">

7646<ul id="_3100">

7647<li>

7648Any T, N0, M1, any PSA, any Gleason.</li>

7649</ul>

7650</div>

7651<p id="_1707" tabindex="-1">

7652Extraprostatic extension with microscopic bladder neck invasion (T4) is included with T3a.</p>

7653<p id="_2603" tabindex="-1">

7654Treatment selection depends on the following factors:</p>

7655<div class="pdq-content-list">

7656<ul id="_2604">

7657<li>

7658Age.</li>

7659<li>

7660Coexisting medical illnesses.</li>

7661<li>

7662Symptoms.</li>

7663<li>

7664The presence of distant metastases (most often bone) or regional lymph node involvement only.</li>

7665</ul>

7666</div>

7667<p id="_2393" tabindex="-1">

7668The most common symptoms originate from the urinary tract or from bone metastases. Palliation of symptoms from the urinary tract with transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) or radiation therapy and palliation of symptoms from bone metastases with radiation therapy or hormonal therapy are an important part of the management of these patients. Bisphosphonates may also be used for the management of bone metastases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.2">

76692</a>

7670]</p>

7671</section>

7672<section id="_808">

7673<h3 id="_808_toc">

7674Treatment Options for Stage IV Prostate Cancer </h3>

7675<p id="_1827" tabindex="-1">

7676Treatment options for patients with <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_71">

7677stage IV prostate cancer </a>

7678 include the following:</p>

7679<div class="pdq-content-list">

7680<ol id="_1226">

7681<li>

7682<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1869">

7683Hormonal manipulations</a>

7684.</li>

7685<li>

7686<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2938">

7687Hormonal manipulations with chemotherapy.</a>

7688</li>

7689<li>

7690<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2429">

7691Bisphosphonates</a>

7692.</li>

7693<li>

7694<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1871">

7695External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</a>

7696.</li>

7697<li>

7698<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1873">

7699Palliative radiation therapy</a>

7700.</li>

7701<li>

7702<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1875">

7703Palliative surgery with TURP</a>

7704.</li>

7705<li>

7706<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_1876">

7707Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</a>

7708.</li>

7709<li>

7710<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3243">

7711Radical prostatectomy with immediate orchiectomy</a>

7712 (under clinical evaluation).</li>

7713</ol>

7714</div>

7715<section id="_1869">

7716<h4 id="_1869_toc">

7717 Hormonal manipulations</h4>

7718<p id="_2394" tabindex="-1">

7719Hormonal treatment is the mainstay of therapy for metastatic prostate cancer. Cure is rarely, if ever, possible, but striking subjective or objective responses to treatment occur in most patients. The cornerstone of hormonal therapy for prostate cancer is medical or surgical castration to stop the production of testosterone by the testes. This is commonly referred to as androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and can be achieved with bilateral orchiectomy or with administration of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists or antagonists. The most effective purely hormonal approach employs a combination of ADT and one of the following agents: </p>

7720<div class="pdq-content-list">

7721<ul id="_3147">

7722<li>

7723Abiraterone acetate, an inhibitor of cytochrome P450c17, a critical enzyme in androgen biosynthesis. </li>

7724<li>

7725Apalutamide, an androgen receptor antagonist. </li>

7726<li>

7727Enzalutamide, an androgen receptor antagonist. </li>

7728</ul>

7729</div>

7730<p id="_3148" tabindex="-1">

7731Randomized controlled trials have reported that combination therapy with any one of these drugs plus ADT results in longer overall survival than does ADT alone. </p>

7732<div class="pdq-content-list">

7733<ol id="_3002">

7734<li>

7735 In the randomized double-blind <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01715285">

7736LATITUDE</a>

7737 trial (NCT01715285), 1,199 men with high-risk metastatic castration-sensitive prostate cancer were given ADT plus either abiraterone acetate (1,000 mg PO qd) and prednisone (5 mg PO qd) or ADT plus abiraterone-prednisone placebos.[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

77383</a>

7739] High-risk disease was defined as having at least two of the following three factors: Gleason score of 8 or higher, three or more bone lesions, or measurable visceral metastases. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7740<ul id="_3003">

7741<li>

7742 After a median follow-up of 30.4 months, the trial was stopped because of a clear overall survival (OS) benefit in the abiraterone study group: median survival not reached versus 34.7 months OS (hazard ratio [HR], 0.62; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.51&#8211;0.76; <em>

7743P</em>

7744 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.3">

77453</a>

7746][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7747Level of evidence A1</a>

7748]</li>

7749<li>

7750 Abiraterone therapy was well tolerated, but there was an increase in the mineralocorticoid effects of grade 3 or 4 hypertension and hypokalemia compared with the placebo study group.</li>

7751<li>

7752A collection of patient-reported outcomes and Health-Related Quality of Life (HRQOL) data showed clinical benefits in pain progression, prostate cancer&#8211;related symptoms, fatigue, functional decline, and overall HRQOL in the abiraterone-acetate study group compared with the placebo group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.4">

77534</a>

7754][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7755Level of evidence A3</a>

7756]</li>

7757</ul>

7758</div>

7759</li>

7760<li>

7761 In the randomized open-label <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00268476">

7762STAMPEDE</a>

7763 trial (NCT00268476), 1,917 men (about 95% newly diagnosed; about 50% had metastatic disease and about 50% had locally advanced or node-positive disease) were treated with ADT alone or ADT plus abiraterone acetate (1,000 mg PO qd) and prednisolone (5 mg PO qd).[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

77645</a>

7765] Local radiation therapy was mandated after 6 to 9 months for men with node-negative nonmetastatic disease and optional for those with node-positive nonmetastatic disease. Hormone therapy was curtailed at 2 years or until progression. Radiation therapy was planned in about 40% of study participants.<div class="pdq-content-list">

7766<ul id="_3004">

7767<li>

7768 With a median follow-up of 40 months, the 3-year OS rate was 83% in the abiraterone study group compared with 76% in the ADT-only study group (HR<sub>

7769death,</sub>

7770 0.63; 95% CI, 0.52&#8211;0.76; <em>

7771P</em>

7772&lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_7.5">

77735</a>

7774][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7775Level of evidence A1</a>

7776] Although there was no clear evidence of heterogeneity in relative treatment differences in metastatic disease versus nonmetastatic disease, absolute differences were much smaller in men with nonmetastatic disease and not statistically significant, perhaps because of the short follow-up (HR<sub>

7777death,</sub>

7778 0.75; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;1.18). </li>

7779<li>

7780 The main additional differences in toxicity associated with abiraterone compared with ADT alone were hypertension (5% vs. 1%), mild increase in blood aminotransferase levels (6% vs. &lt; 1%), and respiratory disorders (5% vs. 2%). </li>

7781</ul>

7782</div>

7783</li>

7784<li>

7785In the randomized, controlled, double-blind phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02489318">

7786TITAN</a>

7787 trial (NCT02489318), 1,052 men with metastatic, castration-sensitive prostate cancer were randomly assigned to receive ADT alone or ADT plus either apalutamide (240 mg PO qd) or placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_7.6">

77886</a>

7789] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7790<ul id="_3149">

7791<li>

7792The 2-year OS rate was 82.4% in the apalutamide group and 73.5% in the placebo group (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.51&#8722;0.89). </li>

7793<li>

7794Radiographic progression-free survival (PFS) was 68.2% in the apalutamide group and 47.5% in the placebo group (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.39&#8722;0.60). </li>

7795<li>

7796Grade 3 or 4 adverse events were reported in 42.2% of patients in the apalutamide group and 40.8% of patients in the placebo group. </li>

7797<li>

7798Apalutamide has been associated with an increased risk of seizure, so men with a history of or predisposition to seizures were excluded from this trial.</li>

7799</ul>

7800</div>

7801</li>

7802<li>

7803In the randomized, controlled, open-label phase III <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT02446405">

7804ENZAMET</a>

7805 trial (NCT02446405), 1,125 men with castrate-sensitive prostate cancer were randomly assigned to receive ADT alone or ADT plus enzalutamide (160 mg PO qd).[<a href="#cit/section_7.7">

78067</a>

7807] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7808<ol id="_3150" class="lower-alpha">

7809<li>

7810The 3-year OS rate was 80% in the combined-therapy arm and 72% in the ADT monotherapy arm (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.52&#8722;0.86). </li>

7811<li>

7812PSA PFS (HR, 0.39, <em>

7813P</em>

7814 &lt; .001) and clinical PFS (HR, 0.40; <em>

7815P</em>

7816 &lt; .001) were also longer in the combined-therapy arm. </li>

7817<li>

7818Serious adverse events were reported in 42% of patients in the enzalutamide arm compared with 34% in the monotherapy arm. <div class="pdq-content-list">

7819<ul id="_3151">

7820<li>

7821Treatment was discontinued more frequently in the enzalutamide arm (33 vs. 14 events), and seizures and fatigue were more common in the enzalutamide arm: seven men (1%) had seizures in the enzalutamide arm versus none in the ADT-alone arm. </li>

7822<li>

7823Six percent of men in the combined-therapy arm reported grade 3 to 4 fatigue compared with 1% in the ADT-alone arm.</li>

7824</ul>

7825</div>

7826</li>

7827</ol>

7828</div>

7829</li>

7830</ol>

7831</div>

7832<p id="_1870" tabindex="-1">

7833Hormonal manipulations effectively used as <strong>

7834initial</strong>

7835 therapy for prostate

7836cancer include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_7.8">

78378</a>

7838]</p>

7839<div class="pdq-content-list">

7840<ul id="_1630">

7841<li>

7842Orchiectomy alone or with an androgen blocker as seen in the Southwest Oncology Group (SWOG-8894) trial.</li>

7843<li>

7844 Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonists, such as leuprolide in daily or depot preparations. These agents may be associated with tumor flare when used alone; therefore, the initial concomitant use of

7845antiandrogens should be considered in the presence of liver pain,

7846ureteral obstruction, or impending spinal cord compression.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

78479</a>

7848-<a href="#cit/section_7.12">

784912</a>

7850][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7851Level of evidence A1</a>

7852]</li>

7853<li>

7854Leuprolide plus flutamide;[<a href="#cit/section_7.13">

785513</a>

7856] however, the addition of an

7857antiandrogen to leuprolide has not been clearly shown in a meta-analysis to improve survival.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

785814</a>

7859]</li>

7860<li>

7861Estrogens (diethylstilboestrol [DES], chlorotrianisene, ethinyl estradiol, conjugated

7862estrogens-USP and DES-diphosphate). DES is no longer commercially available in the United States.

7863</li>

7864</ul>

7865</div>

7866<p id="_2659" tabindex="-1">

7867In some series, pretreatment levels of PSA were inversely correlated with progression-free duration in patients with metastatic prostate cancer who received hormonal therapy. After hormonal therapy is initiated, a PSA reduction to beneath a detectable level provides information regarding the duration of progression-free status; however, decreases in PSA of less than 80% may not be very predictive.[<a href="#cit/section_7.15">

786815</a>

7869]</p>

7870<p id="_2660" tabindex="-1">

7871Orchiectomy and estrogens yield similar results, and selection of one or the other depends on patient preference and the morbidity of expected side effects. Estrogens are associated with the development or exacerbation of cardiovascular disease, especially in high doses. DES at a dose of 1 mg qd is not associated with cardiovascular complications as frequent as those found at higher doses; however, the use of DES has decreased because of cardiovascular toxic effects. </p>

7872<p id="_2661" tabindex="-1">

7873The psychological implications of orchiectomy are objectionable to many patients, and many will choose an alternative therapy if effective.[<a href="#cit/section_7.16">

787416</a>

7875] Combined orchiectomy and estrogens are not indicated to be superior to either treatment administered alone.[<a href="#cit/section_7.17">

787617</a>

7877]</p>

7878<p id="_2662" tabindex="-1">

7879A large proportion of men experience hot flushes after bilateral orchiectomy or treatment with LH-RH agonists. These hot flashes can persist for years.[<a href="#cit/section_7.18">

788018</a>

7881] Varying levels of success in the management of these symptoms have been reported with DES, clonidine, cyproterone acetate, or medroxyprogesterone acetate.</p>

7882<p id="_2663" tabindex="-1">

7883After tumor progression on one form of hormonal manipulation, an objective tumor response to any other form is uncommon.[<a href="#cit/section_7.19">

788419</a>

7885] Some studies, however, suggest that withdrawal of flutamide (with or without aminoglutethimide administration) is associated with a decline in PSA and that one may need to monitor for this response before initiating new therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.20">

788620</a>

7887-<a href="#cit/section_7.22">

788822</a>

7889] Low-dose prednisone may palliate symptoms in about 33% of cases.[<a href="#cit/section_7.23">

789023</a>

7891] Newer hormonal approaches, such as inhibition of androgen receptors, have been shown to improve OS and quality of life (QOL) after tumor progression despite ADT. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_72">

7892Treatment of Recurrent or Hormone-Resistant Prostate Cancer</a>

7893 section.</p>

7894<section id="_2399">

7895<h5 id="_2399_toc">

7896Immediate versus deferred hormonal therapy </h5>

7897<p id="_2675" tabindex="-1">

7898Some patients may be asymptomatic and careful observation without further immediate therapy may be appropriate.</p>

7899<p id="_2400" tabindex="-1">

7900Evidence (immediate vs. deferred hormonal therapy):</p>

7901<div class="pdq-content-list">

7902<ol id="_2401">

7903<li>

7904A meta-analysis of seven randomized controlled trials comparing early (adjuvant or neoadjuvant) with deferred hormonal treatment (LH-RH agonists and/or antiandrogens) in patients with locally advanced prostate cancer, whether treated with prostatectomy, radiation therapy, or watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring, showed improved overall mortality with early treatment (relative risk, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.82&#8211;0.91).[<a href="#cit/section_7.24">

790524</a>

7906][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7907Level of evidence A1</a>

7908]</li>

7909<li>

7910In a small, randomized trial of 98 men who underwent radical prostatectomy plus

7911pelvic lymphadenectomy and were found to have nodal metastases (stage T1&#8211;2, N1,

7912M0), immediate continuous hormonal therapy with the LH-RH agonist goserelin or

7913with orchiectomy was compared with deferred therapy until documentation of

7914disease progression.[<a href="#cit/section_7.25">

791525</a>

7916][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7917Level of evidence A1</a>

7918];[<a href="#cit/section_7.26">

791926</a>

7920]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7921<ul id="_2402">

7922<li>

7923After a median follow-up of 11.9 years, OS (<em>

7924P</em>

7925 = .04) and prostate&#8211;cancer-specific survival (<em>

7926P</em>

7927 = .004) were superior in the immediate adjuvant therapy arm. </li>

7928<li>

7929At 10 years, the survival rate in the immediate therapy arm

7930was about 80% versus about 60% in the deferred therapy arm.[<a href="#cit/section_7.27">

793127</a>

7932]</li>

7933</ul>

7934</div>

7935</li>

7936<li>

7937Another trial (RTOG-8531) with twice as many randomly assigned patients showed no difference in OS with early versus late hormonal manipulation.[<a href="#cit/section_7.28">

793828</a>

7939]</li>

7940<li>

7941Immediate hormonal therapy with goserelin or orchiectomy has also been compared with deferred hormonal therapy for clinical disease progression in a randomized trial (<a href="https://www.eortc.org/research_field/clinical-detail/30846/" title="https://www.eortc.org/research_field/clinical-detail/30846/">

7942EORTC-30846</a>

7943) of men with regional lymph node involvement but no clinical evidence of metastases (any T, N+, M0). None of the 234 men had a prostatectomy or prostatic radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.29">

794429</a>

7945][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7946Level of evidence A1</a>

7947] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7948<ul id="_2403">

7949<li>

7950After a median follow-up of 8.7 years, the HR for OS in the deferred versus immediate hormonal therapy arms was 1.23 (95% CI, 0.88&#8211;1.71). </li>

7951<li>

7952No statistically significant difference in OS between deferred and immediate hormonal therapy was found, but the trial was underpowered to detect small or modest differences.</li>

7953</ul>

7954</div>

7955</li>

7956<li>

7957Immediate hormonal treatment (e.g., orchiectomy or LH-RH agonist) versus deferred treatment (e.g., watchful waiting with hormonal therapy at progression) was examined in a randomized study in men with locally advanced or asymptomatic metastatic prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_7.30">

795830</a>

7959][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7960Level of evidence A1</a>

7961]<div class="pdq-content-list">

7962<ul id="_2404">

7963<li>

7964The initial results showed better OS and prostate&#8211;cancer-specific survival with immediate treatment. </li>

7965<li>

7966The incidence of pathological fractures,

7967spinal cord compression, and ureteric obstruction were also lower in the

7968immediate treatment arm.</li>

7969</ul>

7970</div>

7971</li>

7972<li>

7973In another trial, 197 men with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer were randomly assigned to have a bilateral orchiectomy at diagnosis or at the time of symptomatic progression (or at the time of new metastases that were deemed likely to cause symptoms).[<a href="#cit/section_7.31">

797431</a>

7975][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

7976Level of evidence A1</a>

7977] <div class="pdq-content-list">

7978<ul id="_2405">

7979<li>

7980After 12 years of follow-up, no statistically significant difference was observed in OS.</li>

7981</ul>

7982</div>

7983</li>

7984</ol>

7985</div>

7986</section>

7987<section id="_2409">

7988<h5 id="_2409_toc">

7989Luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (LH-RH) agonists or antiandrogens</h5>

7990<p id="_2410" tabindex="-1">

7991Approaches using LH-RH agonists or antiandrogens in patients with stage IV

7992prostate cancer have produced response rates similar to other hormonal

7993treatments.[<a href="#cit/section_7.9">

79949</a>

7995,<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

799632</a>

7997]</p>

7998<p id="_2411" tabindex="-1">

7999Evidence (LH-RH agonists or antiandrogens):</p>

8000<div class="pdq-content-list">

8001<ol id="_2412">

8002<li>

8003In a randomized trial, the LH-RH agonist leuprolide (1

8004mg subcutaneously [SQ] qd) was as effective as DES (3

8005mg PO qd) in any T, any N, M1 patients, but caused less

8006gynecomastia, nausea and vomiting, and thromboembolisms.[<a href="#cit/section_7.10">

800710</a>

8008]</li>

8009<li>

8010In other randomized

8011studies, the depot LH-RH agonist goserelin was as

8012effective as orchiectomy [<a href="#cit/section_7.11">

801311</a>

8014,<a href="#cit/section_7.33">

801533</a>

8016,<a href="#cit/section_7.34">

801734</a>

8018] or DES at a dose of 3 mg qd.[<a href="#cit/section_7.32">

801932</a>

8020]

8021A depot preparation of leuprolide, which is therapeutically

8022equivalent to daily leuprolide, is available as a monthly or 3-monthly depot.</li>

8023<li>

8024 A systematic evidence review compared nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy with surgical or medical castration from 11 randomized trials in 3,060 men with locally advanced, metastatic, or recurrent disease after local therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_7.35">

802535</a>

8026] Use of nonsteroidal antiandrogens as monotherapy decreased OS and increased the rate of clinical progression and treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_7.35">

802735</a>

8028][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8029Level of evidence A1</a>

8030]</li>

8031<li>

8032A small randomized study comparing 1 mg DES PO tid with 250 mg of flutamide tid in patients with metastatic

8033prostate cancer showed similar response rates with both regimens but superior

8034survival with DES. More cardiovascular and/or thromboembolic toxic

8035effects of borderline statistical significance were associated with DES

8036treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_7.36">

803736</a>

8038][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8039Level of evidence A1</a>

8040] A variety of combinations of hormonal

8041therapy have been tested.

8042</li>

8043</ol>

8044</div>

8045</section>

8046<section id="_2518">

8047<h5 id="_2518_toc">

8048Maximal androgen blockade (MAB)</h5>

8049<p id="_2519" tabindex="-1">

8050On the basis that the adrenal glands continue to produce androgens after surgical or medical castration, case series studies were performed in which antiandrogen therapy was added to castration. Promising results from the case series led to widespread use of the strategy, known as MAB or total androgen blockade. Subsequent randomized controlled trials, however, cast doubt on the efficacy of adding an antiandrogen to castration. </p>

8051<p id="_2520" tabindex="-1">

8052Evidence (MAB):</p>

8053<div class="pdq-content-list">

8054<ol id="_2521">

8055<li>

8056In a large, randomized, controlled trial comparing

8057treatment with bilateral orchiectomy plus either the antiandrogen flutamide or

8058placebo, no difference in OS was reported.[<a href="#cit/section_7.37">

805937</a>

8060][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8061Level of evidence A1</a>

8062]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8063<ul id="_2522">

8064<li>

8065Although it has been suggested that MAB may improve the more subjective

8066end point of response rate, prospectively assessed QOL was worse in

8067the flutamide arm than in the placebo arm primarily because of more diarrhea and

8068worse emotional function in the flutamide-treated group.[<a href="#cit/section_7.38">

806938</a>

8070][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8071Level of evidence A3</a>

8072]</li>

8073</ul>

8074</div>

8075</li>

8076<li>

8077A meta-analysis of 27 randomized trials of 8,275 patients comparing

8078conventional surgical or medical castration with MAB&#8212;castration plus prolonged

8079use of an antiandrogen such as flutamide, cyproterone acetate, or nilutamide&#8212;did not show a statistically significant improvement in survival associated

8080with MAB.[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

808114</a>

8082][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8083Level of evidence A1</a>

8084]<p id="_2523" tabindex="-1">

8085When trials of androgen suppression versus androgen suppression plus either

8086nilutamide or flutamide were examined in a subset analysis, the absolute

8087survival rate at 5 years was better for the combined-therapy group (2.9%

8088better, 95% CI, 0.3&#8211;5.5); however, when trials of androgen

8089suppression versus androgen suppression plus cyproterone acetate were examined,

8090the absolute survival trend at 5 years was worse for the combined-therapy group

8091(2.8% worse, 95% CI, -7.6 to +2.0).[<a href="#cit/section_7.14">

809214</a>

8093]</p>

8094</li>

8095<li>

8096The Agency for Health Care Policy and Research (now the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality) performed a systematic review of the available randomized, clinical trial evidence of single hormonal therapies and total androgen blockade performed by its Technology Evaluation Center, an evidence-based Practice Center of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. A meta-analysis of randomized trials comparing various hormonal monotherapies in men with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer (predominantly stage IV) came to the following conclusions:[<a href="#cit/section_7.39">

809739</a>

8098][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8099Level of evidence A1</a>

8100]

8101<div class="pdq-content-list">

8102<ul id="_2557">

8103<li>

8104OS at 2 years using any of the LH-RH agonists was similar to treatment with orchiectomy or 3 mg every day of DES (HR, 1.26; 95% CI, 0.92&#8211;1.39).</li>

8105<li>

8106Survival rates at 2 years were similar or worse with nonsteroidal antiandrogens compared with orchiectomy (HR, 1.22; 95% CI, 0.99&#8211;1.50).</li>

8107<li>

8108Treatment withdrawals, used as a surrogate for adverse effects, occurred

8109less with LH-RH agonists (0%&#8211;4%) than with nonsteroidal antiandrogens (4%&#8211;10%).</li>

8110</ul>

8111</div>

8112<p id="_2526" tabindex="-1">

8113Total androgen blockade was of no greater benefit than single hormonal

8114therapy and with less patient tolerance. Also, the evidence was judged

8115insufficient to determine whether men newly diagnosed with asymptomatic

8116metastatic disease should have immediate androgen suppression therapy or

8117should have therapy deferred until they have clinical signs or symptoms of

8118progression.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

811940</a>

8120]</p>

8121</li>

8122</ol>

8123</div>

8124</section>

8125<section id="_2422">

8126<h5 id="_2422_toc">

8127Continuous versus intermittent hormonal therapy</h5>

8128<p id="_2423" tabindex="-1">

8129When used as the primary therapy for patients with stage III or stage IV prostate cancer, androgen suppression with hormonal therapy is often given continuously until there is disease progression. Another option is intermittent androgen suppression as a strategy to attain maximal tumor cytoreduction followed by a period without therapy to allow treatment-free periods. It was proposed that this strategy might provide tumor hormone responsiveness for a longer period. An animal model suggested that intermittent androgen deprivation (IAD) could prolong the duration of androgen dependence of hormone-sensitive tumors.[<a href="#cit/section_7.41">

813041</a>

8131] However, randomized controlled trials in humans have failed to support the hypothesis that IAD would delay the development of castration-resistant disease. If there are benefits from IAD, they appear to be in the realm of physical and sexual functioning.</p>

8132<p id="_2424" tabindex="-1">

8133Evidence (continuous vs. intermittent hormonal therapy):</p>

8134<div class="pdq-content-list">

8135<ol id="_2425">

8136<li>

8137A systematic review of 15 randomized trials that compared continuous ADT versus IAD therapy for patients with advanced or recurrent prostate cancer found no significant difference in OS, which was reported in eight of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.11); prostate cancer-specific survival, reported in five of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;1.19); or PFS, reported in four of the trials (HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.05). The meta-analysis fulfilled prespecified criteria for noninferiority of OS (upper bound of 1.15 for the HR<sub>

8138death,</sub>

8139 1.15).[<a href="#cit/section_7.42">

814042</a>

8141][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8142Level of evidence A1</a>

8143] However, of the 15 trials, all but one had an unclear or high risk of bias according to prespecified criteria.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8144<p class="pdq-list-title">

8145</p>

8146<ul id="_2846">

8147<li>

8148 There was minimal difference in patient-reported QOL, but most trials found better physical and sexual functioning in patients in the IAD arms.</li>

8149</ul>

8150</div>

8151</li>

8152</ol>

8153</div>

8154</section>

8155</section>

8156<section id="_2938">

8157<h4 id="_2938_toc">

8158Hormonal manipulations with chemotherapy</h4>

8159<p id="_3045" tabindex="-1">

8160The addition of chemotherapy has been shown in randomized trials to improve OS compared with ADT alone, with efficacy that appears to be comparable with hormonal therapy, which includes ADT plus abiraterone acetate. However, the two approaches have not been directly compared in a randomized study. </p>

8161<p id="_2939" tabindex="-1">

8162The addition of docetaxel has been tested in combination with long-term hormone therapy in the first-line management of metastatic prostate cancer and has been shown to improve results more than hormone therapy alone. A systematic evidence review and meta-analysis of randomized trials in hormone-sensitive metastatic prostate cancer summarizes these data.[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

816343</a>

8164] </p>

8165<p id="_2940" tabindex="-1">

8166Evidence (hormonal manipulations with chemotherapy):</p>

8167<div class="pdq-content-list">

8168<ol id="_2970">

8169<li>

8170In the analysis of three randomized trials (3,206 men), the HR<sub>

8171death</sub>

8172 associated with the addition of docetaxel to standard of care was 0.77 (95% CI, 0.68&#8211;0.87; <em>

8173P</em>

8174 &lt; .0001), representing an absolute improvement of 9% in 4-year survival (95% CI, 5&#8211;14).[<a href="#cit/section_7.43">

817543</a>

8176][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8177Level of evidence A1</a>

8178] </li>

8179<li>

8180In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00309985">

8181CHAARTED</a>

8182 trial (NCT00309985), 790 patients with metastatic, hormone-sensitive disease were randomly assigned to receive ADT with or without docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

81832</span>

8184 intravenously [IV] every 3 weeks for 6 cycles).[<a href="#cit/section_7.44">

818544</a>

8186,<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

818745</a>

8188] Previous adjuvant ADT was permissible if it lasted 12 months or less and progression had occurred within 12 months of completion. Patients were prospectively stratified as having a high- versus low-volume disease, with high volume defined as presence of visceral metastases or at least four bone lesions, with at least one lying outside the vertebral column or pelvis. About 65% of patients had high-volume disease by this definition. <div class="pdq-content-list">

8189<ul id="_3046">

8190<li>

8191With a median follow-up of 53.7 months, median OS in the ADT-plus-docetaxel arm was 57.6 months and in the ADT-alone arm, it was 47.2 months (HR<sub>

8192death</sub>

8193, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.89; <em>

8194P</em>

8195 = .0018).[<a href="#cit/section_7.45">

819645</a>

8197][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8198Level of evidence A1</a>

8199] </li>

8200<li>

8201The survival advantage was observed only in patients with high-volume disease. In the group with high-volume disease, there was a clear improvement in median OS (61.2 months vs. 34.4 months) (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;0.79; <em>

8202P</em>

8203 &lt; .001). However, there was no observed difference in survival in men with low-volume disease (median OS, 63.5 months vs. not reached) (HR, 1.04; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;1.55; <em>

8204P</em>

8205 = .86). The test for heterogeneity of efficacy was statistically significant (<em>

8206P</em>

8207 = .033).</li>

8208<li>

8209 Comparison of QOL between the two study groups, as measured by the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Prostate (FACT-P) scale, was not found to exceed the prospectively defined <em>

8210minimally important difference</em>

8211 at any time point over the 12 months of planned assessment.[<a href="#cit/section_7.46">

821246</a>

8213] </li>

8214</ul>

8215</div>

8216</li>

8217</ol>

8218</div>

8219</section>

8220<section id="_2429">

8221<h4 id="_2429_toc">

8222Bisphosphonates</h4>

8223<p id="_2430" tabindex="-1">

8224In addition to hormonal therapy, adjuvant treatment with bisphosphonates has been tested.[<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

822547</a>

8226]</p>

8227<p id="_2431" tabindex="-1">

8228Evidence (bisphosphonates):</p>

8229<div class="pdq-content-list">

8230<ol id="_2432">

8231<li>

8232 In MRC-PR05, 311 men with bone metastases who were starting or responding to standard hormonal therapy were randomly assigned to oral sodium clodronate (2,080 mg qd) or a matching placebo for up to 3 years.[<a href="#cit/section_7.47">

823347</a>

8234][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8235Level of evidence A1</a>

8236]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8237<ul id="_2433">

8238<li>

8239At a median follow-up of 11.5 years, OS was better in the clodronate arm: HR<sub>

8240death,</sub>

8241 0.77 (95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.98; <em>

8242P</em>

8243 = .032). </li>

8244<li>

8245Five- and 10-year survival rates were 30% and 17% in the clodronate arm versus 21% and 9% in the placebo arm.</li>

8246</ul>

8247</div>

8248</li>

8249<li>

8250A parallel study (MRC-PR04) in men with locally advanced but nonmetastatic disease showed no benefit associated with clodronate.</li>

8251<li>

8252<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00079001">

8253CALGB-90202</a>

8254 [NCT00079001] was a randomized controlled trial that compared zoledronic acid (4 mg IV every 4 weeks) with placebo in 645 men with androgen deprivation-sensitive prostate cancer that was metastatic to bone. Patients who progressed on hormone-therapy resistance received open-label, zoledronic acid.[<a href="#cit/section_7.48">

825548</a>

8256][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8257Level of evidence B1</a>

8258] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8259<ul id="_2756">

8260<li>

8261There was no difference between the two study arms in risk of the primary end point of time to skeletal-related events (defined as the need for palliative bone radiation, clinical fracture, spinal cord compression, bone surgery, or death from prostate cancer) after up to 7 years of follow-up. </li>

8262<li>

8263There were also no differences in PFS or OS.</li>

8264</ul>

8265</div>

8266</li>

8267<li>

8268 In another negative randomized trial (<a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00268476" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00268476">

8269STAMPEDE</a>

8270 [NCT00268476]), 1,245 men with locally advanced (M0) or metastatic (M1) prostate cancer, who were initiating long-term hormonal therapy, were randomly assigned to one of three arms (ratio of 2:1:1): standard of care, celecoxib (400 mg bid for 1 year), and celecoxib plus zoledronic acid (4 mg IV for six 3-week cycles, then 4-week cycles for 2 years).[<a href="#cit/section_7.49">

827149</a>

8272]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8273<ul id="_2997">

8274<li>

8275 After a median follow-up of 69 months, there was no detectable improvement in survival associated with either celecoxib or celecoxib plus zoledronic acid.</li>

8276<li>

8277 Although survival was better in patients with M disease who received celecoxib plus zoledronic acid than in patients with M1 disease who received the standard of care (HR<sub>

8278death,</sub>

8279 0.78; 95% CI, 0.62&#8211;0.98), a formal test for interaction with metastasis status was not statistically significant; therefore, the unexpected finding can only be considered hypothesis-generating.</li>

8280</ul>

8281</div>

8282</li>

8283</ol>

8284</div>

8285<section id="_2434">

8286<h5 id="_2434_toc">

8287Bisphosphonates and decreasing risk of bone metastases</h5>

8288<p id="_2435" tabindex="-1">

8289Patients with locally advanced nonmetastatic disease (T2&#8211;T4, N0&#8211;N1, and M0) are at risk of developing bone metastases, and bisphosphonates are being studied as a strategy to decrease this risk. However, a placebo-controlled randomized trial (MRC-PR04) of a 5-year regimen of the first-generation bisphosphonate clodronate in high oral doses (2,080 mg qd) had no favorable impact on either time to symptomatic bone metastasis or survival.[<a href="#cit/section_7.50">

829050</a>

8291][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8292Level of evidence A1</a>

8293]</p>

8294</section>

8295</section>

8296<section id="_1871">

8297<h4 id="_1871_toc">

8298External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT) with or without hormonal therapy</h4>

8299<p id="_1872" tabindex="-1">

8300EBRT may be used for attempted cure in highly selected stage M0

8301patients.[<a href="#cit/section_7.51">

830251</a>

8303,<a href="#cit/section_7.52">

830452</a>

8305] Definitive radiation therapy should be delayed 4 to 6 weeks

8306after TURP to reduce incidence of stricture.[<a href="#cit/section_7.53">

830753</a>

8308]</p>

8309<p id="_811" tabindex="-1">

8310Hormonal therapy should be considered in addition to EBRT.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

831140</a>

8312,<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

831354</a>

8314]</p>

8315<p id="_2664" tabindex="-1">

8316Evidence (radiation therapy with or without hormonal therapy):</p>

8317<div class="pdq-content-list">

8318<ol id="_2665">

8319<li>

8320The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association Technology Evaluation Center, an evidence-based practice center of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), performed a systematic review of the available randomized clinical trial evidence comparing radiation therapy with radiation therapy and prolonged androgen suppression.[<a href="#cit/section_7.40">

832140</a>

8322][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8323Level of evidence A1</a>

8324] Some patients with bulky T2b tumors were included in the studied groups.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8325<ul id="_2666">

8326<li>

8327The meta-analysis found a difference in 5-year OS in favor of radiation therapy plus continued androgen suppression using an LH-RH agonist or orchiectomy compared with radiation therapy alone (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.83).</li>

8328</ul>

8329</div>

8330</li>

8331<li>

8332In a randomized, prospective clinical trial, 18 months of androgen suppression with an LH-RH agonist appears to have provided results that were similar to 36 months with respect to OS and disease-specific survival.[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

833355</a>

8334][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8335Level of evidence A1</a>

8336] In the trial, 630 men with stage II to stage IVA cancer (clinical stage T3&#8211;T4, or PSA &gt;20 ng/ml, or Gleason score &gt;7) received 70 Gy of radiation in 35 fractions alone plus a total of either 18 or 36 months of goserelin acetate.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8337<ul id="_3079">

8338<li>

8339 With a median follow-up of 9.4 years, OS was nearly identical in each study arm (62% at 10 years; HR<sub>

8340death</sub>

8341, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.81&#8211;1.29, <em>

8342P</em>

8343 = .8), as was prostate cancer&#8211;specific survival (HR<sub>

8344prostate death</sub>

8345, 0.95; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;1.55, <em>

8346P</em>

8347 = .8).</li>

8348<li>

8349 Global quality of life was nearly identical on both study arms, but sexual activity and interest in sex was moderately better in the 18-month arm.[<a href="#cit/section_7.55">

835055</a>

8351][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8352Level of evidence A3</a>

8353]</li>

8354</ul>

8355</div>

8356</li>

8357<li>

8358The optimal duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy has been studied. In a randomized trial (TROG 96.01 [ACTRN12607000237482]) of 818 men with locally advanced (T2b, T2c, T3, and T4), nonmetastatic cancer treated with radiation therapy (i.e., 66 Gy in 2 Gy daily fractions to the prostate and seminal vesicles but not including regional nodes). Patients were randomly assigned to radiation therapy alone, 3 months of neoadjuvant androgen deprivation therapy (NADT) (goserelin 3.6 mg SQ each month plus flutamide 250 mg PO tid) for 2 months before and during radiation, or 6 months of NADT for 5 months before and during radiation.[<a href="#cit/section_7.54">

835954</a>

8360][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8361Level of evidence A1</a>

8362]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8363<ul id="_2667">

8364<li>

8365After a median follow-up of 10.6 years, there were no statistically significant differences between the radiation alone group and the radiation plus 3 months of NADT group.</li>

8366<li>

8367However, the 6-month NADT arm showed better prostate cancer-specific mortality and overall mortality than radiation alone; 10-year all-cause mortality 29.2% versus 42.5% (HR, 0.63; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;0.83, <em>

8368P</em>

8369 = .0008).</li>

8370</ul>

8371</div>

8372</li>

8373<li>

8374The duration of neoadjuvant hormonal therapy was tested in another trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005044">

8375RTOG-9910</a>

8376 [NCT00005044]) of 1,489 eligible men with intermediate-risk prostate cancer (T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 2&#8211;6, and PSA &gt;10 but &#8804;100 ng/mL; T1b&#8211;4, Gleason score 7, and PSA &lt;20; or T1b&#8211;1c, Gleason score 8&#8211;10, and PSA &lt;20) and no evidence of metastases. The men were randomly assigned to receive short-course neoadjuvant&#8211;androgen suppression (an LH-RH agonist plus bicalutamide or flutamide for 8 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy) or long-course neoadjuvant-androgen suppression (28 weeks before and 8 weeks during radiation therapy). Both groups received 70.2 Gy radiation in 39 daily fractions to the prostate and 46.8 Gy to the iliac lymph nodes.[<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

837756</a>

8378][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8379Level of evidence A1</a>

8380] <div class="pdq-content-list">

8381<ul id="_2820">

8382<li>

8383After a median of 9.4 years, 10-year prostate specific mortality, the primary end point, was low in both study arms: 5% versus 4% (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.48&#8211;1.39).[<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

838456</a>

8385][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8386Level of evidence A1</a>

8387]</li>

8388<li>

8389 No statistically significant differences in overall mortality or in locoregional disease progression were found.[<a href="#cit/section_7.56">

839056</a>

8391][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8392Level of evidence A1</a>

8393]</li>

8394<li>

8395 There was also no apparent differential effect of androgen suppression duration among any of the risk-group subsets.</li>

8396</ul>

8397</div>

8398</li>

8399</ol>

8400</div>

8401</section>

8402<section id="_1873">

8403<h4 id="_1873_toc">

8404Palliative radiation therapy</h4>

8405<p id="_2436" tabindex="-1">

8406A single fraction of 8 Gy has been shown to have similar benefits on bone pain relief and QOL as multiple fractions (3 Gy &#215; 10) as was evidenced in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003162">

8407RTOG-9714</a>

8408 trial (NCT00003162).[<a href="#cit/section_7.57">

840957</a>

8410]; [<a href="#cit/section_7.58">

841158</a>

8412][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8413Level of evidence A3</a>

8414]

8415 For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/pain/pain-hp-pdq">

8416Cancer Pain</a>

8417.</p>

8418</section>

8419<section id="_1875">

8420<h4 id="_1875_toc">

8421 Palliative surgery with transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP)</h4>

8422<p id="_2668" tabindex="-1">

8423Transurethral resection of the prostate may be useful in relieving urinary obstruction as part of palliative care in advanced prostate cancer.</p>

8424</section>

8425<section id="_1876">

8426<h4 id="_1876_toc">

8427Watchful waiting or active surveillance/active monitoring</h4>

8428<p id="_1877" tabindex="-1">

8429Careful observation without further immediate treatment (in selected

8430asymptomatic patients).[<a href="#cit/section_7.59">

843159</a>

8432]</p>

8433</section>

8434<section id="_3243">

8435<h4 id="_3243_toc">

8436Radical prostatectomy with immediate orchiectomy</h4>

8437<p id="_3244" tabindex="-1">

8438An uncontrolled, retrospective review of a large series of

8439patients with any T, N1&#8211;3, M0 disease treated at the Mayo Clinic with concurrent

8440radical prostatectomy and orchiectomy was associated with intervals to local

8441and distant progression; however, increase in OS has not

8442been demonstrated.[<a href="#cit/section_7.60">

844360</a>

8444] Patient selection factors make such study designs difficult to interpret.</p>

8445</section>

8446</section>

8447<section id="_TrialSearch_71_sid_7">

8448<h3 id="_TrialSearch_71_sid_7_toc">

8449Current Clinical Trials</h3>

8450<p id="_TrialSearch_71_22" tabindex="-1">

8451Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

8452advanced clinical trial search</a>

8453 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

8454General information</a>

8455 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

8456</section>

8610<li id="section_7.39">

8611Seidenfeld J, Samson DJ, Hasselblad V, et al.: Single-therapy androgen suppression in men with advanced prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Ann Intern Med 132 (7): 566-77, 2000.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10744594&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=10744594&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8612[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8613</li>

8614<li id="section_7.40">

8615Seidenfeld J, Samson DJ, Aronson N, et al.: Relative effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of methods of androgen suppression in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer. Evid Rep Technol Assess (Summ) (4): i-x, 1-246, I1-36, passim, 1999.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11098244&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=11098244&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8616[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8617</li>

8618<li id="section_7.41">

8619Calais da Silva FE, Bono AV, Whelan P, et al.: Intermittent androgen deprivation for locally advanced and metastatic prostate cancer: results from a randomised phase 3 study of the South European Uroncological Group. Eur Urol 55 (6): 1269-77, 2009.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19249153&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=19249153&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8620[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8621</li>

8623Magnan S, Zarychanski R, Pilote L, et al.: Intermittent vs Continuous Androgen Deprivation Therapy for Prostate Cancer: A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. JAMA Oncol 1 (9): 1261-9, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26378418&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26378418&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8624[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8625</li>

8626<li id="section_7.43">

8627Vale CL, Burdett S, Rydzewska LH, et al.: Addition of docetaxel or bisphosphonates to standard of care in men with localised or metastatic, hormone-sensitive prostate cancer: a systematic review and meta-analyses of aggregate data. Lancet Oncol 17 (2): 243-56, 2016.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26718929&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26718929&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8628[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8629</li>

8630<li id="section_7.44">

8631Sweeney CJ, Chen YH, Carducci M, et al.: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Hormone-Sensitive Prostate Cancer. N Engl J Med 373 (8): 737-46, 2015.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26244877&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=26244877&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8632[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8633</li>

8634<li id="section_7.45">

8635Kyriakopoulos CE, Chen YH, Carducci MA, et al.: Chemohormonal Therapy in Metastatic Hormone-Sensitive Prostate Cancer: Long-Term Survival Analysis of the Randomized Phase III E3805 CHAARTED Trial. J Clin Oncol 36 (11): 1080-1087, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29384722&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29384722&amp;dopt=Abstract">

J Clin Oncol 36 (11): 1088-1095, 2018.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29522362&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=29522362&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8656[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8657</li>

Cancer 45 (7 Suppl): 1912-21, 1980.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7370942&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7370942&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8660[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

Urology 27 (1): 10-6, 1986.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3079933&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=3079933&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8681</li>

8682<li id="section_7.57">

Radiother Oncol 79 (3): 278-84, 2006.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16793154&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=16793154&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8684[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8688[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

J Natl Cancer Inst 102 (13): 950-8, 2010.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20562373&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=20562373&amp;dopt=Abstract">

8692[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

8693</li>

8695Zincke H: Extended experience with surgical treatment of stage D1 adenocarcinoma of prostate. Significant influences of immediate adjuvant hormonal treatment (orchiectomy) on outcome. Urology 33 (5 Suppl): 27-36, 1989.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2775377&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=2775377&amp;dopt=Abstract">
