8699</div>

8700

8701 </section>

8702

8703

8704

8705 <section id="_72">

8706

8707 <h2>

8708Treatment of Recurrent or Hormone-Resistant Prostate Cancer</h2>

8709

8710 <div id="_section_72" class="pdq-sections">

8711<nav class="in-this-section" role="navigation">

8712<h6>

8713In This Section</h6>

8714<ul>

8715<li>

8716<a href="#_2437_toc">

8717Overview</a>

8718</li>

8719<li>

8720<a href="#_2930_toc">

8721Immediate Versus Deferred Hormonal Therapy</a>

8722</li>

8723<li>

8724<a href="#_2679_toc">

8725Hormonal Therapy for Recurring Disease<ul>

8726<li>

8727<a href="#_2680_toc">

8728Continuous versus intermittent hormonal therapy</a>

8729</li>

8730<li>

8731<a href="#_3102_toc">

8732Nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy versus surgical or medical castration</a>

8733</li>

8734<li>

8735<a href="#_2687_toc">

8736Hormonal approaches</a>

8737</li>

8738<li>

8739<a href="#_2440_toc">

8740Prevention of bone metastases</a>

8741</li>

8742</ul>

8743</a>

8744</li>

8745<li>

8746<a href="#_1819_toc">

8747Treatment Options for Recurrent Prostate Cancer <ul>

8748<li>

8749<a href="#_2449_toc">

8750Chemotherapy for hormone-resistant prostate cancer</a>

8751</li>

8752<li>

8753<a href="#_2462_toc">

8754Immunotherapy</a>

8755</li>

8756<li>

8757<a href="#_2791_toc">

8758Radiopharmaceutical therapy</a>

8759</li>

8760<li>

8761<a href="#_3184_toc">

8762PARP inhibitors for men with prostate cancer and <em class="gene-name">

8763BRCA1</em>

8764, <em class="gene-name">

8765BRCA2</em>

8766, and/or <em class="gene-name">

8767ATM</em>

8768 mutations</a>

8769</li>

8770</ul>

8771</a>

8772</li>

8773<li>

8774<a href="#_TrialSearch_72_sid_8_toc">

8775Current Clinical Trials</a>

8776</li>

8777</ul>

8778</nav>

8779<section id="_2437">

8780<h3 id="_2437_toc">

8781Overview</h3>

8782<p id="_2606" tabindex="-1">

8783In recurrent or hormone-resistant prostate cancer, the selection of further treatment depends on many factors,

8784including the following:</p>

8785<div class="pdq-content-list">

8786<ul id="_2607">

8787<li>

8788Previous treatment.</li>

8789<li>

8790Site of recurrence.</li>

8791<li>

8792Coexistent illnesses.</li>

8793<li>

8794Individual patient considerations.</li>

8795</ul>

8796</div>

8797<p id="_2438" tabindex="-1">

8798 Definitive radiation therapy can be given

8799to patients with disease that fails only locally after prostatectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.1">

88001</a>

8801-<a href="#cit/section_8.4">

88024</a>

8803] A randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00002874">

8804RTOG-9601</a>

8805 [NCT00002874]) has shown improved overall survival (OS) and prostate&#8211;cancer-specific survival with the addition of high-dose bicalutamide to radiation therapy compared with radiation therapy alone in men with locally recurrent prostate cancer after radical prostatectomy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

88065</a>

8807] </p>

8808<div class="pdq-content-list">

8809<ul id="_2971">

8810<li>

8811In the trial, 760 men who were initially treated with radical prostatectomy for tumor stage T2 or T3, and who had a detectable prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level of 0.2 to 4.0 ng/mL, but no evidence of metastases, were randomly assigned to receive radiation (64.8 Gy over 36 fractions) and either bicalutamide (150 mg PO qd) or placebo for 24 months. The median interval from surgery to PSA detectability was 1.4 years and from surgery to randomization was 2.1 years. Median follow-up was 13 years.</li>

8812<li>

8813 Actuarial OS at 12 years was 76.3% in the bicalutamide group versus 71.3% in the placebo group (<em>

8814P</em>

8815 = .04; hazard ratio [HR], 0.77; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.59&#8211;0.99).[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

88165</a>

8817][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8818Level of evidence A1</a>

8819]</li>

8820<li>

8821Prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality at 12 years was 5.8% (bicalutamide) versus 13.4% (placebo), (HR, 0.49; 95% CI, 0.32&#8211;0.74; <em>

8822P</em>

8823 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.5">

88245</a>

8825][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8826Level of evidence A1</a>

8827]</li>

8828<li>

8829 Most treatment-related toxicities were similar between the two groups, except for gynecomastia, which occurred in 69.7% of the men on bicalutamide versus 10.9% of those on placebo. This side effect may be mitigated by prophylactic breast irradiation, which was not used in this study because of the double-blinded design.</li>

8830</ul>

8831</div>

8832<p id="_2972" tabindex="-1">

8833Some

8834patients with a local recurrence after

8835definitive radiation therapy can be salvaged with prostatectomy;[<a href="#cit/section_8.6">

88366</a>

8837] however, only about 10% of patients treated

8838initially with radiation therapy will have local relapse only. In these patients,

8839prolonged disease control is often possible with hormonal therapy, with median

8840cancer-specific survival of 6 years after local failure.[<a href="#cit/section_8.7">

88417</a>

8842]</p>

8843<p id="_2608" tabindex="-1">

8844Cryosurgical

8845ablation of recurrence after radiation therapy is associated frequently with

8846a high complication rate. This

8847technique is still undergoing clinical evaluation.[<a href="#cit/section_8.8">

88488</a>

8849]</p>

8850<p id="_2439" tabindex="-1">

8851Hormonal therapy is used to manage most relapsing patients with disseminated disease who initially received locoregional therapy with surgery or radiation therapy. For more information, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_808">

8852Treatment Options for Stage IV Prostate Cancer </a>

8853 section.</p>

8854</section>

8855<section id="_2930">

8856<h3 id="_2930_toc">

8857Immediate Versus Deferred Hormonal Therapy</h3>

8858<p id="_2973" tabindex="-1">

8859For more information on the use of immediate hormonal therapy (bicalutamide or luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone [LH-RH] agonists) plus radiation in the setting of locally recurrent prostate cancer after radical prostatectomy, see the <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_62">

8860Treatment Option Overview for Prostate Cancer</a>

8861 section.</p>

8862<p id="_2932" tabindex="-1">

8863PSA is often used to monitor patients after initial therapy with curative intent, and elevated or rising PSA is a common trigger for additional therapy even in asymptomatic men. Despite how common the situation is, it is not clear whether additional treatments given because of rising PSA in asymptomatic men with prostate cancer increase OS. The quality of evidence is limited.</p>

8864<div class="pdq-content-list">

8865<ol id="_2933">

8866<li>

8867After radical prostatectomy, detectable PSA levels identify patients at elevated risk of local treatment failure or metastatic disease;[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

88689</a>

8869] however, a substantial proportion of patients with elevated or rising PSA levels after initial therapy with curative intent may remain clinically free of symptoms for extended periods.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

887010</a>

8871] In a retrospective analysis of nearly 2,000 men who had undergone radical prostatectomy with curative intent and who were followed for a mean of 5.3 years, 315 men (15%) demonstrated an abnormal PSA of 0.2 ng/mL or higher, which is evidence of biochemical recurrence.[<a href="#cit/section_8.11">

887211</a>

8873]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8874<ul id="_2934">

8875<li>

8876Of these 315 men, 103 men (34%) developed clinical evidence of recurrence.</li>

8877<li>

8878The median time to development of clinical metastasis after biochemical recurrence was 8 years. </li>

8879<li>

8880After the men developed metastatic disease, the median time to death was an additional 5 years.</li>

8881</ul>

8882</div>

8883</li>

8884<li>

8885After radiation therapy with curative intent, persistently elevated or rising PSA may be a prognostic factor for clinical disease recurrence. However, reported case series have used a variety of definitions of PSA failure. Criteria have been developed by the American Society for Therapeutic Radiology and Oncology Consensus Panel.[<a href="#cit/section_8.12">

888612</a>

8887,<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

888813</a>

8889] The implication of the various definitions of PSA failure for OS is not known, and as in the surgical series, many biochemical relapses (rising PSA alone) may not be clinically manifested in patients treated with radiation therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.14">

889014</a>

8891,<a href="#cit/section_8.15">

889215</a>

8893]</li>

8894<li>

8895A randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00110162">

8896PMCC-VCOG-PR-0103</a>

8897 [NCT00110162]) of androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) in men who received curative therapy but have a rising PSA, provides some evidence of improved OS associated with immediate versus delayed therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

889816</a>

8899] The study had important shortcomings.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8900<ol id="_2935" class="lower-alpha">

8901<li>

8902Two groups of men were randomly assigned to open-label, immediate-versus-delayed (at least 2-year delay) ADT: <div class="pdq-content-list">

8903<ul id="_2936">

8904<li>

8905Group 1 included men who had a PSA relapse after curative therapy (89% of the study population). </li>

8906<li>

8907Group 2 included asymptomatic men who were considered unsuitable for curative treatment because of age, comorbidity, or locally advanced disease (11% of the study population).</li>

8908</ul>

8909</div>

8910<p id="_2937" tabindex="-1">

8911Planned accrual was 750 patients, but because of slow accrual, the trial closed at 293 patients.</p>

8912 </li>

8913<li>

8914In groups 1 and 2 combined, with a median follow-up of 5 years, the 5-year OS rate was 86.4% in the delayed ADT study arm versus 91.2% in the immediate ADT study arm (log rank, <em>

8915P</em>

8916 = .047).[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

891716</a>

8918][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8919Level of evidence A1</a>

8920] After full adjustment for baseline characteristics, the HR for OS was 0.54 (95% CI, 0.27&#8211;1.06; <em>

8921P</em>

8922 = .074). </li>

8923<li>

8924For group 1 only (those with PSA relapse after curative therapy, N = 261), the estimated 5-year survival rate was 78.2% versus 84.3% with delayed-versus-immediate ADT (log rank, <em>

8925P</em>

8926 = .10; fully adjusted HR, 0.59; 95% CI, 0.26&#8211;1.30, <em>

8927P</em>

8928 = .19).</li>

8929<li>

8930Toxicity was greater in the immediate ADT study arm compared with delayed therapy. Serious (grade 4) adverse events were reported in 42% of patients in the immediate ADT study arm versus 31% of patients in the delayed therapy arm. Quality of life (QOL) fell by 6.1% (considered a <em>

8931small but clinically important</em>

8932 drop) with immediate ADT versus 3% with delayed ADT (considered a <em>

8933trivial</em>

8934 drop); but this was not a statistically significant difference (<em>

8935P</em>

8936 = .14).[<a href="#cit/section_8.16">

893716</a>

8938] Sexual activity was lower and hormone-related symptoms (hot flashes and sore or enlarged nipples) were clinically and statistically significantly worse in the immediate ADT arm compared with the delayed therapy arm.[<a href="#cit/section_8.17">

893917</a>

8940] </li>

8941</ol>

8942</div>

8943</li>

8944</ol>

8945</div>

8946</section>

8947<section id="_2679">

8948<h3 id="_2679_toc">

8949Hormonal Therapy for Recurring Disease</h3>

8950<section id="_2680">

8951<h4 id="_2680_toc">

8952Continuous versus intermittent hormonal therapy</h4>

8953<p id="_2681" tabindex="-1">

8954Most men who are treated for recurrence after initial local therapy are asymptomatic, and the recurrence is detected by a rising PSA. It is possible that intermittent androgen deprivation (IAD) therapy can be used as an alternative to continuous ADT (CAD) to improve QOL and decrease the amount of time during which the patient experiences the side effects of hormonal therapy, without decreasing the survival rate. </p>

8955<div class="pdq-content-list">

8956<ol id="_2685">

8957<li>

8958This important clinical question was addressed in a noninferiority-designed, randomized, controlled trial with 1,386 men who had rising PSA levels (&gt;3 ng/mL, with serum testosterone &gt;5 nmol/L) more than 1 year after primary or salvage radiation therapy for localized prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_8.18">

895918</a>

8960][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8961A1</a>

8962 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8963A3</a>

8964]<div class="pdq-content-list">

8965<ul id="_2686">

8966<li>

8967The ADT arm consisted of 8-month treatment cycles with an LH-RH agonist (combined with a nonsteroidal antiandrogen for at least the first 4 weeks) that was reinstituted if the PSA level exceeded 10 ng/mL. The study was powered to detect (with 95% confidence) an 8% lower OS rate in the IAD group compared with the CAD group at 7 years.</li>

8968<li>

8969After a median follow-up of 6.9 years (maximum follow-up 11.2 years), OS in the two groups was nearly identical, and the study was stopped (median survival, 8.8 vs. 9.1 years; HR<sub>

8970death,</sub>

8971 1.02; 95% CI, 0.86&#8211;1.21). This fulfilled the prospective criterion of noninferiority. </li>

8972<li>

8973In a retrospective analysis, prostate&#8211;cancer-specific mortality was also similar in the two arms (HR, 1.18; 95% CI, 0.90&#8211;1.55; <em>

8974P</em>

8975 = 0.24). In addition, IAD was statistically significantly better than CAD in several QOL domains, such as hot flashes, desire for sexual activity, and urinary symptoms. Patients on the IAD study arm received a median of 15.4 months of treatment versus 43.9 months on the CAD arm.</li>

8976<li>

8977The study does not address the unanswered question about whether the initiation of any ADT for an elevated PSA after initial local therapy extends survival compared with delay until clinically symptomatic progression. Of note, 59% of all deaths were unrelated to prostate cancer, and only 14% of all patients died of prostate cancer.</li>

8978</ul>

8979</div>

8980</li>

8981<li>

8982A systematic review of 15 randomized trials that compared CAD versus IAD therapy for patients with advanced or recurrent prostate cancer found no significant difference in OS, which was reported in eight of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.93&#8211;1.11); prostate&#8211;cancer-specific survival, reported in five of the trials (HR, 1.02; 95% CI, 0.87&#8211;1.19); or progression-free survival (PFS), reported in four of the trials (HR, 0.94; 95% CI, 0.84&#8211;1.05). The meta-analysis fulfilled prespecified criteria for noninferiority of OS (upper bound of 1.15 for the HR of 1.15).[<a href="#cit/section_8.19">

898319</a>

8984][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

8985Level of evidence A1</a>

8986] However, of the 15 trials, all but one had an unclear or high risk of bias according to prespecified criteria.<div class="pdq-content-list">

8987<ul id="_2847">

8988<li>

8989 There was minimal difference in patient-reported QOL, but most trials found better physical and sexual functioning in patients in the IAD arms.</li>

8990</ul>

8991</div>

8992</li>

8993</ol>

8994</div>

8995</section>

8996<section id="_3102">

8997<h4 id="_3102_toc">

8998Nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy versus surgical or medical castration</h4>

8999<p id="_3103" tabindex="-1">

9000A systematic evidence review compared nonsteroidal antiandrogen monotherapy with surgical or medical castration from 11 randomized trials in 3,060 men with locally advanced, metastatic, or recurrent disease after local therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

900120</a>

9002] The use of nonsteroidal antiandrogens as monotherapy decreased OS and increased the rate of clinical progression and treatment failure.[<a href="#cit/section_8.20">

900320</a>

9004][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9005Level of evidence A1</a>

9006]</p>

9007</section>

9008<section id="_2687">

9009<h4 id="_2687_toc">

9010Hormonal approaches</h4>

9011<p id="_2688" tabindex="-1">

9012As noted above, studies have shown that chemotherapy with docetaxel or cabazitaxel and immunotherapy with sipuleucel-T can prolong OS in patients with hormone-resistant metastatic prostate cancer. Nevertheless, hormonal therapy has also been shown to improve survival even in men who have progressed after other forms of hormonal therapy as well as chemotherapy. Some forms of hormonal therapy are effective in the management of metastatic hormone&#8211;refractory prostate cancer.</p>

9013<p id="_3111" tabindex="-1">

9014Because there are no head-to-head comparisons, there are no trials to help decide which of these agents should be used first or in what sequence they should be used.</p>

9015<p id="_3112" tabindex="-1">

9016Even among patients with metastatic hormone-refractory prostate cancer, some heterogeneity is found in prognosis and in retained hormone sensitivity. In such patients who have symptomatic bone disease, several factors are associated with worsened prognosis: poor performance status, elevated alkaline phosphatase, abnormal serum creatinine, and short (&lt;1 year) previous response to hormonal therapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.21">

901721</a>

9018] The absolute level of PSA at the initiation of therapy in relapsed or hormone-refractory patients has not shown prognostic significance.[<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

901922</a>

9020]</p>

9021<p id="_3113" tabindex="-1">

9022Some patients whose disease has progressed on combined androgen blockade can respond to a variety of second-line hormonal therapies. Aminoglutethimide, hydrocortisone, flutamide withdrawal, progesterone, ketoconazole, and combinations of these therapies have produced PSA responses in 14% to 60% of patients treated and have also produced clinical responses of 0% to 25% when assessed. The duration of these PSA responses has ranged from 2 to 4 months.[<a href="#cit/section_8.23">

902323</a>

9024] Survival rates are similar whether ketoconazole plus hydrocortisone is initiated at the same time as antiandrogen (e.g., flutamide, bicalutamide, or nilutamide) withdrawal or when PSA has risen after an initial trial of antiandrogen withdrawal, as seen in the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00002760" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00002760">

9025CLB-9583</a>

9026 trial (NCT00002760), for example.[<a href="#cit/section_8.24">

902724</a>

9028][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9029Level of evidence A1</a>

9030] There are conflicting data on whether PSA changes in men undergoing chemotherapy are predictive of survival.[<a href="#cit/section_8.22">

903122</a>

9032,<a href="#cit/section_8.25">

903325</a>

9034]</p>

9035<p id="_3114" tabindex="-1">

9036Patients treated with either luteinizing-hormone agonists or estrogens as primary therapy are generally maintained with castrate levels of testosterone. One study from the Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) showed that a superior survival resulted when patients were maintained on primary androgen deprivation;[<a href="#cit/section_8.9">

90379</a>

9038] however, another study from SWOG (formerly the Southwest Oncology Group) did not show an advantage to continued androgen blockade.[<a href="#cit/section_8.26">

903926</a>

9040]</p>

9041<p id="_2689" tabindex="-1">

9042Evidence (hormonal approaches <strong>

9043for castration-resistant progressive disease with no previous chemotherapy</strong>

9044):</p>

9045<div class="pdq-content-list">

9046<ol id="_2786">

9047<li>

9048Abiraterone acetate is an inhibitor of androgen biosynthesis that works by blocking cytochrome P450c17 (CYP17). Abiraterone has mineralocorticoid effects, producing an increased incidence of fluid retention and edema, hypokalemia, hypertension, and cardiac dysfunction. In addition, abiraterone is associated with hepatotoxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.27">

904927</a>

9050] However, compared with other therapies, abiraterone toxicities are mild. In a double-blinded placebo-controlled trial, 1,088 men with progressing hormone refractory disease (serum testosterone &lt;50 ng per deciliter on previous antiandrogen therapy), no previous chemotherapy, and ECOG performance status (PS) 0 to 1 were given prednisone (5 mg PO bid) plus either abiraterone acetate (1,000 mg PO qd) or placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

905128</a>

9052,<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

905329</a>

9054][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9055Level of evidence A1</a>

9056] The coprimary end points were radiological PFS and OS. Four sequential analyses were planned.<div class="pdq-content-list">

9057<ul id="_2787">

9058<li>

9059At the second interim analysis, after a median follow-up of 22.2 months, the study was stopped and unblinded because of aggregate efficacy and safety as assessed by the data monitoring committee. At that point, the radiological PFS had reached the prespecified stopping boundary in favor of abiraterone (median PFS, 16.5 months vs. 8.3 months [HR, 0.53; 95% CI, 0.45&#8211;0.62; <em>

9060P</em>

9061 &lt; .001]). </li>

9062<li>

9063At the fourth (and final) analysis with a median follow-up of 49.2 months (maximum 60 months), 65% had died in the abiraterone-acetate study arm and 71% had died in the placebo study arm (HR, 0.81; 95% CI, 0.70&#8211;0.93: <em>

9064P</em>

9065 = .033). Median OS was 34.7 versus 30.3 months.[<a href="#cit/section_8.29">

906629</a>

9067][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9068Level of evidence A1</a>

9069]</li>

9070<li>

9071Median time to health-related QOL deterioration was long in the abiraterone study arm, as assessed by the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy-Prostate Version 4 (FACT-P) total score (12.7 months vs. 8.3 months; HR, 0.78; 95% CI, 0.66-0.92; <em>

9072P</em>

9073 = .003) and by the prostate&#8211;cancer-specific subscale (11.1 months vs. 5.8 months; HR, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.60&#8211;0.83; <em>

9074P</em>

9075 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

907630</a>

9077][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9078Level of evidence A3</a>

9079] </li>

9080<li>

9081In addition, patients in the abiraterone study group had statistically significant longer median times to opiate use for pain, initiation of cytotoxic chemotherapy, decline in PS, and PSA progression.[<a href="#cit/section_8.28">

908228</a>

9083,<a href="#cit/section_8.30">

908430</a>

9085][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9086A3</a>

9087 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9088B1</a>

9089]</li>

9090</ul>

9091</div>

9092</li>

9093<li>

9094Enzalutamide, an androgen receptor antagonist, has been shown to increase OS and QOL in men with metastatic prostate cancer that has progressed despite ADT. In the <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01212991" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01212991">

9095PREVAIL</a>

9096 study (NCT01212991), 1,717 asymptomatic or mildly symptomatic men with recurrent metastatic prostate cancer despite ADT were randomly assigned to receive enzalutamide (160 mg PO qd) versus placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_8.31">

909731</a>

9098-<a href="#cit/section_8.33">

909933</a>

9100][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9101A1</a>

9102 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9103A3</a>

9104]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9105<ul id="_3104">

9106<li>

9107After a median follow-up of 22 months, the study was stopped because of an OS benefit in the enzalutamide study arm (HR, 0.72; 95% CI, 0.6&#8211;0.84; <em>

9108P</em>

9109 &lt; .001). The proportion of men who had died was 28% versus 35%, and the median OS was 32.4 versus 30.2 months.</li>

9110<li>

9111Median time until decline in global QOL, measured by the FACT-P score, was 11.3 months versus 5.6 months in the enzalutamide and placebo groups (<em>

9112P</em>

9113 &lt; .001), and delayed occurrence of first skeletal-related event requiring clinical intervention was also shown.[<a href="#cit/section_8.31">

911431</a>

9115,<a href="#cit/section_8.32">

911632</a>

9117][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9118A3</a>

9119 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9120B1</a>

9121]</li>

9122<li>

9123 Grade 3 or worse adverse events were more common in the enzalutamide group (43% vs. 37%), primarily because of differences in hypertension, fatigue, and falls. Because patients receiving enzalutamide were on assigned therapy for an average of 1 year longer than those on placebo, the duration of response was longer in patients receiving enzalutamide, and this difference may have contributed to the increase in adverse events.</li>

9124</ul>

9125</div>

9126</li>

9127<li>

9128Enzalutamide has also been tested in the setting of clinically nonmetastatic, hormone-resistant prostate cancer (defined as PSA doubling time &#8804;10 months while undergoing hormonal therapy).[<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

912934</a>

9130]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9131<ul id="_3116">

9132<li>

9133In the double-blind phase III <a href="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02003924" title="https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02003924">

9134PROSPER</a>

9135 trial (NCT02003924), 1,401 men without clinical metastases on imaging, but with a rapidly rising PSA, were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive either enzalutamide (160 mg PO qd) or placebo. After follow-up of up to 41 months, enzalutamide showed superiority in the primary end point, metastasis-free survival: 77% versus 51% (median 36.6 vs. 14.7 months; HR, 0.29; 95% CI, 0.24&#8211;0.35; <em>

9136P</em>

9137 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.34">

913834</a>

9139][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9140Level of evidence B1</a>

9141]</li>

9142<li>

9143 OS data were not mature, but at the time of the report, 11% of the men had died in the enzalutamide arm versus 13% in the placebo arm.</li>

9144<li>

9145 The rate of decline in health-related quality of life was the same in both arms.</li>

9146<li>

9147 Grade 3+ toxicities were more common in the enzalutamide group: 31% versus 23%. </li>

9148<li>

9149There were also excesses in several adverse events <em>

9150of special interest</em>

9151 because they have been reported previously in patients treated with enzalutamide, including hypertension (12% vs. 5%), major cardiovascular events (5% vs. 3%), and mental impairment disorders (5% vs. 2%).</li>

9152</ul>

9153</div>

9154</li>

9155<li>

9156Continuing enzalutamide in patients who were switched to abiraterone because of progression, and who had castration-resistant metastatic prostate cancer and a rising PSA while receiving enzalutamide, did not appear to improve the rate of PFS or of clinical progression, a strategy that was tested in the randomized <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/v?id=NCT01995513&amp;r=1" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/v?id=NCT01995513&amp;r=1">

9157PLATO</a>

9158 trial (NCT01995513).[<a href="#cit/section_8.35">

915935</a>

9160][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9161Level of evidence B1</a>

9162]</li>

9163<li>

9164Apalutamide, an androgen receptor antagonist, has been tested in the setting of clinically nonmetastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer (defined as PSA doubling time &#8804;10 months while undergoing androgen deprivation therapy).[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

916536</a>

9166] In the trial, 1,207 men were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive either daily apalutamide (240 mg PO) or a placebo. All continued their previous ADT. <div class="pdq-content-list">

9167<ul id="_3117">

9168<li>

9169With a median follow-up of 20.3 months, metastasis-free survival was 40.5 months in the apalutamide group compared with 16.2 months on placebo (HR, 0.28; 95% CI, 0.23&#8211;0.35; <em>

9170P</em>

9171 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.36">

917236</a>

9173][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9174Level of evidence B1</a>

9175]</li>

9176<li>

9177There was a trend toward improved OS in the apalutamide group, but it did not reach statistical significance at the time of the report (HR, 0.70; 95% CI, 0.47&#8211;1.04; <em>

9178P</em>

9179 = .07).</li>

9180<li>

9181 There were increases in a number of toxicities associated with apalutamide treatment, which included the following: bone fractures (11.7% vs. 6.5%), hypothyroidism (8.1% vs. 2.0%), fatigue (30.4% vs. 21.1%), hypertension (24.8% vs. 19.8%), rash (23.8% vs. 5.5%), diarrhea (20.3% vs. 15.1%), weight loss (16.1% vs. 6.3%), arthralgias (15.9% vs. 7.5%), and falls (15.6% vs. 9.0%).</li>

9182<li>

9183In a prespecified exploratory analysis, quality of life over time was similar in the apalutamide and placebo arms, as assessed overall and for all component subscale scores of the FACT-P and EuroQol five-dimension, three-level (EQ-5D-3L) questionnaires.[<a href="#cit/section_8.37">

918437</a>

9185][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9186Level of evidence A3</a>

9187]</li>

9188</ul>

9189</div>

9190</li>

9191<li>

9192Darolutamide, another androgen receptor antagonist, has also been shown to prolong metastasis-free survival and OS in men with nonmetastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

919338</a>

9194,<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

919539</a>

9196] A distinguishing characteristic of darolutamide is its low penetration of the blood-brain barrier. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved darolutamide specifically for nonmetastatic, castration-resistant prostate cancer, a more limited label compared with enzalutamide and apalutamide.<p id="_3183" tabindex="-1">

9197A randomized controlled trial included 1,509 men with nonmetastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer, a rising PSA, and a castrate testosterone level. Patients were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive darolutamide or placebo while continuing ADT.[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

919838</a>

9199,<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

920039</a>

9201]</p>

9202<div class="pdq-content-list">

9203<ul id="_3182">

9204<li>

9205The 3-year OS rate was 83% for patients who received darolutamide (95% CI, 80%&#8211;86%) and 77% for patients who received placebo (95% CI, 72%&#8211;81%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.38">

920638</a>

9207,<a href="#cit/section_8.39">

920839</a>

9209][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9210Level of evidence A1</a>

9211]</li>

9212<li>

9213 The darolutamide arm was also associated with longer metastasis-free survival (HR, 0.41; 95% CI, 0.34&#8211;0.50).</li>

9214<li>

9215 Patient-reported QOL was similar in the two arms and differences favored the darolutamide arm. There were statistically significant differences favoring darolutamide for measures of pain, well-being, and urinary symptoms, but the differences did not reach clinically meaningful levels.</li>

9216<li>

9217 In contrast to studies of enzalutamide and apalutamide, darolutamide was not associated with a higher incidence of falls or fractures, hypertension, or central nervous system&#8211;related adverse effects when compared with placebo. </li>

9218</ul>

9219</div>

9220</li>

9221</ol>

9222</div>

9223<p id="_3105" tabindex="-1">

9224Evidence (hormonal approaches <strong>

9225for progressive disease with previous chemotherapy</strong>

9226):</p>

9227<div class="pdq-content-list">

9228<ol id="_3106">

9229<li>

9230Men with metastatic prostate cancer who had biochemical or clinical progression after treatment with docetaxel (N = 1,195) were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive either abiraterone acetate (1,000 mg) (n = 797) or placebo (n = 398) by mouth every day (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00638690">

9231COU-AA-301</a>

9232 [NCT00638690]). Both groups received prednisone (5 mg PO bid).[<a href="#cit/section_8.40">

923340</a>

9234][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9235Level of evidence A1</a>

9236]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9237<ul id="_3107">

9238<li>

9239After a median follow-up of 12.8 months, the trial was stopped when an interim analysis showed an OS advantage in the abiraterone group. The final report of the trial was published after a median follow-up of 20.2 months.</li>

9240<li>

9241Median OS was 15.8 months in the abiraterone group versus 11.2 months in the placebo group (HR<sub>

9242death,</sub>

9243 0.74; 95% CI, 0.64&#8211;0.86; <em>

9244P</em>

9245 &lt; .0001).</li>

9246<li>

9247Compared with placebo, abiraterone was also associated with a delay in median time to deterioration in the FACT-P QOL score (59.9 weeks vs. 36.1 weeks, <em>

9248P</em>

9249 &lt; .0001) and a clinically important improvement in QOL in men with functional status impairment at baseline (48% vs. 32%, <em>

9250P</em>

9251 &lt; .0001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.41">

925241</a>

9253][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9254Level of evidence A3</a>

9255]</li>

9256</ul>

9257</div>

9258</li>

9259<li>

9260Enzalutamide has also been shown to increase survival in patients with progressive prostate cancer who previously received ADT as well as docetaxel. In a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial, 1,129 men were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive enzalutamide (160 mg PO qd) versus placebo.[<a href="#cit/section_8.42">

926142</a>

9262-<a href="#cit/section_8.45">

926345</a>

9264][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9265A1</a>

9266 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9267A3</a>

9268]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9269<ul id="_3115">

9270<li>

9271After a median follow-up of 14.4 months, the study was stopped at the single-planned interim analysis because improved OS, the primary end point, was found in the enzalutamide study group (median OS, 18.4 months; 95% CI, 17.3&#8211;not-yet-reached vs. 13.6 months; 95% CI, 11.3&#8211;15.8; HR<sub>

9272death,</sub>

9273 0.63; 95% CI, 0.53&#8211;0.75; <em>

9274P</em>

9275 &lt; .001). In addition, QOL, measured by the FACT-P questionnaire, was superior in the enzalutamide arm, as was time to first skeletal-related event.[<a href="#cit/section_8.43">

927643</a>

9277,<a href="#cit/section_8.45">

927845</a>

9279]</li>

9280<li>

9281A seizure was reported in 5 of the 800 men in the enzalutamide study group versus none in the placebo group; however, the relationship to enzalutamide is not clear. Of the reported seizures, two patients had brain metastases, one patient had just received intravenous (IV) lidocaine, and one seizure was not witnessed.

9282

9283</li>

9284</ul>

9285</div>

9286</li>

9287</ol>

9288</div>

9289</section>

9290<section id="_2440">

9291<h4 id="_2440_toc">

9292Prevention of bone metastases</h4>

9293<p id="_2609" tabindex="-1">

9294Painful bone metastases can be a major problem for patients with prostate cancer. Many

9295strategies have been studied for palliation, including the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.46">

929646</a>

9297-<a href="#cit/section_8.50">

929850</a>

9299]</p>

9300<div class="pdq-content-list">

9301<ul id="_2610">

9302<li>

9303External-beam radiation therapy (EBRT).</li>

9304<li>

9305Bone-seeking radionuclides (strontium chloride Sr 89 [89Sr]).</li>

9306<li>

9307Denosumab (a monoclonal antibody that inhibits osteoclast function).</li>

9308<li>

9309Pain medication.</li>

9310<li>

9311Corticosteroids.</li>

9312<li>

9313Bisphosphonates.</li>

9314</ul>

9315</div>

9316<p id="_2611" tabindex="-1">

9317For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/pain/pain-hp-pdq">

9318Cancer Pain</a>

9319.</p>

9320<p id="_2445" tabindex="-1">

9321Evidence (palliation for bone metastases using radiation therapy):</p>

9322<div class="pdq-content-list">

9323<ol id="_2620">

9324<li>

9325EBRT for palliation of bone

9326pain can be very useful. A single fraction of 8 Gy has been shown to have similar benefits on bone pain relief and QOL as multiple fractions (3 Gy &#215; 10) was seen in the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00003162">

9327RTOG-9714</a>

9328 trial (NCT00003162), for example.[<a href="#cit/section_8.51">

932951</a>

9330,<a href="#cit/section_8.52">

933152</a>

9332][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9333Level of evidence A3</a>

9334]</li>

9335</ol>

9336</div>

9337<p id="_2621" tabindex="-1">

9338Evidence (palliation for bone metastases using strontium chloride):</p>

9339<p id="_2622" tabindex="-1">

9340The use of radioisotopes such as 89Sr has been effective as palliative treatment of some patients with osteoblastic metastases. As a single agent, 89Sr has been reported to decrease bone pain in 80% of patients treated.[<a href="#cit/section_8.53">

934153</a>

9342]</p>

9343<div class="pdq-content-list">

9344<ol id="_2564">

9345<li>

9346A multicenter randomized trial of a single IV dose of 89Sr (150 MBq: 4 mCi) versus palliative EBRT was done in men with painful bone metastases from prostate cancer despite hormone treatment.[<a href="#cit/section_8.54">

934754</a>

9348][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9349Level of evidence A1</a>

9350]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.55">

935155</a>

9352]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9353<ul id="_2565">

9354<li>

9355Similar subjective pain response rates were shown in both groups: 34.7% for 89Sr versus 33.3% for EBRT alone. </li>

9356<li>

9357OS was better in the EBRT group than in the 89Sr group (<em>

9358P</em>

9359 = .046; median survival, 11.0 months vs. 7.2 months). </li>

9360<li>

9361No statistically significant differences in time to subjective progression or in PFS were seen.</li>

9362<li>

9363When used as an adjunct to EBRT, 89Sr was shown to slow disease progression and to reduce analgesic requirements, compared with EBRT alone.</li>

9364</ul>

9365</div>

9366</li>

9367</ol>

9368</div>

9369<p id="_2614" tabindex="-1">

9370Evidence (palliation or prevention of bone metastases using denosumab):</p>

9371<div class="pdq-content-list">

9372<ol id="_2615">

9373<li>

9374A placebo-controlled randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00321620">

9375NCT00321620</a>

9376) compared denosumab with zoledronic acid for the prevention of skeletal events (pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, or the need for palliative bone radiation or surgery) in men with hormonal therapy-resistant prostate cancer with at least one bone metastasis.[<a href="#cit/section_8.46">

937746</a>

9378] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9379<ul id="_2616">

9380<li>

9381The trial reported that denosumab was more effective than zoledronic acid; median time to first on-study skeletal event was 20.7 versus 17.1 months (HR, 0.82; 95% CI, 0.71&#8211;0.95).</li>

9382<li>

9383Serious adverse events were reported in 63% of denosumab patients versus 60% in patients on zoledronic acid. The cumulative incidence of osteonecrosis of the jaw was low in both study arms (2% in the denosumab arm vs. 1% in the zoledronic acid arm). There was grade 3 to 4 toxicity. There was no difference in survival. The incidence of hypocalcemia was higher in the denosumab arm (13% vs. 6%).[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

938456</a>

9385]

9386</li>

9387</ul>

9388</div>

9389</li>

9390<li>

9391A randomized placebo-controlled trial included 1,432 men with castration-resistant prostate cancer with no evidence of any metastases who were given denosumab (120 mg administered subcutaneously every 4 weeks) to prevent the first evidence of bone metastasis (whether symptomatic or not).[<a href="#cit/section_8.56">

939256</a>

9393][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810025&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9394Level of evidence B1</a>

9395]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9396<ul id="_2754">

9397<li>

9398After a median follow-up of 20 months, median bone metastasis-free survival was 29.5 versus 25.2 months in the denosumab versus placebo arms (HR, 0.85; 95% CI, 0.73&#8211;0.98; <em>

9399P</em>

9400 = .028). </li>

9401<li>

9402Symptomatic bone metastases were reported in 69 (10%) denosumab patients versus 96 (13%) placebo patients (HR, 0.67; 95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.92; <em>

9403P</em>

9404 = .01).</li>

9405<li>

9406There were no differences in OS between the two groups.</li>

9407<li>

9408Osteonecrosis occurred in 33 (5%) of men on the denosumab arm versus none on the placebo arm. Hypocalcemia occurred in 12 (2%) versus 2 (&lt;1%) men, and urinary retention in 54 (8%) of men on denosumab versus 31 (4%) of men on placebo. </li>

9409</ul>

9410</div>

9411</li>

9412</ol>

9413</div>

9414</section>

9415</section>

9416<section id="_1819">

9417<h3 id="_1819_toc">

9418Treatment Options for Recurrent Prostate Cancer </h3>

9419<p id="_1828" tabindex="-1">

9420Treatment options for patients with <a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_72">

9421recurrent prostate cancer</a>

9422 include the following:</p>

9423<div class="pdq-content-list">

9424<ul id="_2448">

9425<li>

9426Hormone therapy.</li>

9427<li>

9428<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2449">

9429Chemotherapy for hormone-resistant prostate cancer</a>

9430.</li>

9431<li>

9432<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2462">

9433Immunotherapy</a>

9434.</li>

9435<li>

9436<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_2791">

9437Radiopharmaceutical therapy</a>

9438.</li>

9439<li>

9440<a href="/types/prostate/hp/prostate-treatment-pdq#_3184">

9441Poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) inhibitors for men with prostate cancer and <em class="gene-name">

9442BRCA1</em>

9443, <em class="gene-name">

9444BRCA2</em>

9445, and/or <em class="gene-name">

9446ATM</em>

9447 mutations</a>

9448.</li>

9449</ul>

9450</div>

9451<section id="_2449">

9452<h4 id="_2449_toc">

9453Chemotherapy for hormone-resistant prostate cancer</h4>

9454<p id="_2625" tabindex="-1">

9455Evidence (chemotherapy for hormone-resistant prostate cancer):</p>

9456<div class="pdq-content-list">

9457<ol id="_2626">

9458<li>

9459A randomized trial showed improved pain control in patients with hormone-resistant prostate cancer treated with mitoxantrone plus prednisone compared with those treated with prednisone alone.[<a href="#cit/section_8.57">

946057</a>

9461] Differences in OS or measured global QOL between the two treatments were not statistically significant.</li>

9462<li>

9463Docetaxel has been shown to improve OS compared with mitoxantrone. In a randomized trial involving patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer, docetaxel (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

94642</span>

9465 every 3 weeks) and docetaxel (30 mg/m<span class="sup">

94662</span>

9467 weekly for 5 out of every 6 weeks) were compared with mitoxantrone (12 mg/m<span class="sup">

94682</span>

9469 every 3 weeks). All patients received oral prednisone (5 mg bid). Patients in the docetaxel arms also received high-dose dexamethasone pretreatment for each docetaxel administration (8 mg given at 12 hours, 3 hours, and 1 hour before the 3-week regimen; 8 mg given at 1 hour before the 5 out-of-every-6 weeks' regimen).[<a href="#cit/section_8.58">

947058</a>

9471] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9472<ul id="_2453">

9473<li>

9474OS at 3 years was statistically significantly better in the 3-weekly docetaxel arm (18.6%) than in the mitoxantrone arm (13.5%, HR<sub>

9475death,</sub>

9476 0.79; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.93). </li>

9477<li>

9478However, the OS rate for the 5 out-of-every-6 weeks docetaxel regimen was 16.8%, which was not statistically significantly better than mitoxantrone. </li>

9479<li>

9480QOL was also superior in the docetaxel arms compared with mitoxantrone (<em>

9481P</em>

9482 = .009).[<a href="#cit/section_8.59">

948359</a>

9484][Levels of evidence <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9485A1</a>

9486 and <a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9487A3</a>

9488]</li>

9489</ul>

9490</div>

9491</li>

9492<li>

9493 In another randomized trial involving patients with hormone-refractory prostate cancer, a 3-week regimen of estramustine (280 mg PO tid for days 1 to 5, plus daily warfarin and 325 mg aspirin to prevent vascular thrombosis), and docetaxel (60 mg/m<span class="sup">

94942</span>

9495 IV on day 2, preceded by dexamethasone [20 mg &#215; 3 starting the night before]) was compared with mitoxantrone (12 mg/m<span class="sup">

94962</span>

9497 IV every 3 weeks) plus prednisone (5 mg qd).[<a href="#cit/section_8.60">

949860</a>

9499][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9500Level of evidence A1</a>

9501]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9502<ul id="_2454">

9503<li>

9504After a median follow-up of 32 months, median OS was 17.5 months in the estramustine/docetaxel arm versus 15.6 months in the mitoxantrone arm (HR<sub>

9505death,</sub>

9506 0.80; 95% CI, 0.67&#8211;0.97; <em>

9507P</em>

9508 = .02).</li>

9509<li>

9510 Global QOL and pain palliation measures were similar in the two treatment arms.[<a href="#cit/section_8.61">

951161</a>

9512][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9513Level of evidence A3</a>

9514]</li>

9515</ul>

9516</div>

9517</li>

9518<li>

9519 A 2-weekly regimen of docetaxel has been compared with a 3-weekly regimen. OS appeared to be better in the 2-week regimen, and hematologic toxicity was less.[<a href="#cit/section_8.62">

952062</a>

9521][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9522Level of evidence A1</a>

9523]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9524<ul id="_2725">

9525<li>

9526In the trial, 361 men with metastatic hormone-resistant prostate cancer were randomly assigned to receive docetaxel either in a 2-weekly regimen (50 mg/m<span class="sup">

95272</span>

9528 IV) or a 3-weekly regimen (75 mg/m<span class="sup">

95292</span>

9530 IV) until progression. All patients were also to receive prednisolone (10 mg PO qd) and dexamethasone (7.5&#8211;8.0 mg qd), starting the day before and continuing for 1 to 2 days after each docetaxel dose. Fifteen randomly assigned patients (4.2%) were deemed ineligible in retrospect or withdrew consent, and they were dropped from the analysis.</li>

9531<li>

9532With a median follow-up of 18 months, there was a small difference in time to treatment failure, the primary end point of the study (5.6 months [95% CI, 5.0&#8211;6.2] vs. 4.9 months [95% CI, 4.5&#8211;5.4]; <em>

9533P</em>

9534 = .014). However, there was a larger difference in median OS, a secondary end point, in favor of the 2-week regimen (19.5 months [95% CI, 15.9&#8211;23.1] vs. 17.0 months [95% CI, 15.0 &#8211;19.1]; <em>

9535P</em>

9536 = .02). </li>

9537<li>

9538There was a lower rate of grade 3 to 4 neutropenia with the 2-week regimen (36% vs. 53%; <em>

9539P</em>

9540 &lt; .0001) and a lower rate of febrile neutropenia (4% vs. 14%; <em>

9541P</em>

9542 = .001).</li>

9543</ul>

9544</div>

9545</li>

9546<li>

9547In patients with metastatic hormone/castrate-refractory prostate cancer (mCRPC) and no previous chemotherapy, cabazitaxel and docetaxel appeared to provide similar results with respect to OS.[<a href="#cit/section_8.63">

954863</a>

9549]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9550<ul id="_3030">

9551<li>

9552 In the <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT01308567">

9553FIRSTANA</a>

9554 trial (NCT01308567), 1,168 men with mCRPC were randomly assigned (1:1:1 ratio) to receive cabazitaxel 20 mg/m<span class="sup">

95552</span>

9556, cabazitaxel 25 mg/m<span class="sup">

95572</span>

9558, or docetaxel 75 mg/m<span class="sup">

95592</span>

9560 IV every 3 weeks (plus prednisone 10 mg PO qd) until disease progression. Median OS was similar across all three study arms and not statistically significantly different (24.5 vs. 25.2 vs. 24.3 months, respectively), with virtually overlapping survival curves.[<a href="#cit/section_8.63">

956163</a>

9562][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9563Level of evidence A1</a>

9564]</li>

9565<li>

9566 However, toxicities varied across the study arms, with adverse event rates of 41.2%, 60.1%, and 46.0%, respectively, which required urgent treatment.</li>

9567</ul>

9568</div>

9569</li>

9570<li>

9571In patients with mCRPC whose disease progressed during or after treatment with docetaxel, cabazitaxel was shown to improve survival compared with mitoxantrone in a randomized trial (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00417079">

9572NCT00417079</a>

9573).[<a href="#cit/section_8.64">

957464</a>

9575] In this trial, 755 such men were treated with prednisone (10 mg PO qd) and randomly assigned to receive either cabazitaxel (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

95762</span>

9577 IV) or mitoxantrone (12 mg/m<span class="sup">

95782</span>

9579 IV) every 3 weeks.[<a href="#cit/section_8.64">

958064</a>

9581][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9582Level of evidence A1</a>

9583]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9584<ul id="_2627">

9585<li>

9586Median OS was 15.1 months in the cabazitaxel arm and 12.7 months in the mitoxantrone study arm (HR<sub>

9587death,</sub>

9588 0.70; 95% CI, 0.59&#8211;0.83; <em>

9589P</em>

9590 &lt; .0001).</li>

9591</ul>

9592</div>

9593</li>

9594<li>

9595 In a noninferiority-design randomized trial comparing cabazitaxel (20 mg/m<span class="sup">

95962</span>

9597 IV every 3 weeks) with cabazitaxel (25 mg/m<span class="sup">

95982</span>

9599 IV every 3 weeks) in a similar population of 1,200 men with mCRPC who had received previous docetaxel, the lower dose of cabazitaxel fulfilled noninferiority criteria with respect to OS (HR<sub>

9600death,</sub>

9601 1.024; CI, upper bound at 1.184), but with less toxicity.[<a href="#cit/section_8.65">

960265</a>

9603][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9604Level of evidence A1</a>

9605]</li>

9606</ol>

9607</div>

9608<p id="_2459" tabindex="-1">

9609Other chemotherapy regimens reported to produce subjective improvement in symptoms and reduction in PSA level include the following:[<a href="#cit/section_8.66">

961066</a>

9611][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810037&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9612Level of evidence C2</a>

9613]; [<a href="#cit/section_8.67">

961467</a>

9615]</p>

9616<div class="pdq-content-list">

9617<ul id="_2460">

9618<li>

9619Paclitaxel.</li>

9620<li>

9621 Estramustine/etoposide.</li>

9622<li>

9623Estramustine/vinblastine.</li>

9624<li>

9625Estramustine/paclitaxel.</li>

9626</ul>

9627</div>

9628<p id="_2461" tabindex="-1">

9629A study suggests that patients whose tumors exhibit neuroendocrine differentiation are more responsive to chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.68">

963068</a>

9631]</p>

9632</section>

9633<section id="_2462">

9634<h4 id="_2462_toc">

9635Immunotherapy</h4>

9636<p id="_2463" tabindex="-1">

9637Sipuleucel-T, an active cellular immunotherapy, has been shown to increase OS in patients with hormone-refractory metastatic prostate cancer. Sipuleucel-T consists of autologous peripheral blood mononuclear cells that have been exposed ex vivo to a recombinant fusion protein (PA2024) composed of prostatic acid phosphatase fused to granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor. </p>

9638<p id="_2702" tabindex="-1">

9639Side effects are generally consistent with cytokine release and include chills, fever, headache, myalgia, sweating, and influenza-like symptoms, usually within the first 24 hours of infusion. No increase in autoimmune disorders or secondary malignancies has been noted.[<a href="#cit/section_8.69">

964069</a>

9641]</p>

9642<p id="_2464" tabindex="-1">

9643Evidence (immunotherapy):</p>

9644<div class="pdq-content-list">

9645<ol id="_2465">

9646<li>

9647 In the largest trial (Immunotherapy for Prostate Adenocarcinoma Treatment: <a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00065442">

9648IMPACT</a>

9649 trial [NCT00065442]), 512 patients with hormone-refractory metastatic disease were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive sipuleucel-T (n = 341) versus placebo (n = 171) by IV in a 60-minute infusion every 2 weeks for a total of 3 doses.[<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

965070</a>

9651] Patients with visceral metastases, pathological bone fractures, or ECOG performance status worse than 0&#8211;1 were excluded from the study. At documented disease progression, patients in the placebo group could receive, at the physician&#8217;s discretion, infusions manufactured with the same specifications as sipuleucel-T but using cells that had been cryopreserved at the time that the placebo was prepared (63.7% of the placebo patients received these transfusions). Time to disease progression and time to development of disease-related pain were the initial primary end points, but the primary end point was changed before unblinding based upon survival differences in two previous trials of similar design (described below).[<a href="#cit/section_8.70">

965270</a>

9653][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9654Level of evidence A1</a>

9655] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9656<ul id="_2466">

9657<li>

9658 After a median follow-up of 34.1 months, the overall mortality was 61.6% in the sipuleucel-T group versus 70.8% in the placebo group (HR<sub>

9659death,</sub>

9660 0.78; 95% CI, 0.61&#8211;0.98; <em>

9661P</em>

9662 = .03). However, the improved survival was not accompanied by measurable antitumor effects. </li>

9663<li>

9664There was no difference between the study groups in rate of disease progression. In 2011, the estimated price of sipuleucel-T was $93,000 for a 1-month course of therapy. This translates into an estimated cost of about $276,000 per year-of-life saved.[<a href="#cit/section_8.71">

966571</a>

9666] </li>

9667</ul>

9668</div>

9669</li>

9670<li>

9671The same investigators previously performed two smaller trials (<a href="/clinicaltrials/NCT00005947">

9672D9901 and D9902A</a>

9673 [NCT00005947]) of nearly identical design to the IMPACT trial.[<a href="#cit/section_8.72">

967472</a>

9675,<a href="#cit/section_8.73">

967673</a>

9677]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9678<ul id="_2467">

9679<li>

9680The combined results of the two smaller trials, involving a total of 225 patients randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio of sipuleucel-T to placebo were like those in the IMPACT trial. The HR<sub>

9681death</sub>

9682 was 0.67 (95% CI, 0.49&#8211;0.91), but the time-to-progression rates were not statistically significantly different.</li>

9683</ul>

9684</div>

9685 </li>

9686</ol>

9687</div>

9688</section>

9689<p id="_2476" tabindex="-1">

9690Low-dose prednisone may palliate symptoms in some patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.74">

969174</a>

9692] </p>

9693<p id="_2477" tabindex="-1">

9694Evidence (low-dose prednisone for palliation):</p>

9695<div class="pdq-content-list">

9696<ol id="_2478">

9697<li>

9698A randomized comparison of prednisone (5 mg qid) with flutamide (250 mg tid) was conducted in patients with disease progression after androgen ablative therapy (castration or LH-RH agonist).[<a href="#cit/section_8.75">

969975</a>

9700] <div class="pdq-content-list">

9701<ul id="_2479">

9702<li>

9703 Prednisone and flutamide produced similar OS, symptomatic response, PSA response, and time to progression; however, there were statistically significant differences in pain, nausea and vomiting, and diarrhea in patients who received prednisone. For more information, see <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/pain/pain-hp-pdq">

9704Cancer Pain</a>

9705, <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/nausea/nausea-hp-pdq">

9706Nausea and Vomiting Related to Cancer Treatment</a>

9707, and <a href="/about-cancer/treatment/side-effects/constipation/GI-complications-hp-pdq">

9708Gastrointestinal Complications</a>

9709. </li>

9710</ul>

9711</div>

9712</li>

9713</ol>

9714</div>

9715<p id="_2480" tabindex="-1">

9716Ongoing clinical trials continue to explore the value of chemotherapy for these patients.[<a href="#cit/section_8.10">

971710</a>

9718-<a href="#cit/section_8.13">

971913</a>

9720,<a href="#cit/section_8.57">

972157</a>

9722,<a href="#cit/section_8.66">

972366</a>

9724-<a href="#cit/section_8.68">

972568</a>

9726]</p>

9727<section id="_2791">

9728<h4 id="_2791_toc">

9729Radiopharmaceutical therapy</h4>

9730<section id="_2718">

9731<h5 id="_2718_toc">

9732Alpha emitter radiation</h5>

9733<p id="_2719" tabindex="-1">

9734Radium Ra 223 (223Ra) emits alpha particles (i.e., two protons and two neutrons bound together, identical to a helium nucleus) with a half-life of 11.4 days. It is administered by IV and selectively taken up by newly formed bone stroma. The high-energy alpha particles have a short range of &lt;100 mcM. 223Ra improved OS in patients with prostate cancer metastatic to the bone. </p>

9735<p id="_2720" tabindex="-1">

9736Evidence (alpha emitter radiation):</p>

9737<div class="pdq-content-list">

9738<ol id="_2721">

9739<li>

9740In a placebo-controlled trial, 921 men with symptomatic castration-resistant prostate cancer, two or more bone metastases, and no known visceral metastases, were randomly assigned in a 2:1 ratio to receive 223Ra at a dose of 50kBq per kg body weight every 4 weeks for six injections versus placebo. All study participants had already received docetaxel, were not healthy enough to receive it, or declined it.[<a href="#cit/section_8.76">

974176</a>

9742,<a href="#cit/section_8.77">

974377</a>

9744]<div class="pdq-content-list">

9745<ul id="_2722">

9746<li>

9747 Median OS was 14.9 months in the 223Ra study group versus 11.3 months in the placebo groups (HR<sub>

9748mortality,</sub>

9749 0.70; 95% CI, 0.58&#8211;0.83; <em>

9750P</em>

9751 &lt; .001).[<a href="#cit/section_8.76">

975276</a>

9753][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810017&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9754Level of evidence A1</a>

9755] </li>

9756<li>

9757 The rates of symptomatic skeletal events (33% vs. 38%) and spinal cord compression (4% vs. 7%) were also statistically significantly improved. </li>

9758<li>

9759Prospectively measured, QOL was also better in the 223Ra study group (25% vs. 16% had a &#8805;10 point improvement on a scale of 0 to 156; <em>

9760P</em>

9761 = .02).[<a href="#cit/section_8.76">

976276</a>

9763][<a href="/Common/PopUps/popDefinition.aspx?id=810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English" onclick="javascript:popWindow('defbyid','CDR0000810021&amp;version=HealthProfessional&amp;language=English'); return(false);">

9764Level of evidence A3</a>

9765]</li>

9766<li>

9767 With administration of 223Ra at a dose of 50kBq per kg of body weight every 4 weeks for 6 injections, the side effects were like those of a placebo.</li>

9768</ul>

9769</div>

9770</li>

9771</ol>

9772</div>

9773</section>

9774</section>

9775<section id="_3184">

9776<h4 id="_3184_toc">

9777PARP inhibitors for men with prostate cancer and <em class="gene-name">

9778BRCA1</em>

9779, <em class="gene-name">

9780BRCA2</em>

9781, and/or <em class="gene-name">

9782ATM</em>

9783 mutations</h4>

9784<section id="_3185">

9785<h5 id="_3185_toc">

9786 Olaparib</h5>

9787<p id="_3186" tabindex="-1">

9788Evidence (olaparib):</p>

9789<div class="pdq-content-list">

9790<ol id="_3187">

9791<li>

9792The PARP inhibitor olaparib was tested in an open-label, phase III, randomized controlled trial in men with metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer and mutations in one of 15 prespecified genes related to homologous recombination repair, including <em class="gene-name">

9793BRCA1</em>

9794 or <em class="gene-name">

9795BRCA2</em>

9796. The men had previously received enzalutamide, abiraterone, or both, with or without previous taxane chemotherapy.[<a href="#cit/section_8.78">

979778</a>

9798] The trial enrolled 387 men and randomly assigned them in a 2:1 ratio to receive olaparib (300 mg twice daily) or physician's choice of enzalutamide or abiraterone plus prednisone. <p id="_3189" tabindex="-1">

9799Cohort A included 245 patients with at least one mutation in <em class="gene-name">

9800BRCA1</em>

9801, <em class="gene-name">

9802BRCA2</em>

9803, or <em class="gene-name">

9804ATM</em>

9805. Cohort B included 142 patients with at least one mutation in one of the other 12 prespecified genes.</p>

9806 <div class="pdq-content-list">

9807<ul id="_3188">

9808<li>

9809 The median OS in cohort A was 19.1 months for patients who received olaparib and 14.7 months for patients who received the control regimen (HR, 0.69; 95% CI, 0.50&#8211;0.97). A sensitivity analysis adjusting for crossover to olaparib in the control arm reported an HR of 0.42 (95% CI, 0.19&#8211;0.91).</li>

9810<li>

9811 There was no significant OS benefit in cohort B.</li>

9812<li>

9813 There was no significant OS benefit in the overall population.</li>

9814<li>

9815 The most common adverse events for patients who received olaparib were anemia (50%), nausea (43%), and fatigue or asthenia (42%).</li>

9816</ul>

9817</div>

9818</li>

9819</ol>

9820</div>

9821</section>

9822</section>

9823</section>

9824<section id="_TrialSearch_72_sid_8">

9825<h3 id="_TrialSearch_72_sid_8_toc">

9826Current Clinical Trials</h3>

9827<p id="_TrialSearch_72_22" tabindex="-1">

9828Use our <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/search/advanced">

9829advanced clinical trial search</a>

9830 to find NCI-supported cancer clinical trials that are now enrolling patients. The search can be narrowed by location of the trial, type of treatment, name of the drug, and other criteria. <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/" title="https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/">

9831General information</a>

9832 about clinical trials is also available.</p>

9833</section>

9922Kelly WK, Scher HI, Mazumdar M, et al.: Prostate-specific antigen as a measure of disease outcome in metastatic hormone-refractory prostate cancer. J Clin Oncol 11 (4): 607-15, 1993.&#160;<a href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7683043&amp;dopt=Abstract" title="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=Retrieve&amp;db=PubMed&amp;list_uids=7683043&amp;dopt=Abstract">

9923[PUBMED Abstract]</a>

10155

10156 <section id="_2857">

10157

10158 <h2>

10159Key References for Prostate Cancer</h2>

10160

10161 <div id="_section_2857" class="pdq-sections">

10162<p id="_2858" tabindex="-1">

10163These references have been identified by members of the <a href="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment" title="https://www.cancer.gov/publications/pdq/editorial-boards/adult-treatment">

10164PDQ Adult Treatment Editorial Board</a>

10165 as significant in the field of prostate cancer treatment. This list is provided to inform users of important studies that have helped shape the current understanding of and treatment options for prostate cancer. Listed after each reference are the sections within this summary where the reference is cited.</p>

10166<div class="pdq-content-list">

10167<ul id="_2859">

10168<li>
